232.01   ESTABLISHMENT AND COMPOSITION.
   A Police Department is hereby established in and for the City. The
Department shall consist of the Chief of Police and such other officers and
employees as may be determined from time to time by Council.
(Ord. 13-59. Passed 3-23-59.)
232.015   MAXIMUM AGE LIMITATION.  (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE:  Section 232.015 was repealed by Ordinance 14-96, passed
February 5, 1996.)
232.02   ORDER OF RANK; PROMOTIONS.
   (A)   Promotion within the Police Department shall be by successive ranks
established as follows:
      (1)   Chief of Police;
      (2)   Major;
      (3)   Lieutenant;
      (4)   Sergeant;
      (5)   Patrol Officer; and
      (6)   Meter Officer.
   (B)   Within the ranks below that of Sergeant, Council may establish such
special positions having special duties with preferential pay as Council deems
necessary, but the existence of such special positions shall not establish
eligibility for promotion to the next higher rank. No special position
established by Council within the ranks below that of Sergeant shall be filled
without promotional examination.
   (C)   The positions of detective, identification officer and clerk shall
carry the rank of patrol officer.
   (D)   When an examination is held for any rank above patrol officer, all
incumbents of the next lower rank who meet the seniority and efficiency
standards established by the Civil Service Board shall be eligible.
If no more than one incumbent of the next lower rank meets such requirements,
the Civil Service Board shall be authorized to open the examination to
incumbents of the next lower rank.
(Ord. 50-86. Passed 4-21-86; Ord. 144-97.  Passed 10-6-97.)
232.03   CHAIN OF COMMAND.
   (A)   The Chief of Police shall serve as the commanding law enforcement
officer for the members of the City of Lima Police Department.
   (B)   The Chief of Police shall also serve as the commanding law enforcement
officer for all other law enforcement officials with police powers working in
any other city department, solely with respect to their exercise of law
enforcement powers granted or derived under the authority of the Chief or
Mayor.  This provision shall not affect or impair the authority of the Fire
Chief or any member of the Fire Department granted under any other provision of
the City Code, City ordinance, or under Ohio law.
   (C)   The chain of command within the Police Department is established as
follows: The superior officer below the rank of Chief of Police shall be
determined by seniority within each rank.
(Ord. 31-55. Passed 3-28-55; Ord. 005-17. Passed 2-6-17.)
232.04   FILLING OF TEMPORARY VACANCIES.
   The Mayor is hereby authorized and directed to make temporary appointments
to fill such vacancies in the Police Department as may be occasioned by the
sickness, disability or vacation of the regular employees of the Department.
(1956 Code Sec. 137.02)
232.05   UNIFORM FUNDS AND ALLOWANCES.
   (A)   Uniform Fund; Establishment and Purpose. There is hereby established a
Uniform Fund for members of the Police Department for the purpose of allocating
money for the purchase of uniforms and clothing for Department members required
to wear the same in the line of duty. The Uniform Fund shall be placed under
the supervision of the City Auditor and disbursed under his direction in the
manner herein stipulated.
   (B)   Use of Fund. The Uniform Fund shall be used for the sole purpose of
purchasing various items of official uniforms and clothing required to be worn
by Police Department members, which items of uniforms and clothing so purchased
shall at all times remain the property of the City.
(Ord. 195-52. Passed 10-27-52.)
   (C)   Uniform Allowances. Each member of the Police Department, upon
appointment, shall receive one holster, one Sam Browne belt, one handcuff case,
one cartridge holder, two belt holders, one key holder, one baton ring, one
trouser belt, one nylon jacket, five long-sleeve shirts, five short-sleeve
shirts, two caps, three year-round trousers, one pair of shoes, one whistle,
one chain, two name tags and two ties.
   Upon the successful completion of a twelve-month probationary period, each
member shall receive one dress blouse and one closed holster.
   Upon satisfactory completion of a three-month probationary period, each
member shall receive additional clothing and other items at the rate of twenty-
five dollars ($25.00) per month for each month remaining in the calendar year
of appointment. Thereafter, each member, during such time as he or she is
required to wear an official police uniform, shall receive an allowance not
exceeding three hundred dollars ($300.00) in any calendar year. Such sum of
three hundred dollars ($300.00) shall be cumulative. If such sum is not fully
used in one calendar year, the balance shall be credited to such member for use
in subsequent years.
   Upon assignment of any member of the Police Department to the Detective
Division or the Plain-Clothes Squad or as Juvenile Court officer, such member
shall be entitled to receive a clothing allowance in the amount of twenty-five
dollars ($25.00) for each month of such assignment, to be used for the purchase
of clothing commonly worn by such officers while on duty. The Chief of Police
shall also receive a monthly clothing allowance of twenty- five dollars
($25.00). These clothing allowances are to be administered under the same terms
and conditions pertaining to the uniform allowance.
   Upon appointment of any member of the Police Department as a Corrections
Officer, such member shall be entitled to receive a first-year clothing
allowance in the amount of three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00); after the
first year of his appointment, such member shall be entitled to a yearly
clothing allowance of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). These clothing
allowances are to be administered under the same terms and conditions
pertaining to the uniform allowance.
   (D)   Use of Allowances. It is hereby determined by Council that the initial
allowance given to a person upon his original appointment to the Police
Department shall be for the purchase of new wearing apparel and that the annual
allowance provided in subsection (c) hereof shall be available to the member to
cover ordinary wear and tear and replacement of such clothing.
   (E)   Uniform Emergency Replacement Fund. In the event that a uniform or
portion of a uniform worn by a member of the Police Department is damaged
beyond repair or destroyed while a police officer is engaged in performing a
particular assignment in the line of duty, then upon special application by
such member, approved by the Chief of Police and by the Mayor, the City Auditor
is authorized to disburse from a special fund, known as the Uniform Emergency
Replacement Fund, a sufficient sum of money to be applied by the City toward
the purchase of wearing apparel and uniforms to replace the articles of
clothing so damaged or destroyed. In order to authorize the purchase of such
apparel from the Uniform Emergency Replacement Fund the City Auditor shall be
satisfied that such application is within the scope of the provisions of this
section and that such expenditure is not required because of reasonable wear
and tear experienced by the Police Department member with respect to such
clothing but is in fact required as a result of unforeseen and extraordinary
circumstances. 
   (F)   Records. The City Auditor is hereby authorized and directed to keep a
separate ledger account of each individual member of the Police Department,
disclosing the amount made available for the purchase of clothing by action of
Council, as the same may be amended from time to time, the items of clothing
and apparel purchased for such member by the City, the date of the order, the
date of the delivery of the clothing, the cost thereof and such other
information as the City Auditor may deem advisable or necessary.
   The City Auditor is further authorized and directed to make any additional
regulations necessary for the purpose of properly administering the provisions
of this section.
(Ord. 52-86. Passed 5-5-86.)
232.06   WEAPON ALLOWANCE. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section 232.06 was repealed by Ordinance 203-77, passed
December 5, 1977.)
232.061   POLICE RETIREMENT BENEFIT.
   Each police officer with an accumulated service with the City of Lima, Ohio,
of twenty-five years or more, upon his retirement from the Police Department,
shall have the right to purchase his service revolver for the sum of one dollar
($1.00), payable to the City Auditor. The Chief of Police shall keep a record
of the name and address of the retiring officer, together with the make, serial
number and model number of the weapon purchased.
(Ord. 197-77. Passed 11-21-77.)
232.07   ALARM SYSTEMS.
   (A)   Definitions.
      (1)   "Alarm receiving device" means the instrumentation on an alarm
console at the receiving terminal of a signal line which, through both visual
and audible signals, shows when an alarm device at a particular location has
been activated, or indicates line trouble.
      (2)   "Alarm system" means any mechanical or electrical device which is
designed or used for the detection of an unauthorized entry into a building,
structure, facility or vehicle and for alerting others of the commission of an
unlawful act within a building, structure, or facility, or both, and which
emits a sound or transmits a signal or message when actuated. Alarm systems
include, but are not limited to, automatic dial protection devices, central
stations, modified central stations, direct dial telephone devices, audible
alarms and proprietor alarms. Devices perceptible outside of the protected
building, structure, or facility are not included within this definition, nor
are auxiliary devices installed by the telephone company to protect the
telephone company system which might be damaged or disrupted by the use of an
alarm system.
      (3)   "Alarm user" means the person, firm, partnership, association,
corporation, company, or organization of any kind in control of any building,
structure, facility, or motor vehicle wherein an alarm system is maintained.
For the purpose of this definition, the registered owner of the motor vehicle
shall be considered the alarm user.
      (4)   "Appellant"  means a person who perfects an appeal pursuant to this
section.
      (5)   "Audible alarm" means a device designed for the detection of an
unauthorized entry on premises which generates an audible sound on the premises
when it is actuated.
      (6)   "Automatic dial protection devices" refers to an alarm system which
automatically sends, over regular telephone lines, by direct connection or
otherwise, a prerecorded voice message or coded signal indicating the existence
of the emergency situation that the alarm system is designed to detect.
      (7)   "Central station" means a system in which the operation of
electrical protection circuits and devices is signaled automatically to,
recorded in, maintained, and supervised from, a central station having trained
operators and guards in attendance at all times.
      (8)   "Commercial enterprise/establishment" means any commercial
enterprise or business as defined in
Chapter 1252 of these Codified Ordinances.
      (9)   "Direct dial telephone device" refers to an alarm system which
automatically sends, over regular telephone lines, by direct connection or
otherwise, a prerecorded voice message or coded signal indicating the existence
of the emergency situation that the alarm system is designed to detect.
      (10)   "False alarm" means an alarm signal which elicits a response by
fire or police units when a burglary, robbery or life-threatening emergency
situation does not in fact exist, but does not include an alarm signal caused
by conditions of nature such as tornadoes, earthquakes, or other violent
conditions.
      (11)   "Governmental agency" means any agency of the United States
Government, the State of Ohio, counties, municipal corporations, departments
thereof and other governmental entities.
      (12)   "Modified central station" means an office to which remote alarm
and supervisory signaling devices are connected, where operators supervise the
circuits.
      (13)   "Police chief" means the Police Chief of the City of Lima or his
or her designated representative.
      (14)   "Police response" means any response of Lima police personnel to
any alarm system location upon actuation of such alarm system.
      (15)   "Proprietor alarm" means an alarm which is not serviced by an
alarm business.
   (B)   Audible Alarm Requirements.  Every person maintaining an audible alarm
shall post a notice containing the names and telephone numbers of persons to be
notified to render repairs or service and secure the premises during any hour
of the day or night that the alarm is functioning. Such notice shall be posted
near the alarm in such a position as to be legible from ground level adjacent
to the building where the alarm system is located.
   (C)   Alarm Connection Within the Police Department.  The following
conditions shall be met for connection of an alarm system to an alarm receiving
device located on the premises of the Lima Police Department:
      (1)   The alarm system user shall be actively engaged in commercial
enterprise or be an active governmental agency.
      (2)   The protected premises and/or persons of such commercial
establishment or governmental agency shall be located within the corporate
limits of the City of Lima, or be within the jurisdiction of the Lima Police
Department.
      (3)   The alarm system shall be compatible with the alarm receiving
device located on the premises of the Lima Police Department.
      (4)   Such connection is agreeable between the alarm user and the alarm
company owning or maintaining an alarm receiving device located on the premises
of the Lima Police Department.
      (5)   The alarm user shall file an application for connection, with the
Chief of Police, on the prescribed form.
      (6)   It shall be the responsibility of the alarm user to contact the
utility company to arrange such connection and provide necessary interface
equipment for connection to the alarm receiving device.
      (7)   Every alarm user connected to the police alarm receiving device
shall keep current at the Lima Police Department a list containing the names
and telephone numbers of persons to be notified to render repairs or service
and secure the premises during any hour of the day or night that an alarm is
functioning. Any changes of persons responsible and/or their telephone numbers
shall be provided to the Chief of Police, in writing, within  seventy-two hours
of such changes.
      (8)   The alarm user shall, upon receipt of an order to disconnect issued
by the Chief of Police, disconnect his or her alarm from the receiving device
located on Lima Police Department premises within ten business days of such
notice. Such order shall be issued for non- compliance with one or more
provisions of this section. When an appeal is filed, as provided in subsection
(f) hereof, the order to disconnect will be stayed pending a determination by
the hearing commission.
      (9)   No person shall install, connect, or maintain any automatic dial
protection device which sends a recorded message or alarm over regular
telephone lines into the communications center, or any other telephone, of the
Lima Police Department. This paragraph shall not apply to City-owned or leased
devices or equipment.
   (D)   False Alarms.
      (1)   Whenever there is a police response to a false alarm, the alarm
user shall be charged a fee as provided in the following fee schedule:
         (a)   First response to the location of a false alarm, no charge to
the subscriber;
         (b)   Two to three false alarms within one-half of a calendar year,
twenty-five dollars ($25.00) each, plus a late fee of two dollars and fifty
cents ($2.50) per false alarm each month if not paid within thirty days of
billing;
         (c)   Four to twelve false alarms within one-half of a calendar year,
fifty dollars ($50.00) each, plus a late fee of five dollars ($5.00) per false
alarm each month if not paid within thirty days of billing;
         (d)   Thirteen or more false alarms within one-half of a calendar
year, one hundred dollars ($100.00) each, plus a later fee of ten dollars
($10.00) per false alarm each month if not paid within thirty days of billing.
      (2)   This section shall apply to all residential, commercial and
vehicular alarm systems.
      (3)   False alarms that qualify under Sections
648.09 and 1610.02 of these Codified Ordinances are exempt from this section.
      (4)   For administrative purposes, the six-month period pertaining to the
fee schedule shall begin on January 1 and July 1 of each year.
   (E)   Testing of Equipment. No alarm system designed to transmit emergency
messages directly to the Police Department shall be tested or demonstrated
without first obtaining permission from the Uniform Division Officer-in-
Charge. Permission is not required to test or demonstrate alarm devices not
transmitting emergency messages directly to the Police Department unless the
messages are to be relayed to the Police Department.
   (F)   Appeal Procedure.
      (1)   Upon receipt of a false alarm billing or order to disconnect from
the alarm receiving device located on the premises of the Lima Police
Department, the alarm user may, within five business days, submit a written
Notice of Appeal by first class mail, return receipt requested, for a hearing
before the Small Claims Committee of Lima City Council, setting forth the
reasons why such billing order to disconnect is being contested. The alarm fee
must accompany the written request for a hearing.
      (2)   Within 14 days of the date of the Notice of Appeal, a written
statement and all evidence supporting the appeal shall be submitted to the
Small Claims Committee, 117 E. Market Street, Lima, Ohio 45801.
      (3)   Within 30 days of the receipt of evidence supporting the appeal,
the Small Claims Committee shall, by first class mail, notify the appellant of
its decision. The Committee may require that the billing be paid and/or that
the disconnect order be upheld. The Committee may also find that the conditions
of this section have been complied with and may, therefore, void the billing
and/or rescind the disconnect order. If the billing is voided, or the
disconnect order rescinded, the alarm fee shall be returned to the alarm user.
   (G)   Collection of Costs.  If the owner of the alarm system fails to pay
the cost of the false alarms within 30 days after being notified in writing of
the amount thereof, the following shall apply:
      (1)   The Director of Law is authorized to bring suit or to take other
legal action to collect all such expenses or costs incurred by the City
pursuant to this section.
      (2)   Expenses shall include the cost of preparing and serving notices.
      (3)   The notification of costs and expenses incurred by the Police
Department may be made by ordinary mail addressed to the owner of the alarm
system or the address of the business of the alarm system.
(Ord. 127-92.  Passed 9-28-92.)
232.08   COUNTY POLICE PROTECTION.
   The Chief of Police of the City, is hereby authorized to extend police
protection to Allen County, Ohio, and all other political subdivisions located
therein, whether townships or municipalities and to those portions of those
municipalities which are located partly within and partly without the
boundaries of Allen County, Ohio.
(Ord. 111-81.  Passed 8-10-81.)
232.09   POLICE AIDE TRAINEE PERS EXEMPTION.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section 232.09 was repealed by Ordinance 39-84, passed April
23, 1984.)
232.10   DIVISION OF CODE ENFORCEMENT. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section 232.10 was repealed by Ordinance 27-89, passed
February 27, 1989.)
232.11   FEE FOR FINGERPRINTING SERVICES.
   Any interested party desiring fingerprinting services may obtain such
services upon payment to the Police Department of a fee of five dollars ($5.00)
for each person fingerprinted.  No fee shall be charged to representatives of
governmental agencies.
(Ord. 57-88.  Passed 5-16-88; Ord. 44-98.  Passed 3-9-98.)
232.12   AUXILIARY POLICE.
   (A)   Establishment.  Pursuant to Ohio R.C. 737.051, there is hereby
established within the Police Department an auxiliary police force, the members
of which shall be appointed by the Mayor with the recommendation of the Chief
of Police. The establishment of an auxiliary police force will in no way affect
the strength ordinance of the Department.
   (B)   Service.  Auxiliary police officers shall serve as long as the Mayor
may direct or until resignation in writing is submitted to the Mayor or upon a
violation of the rules and regulations of the Department as determined by the
Mayor.
   (C)   Command.  The Chief of Police shall be the commanding officer of the
auxiliary police force.  The Chief of Police or his or her designee shall have
control of the assignment, training, stationing and direction of auxiliary
police officers.
   (D)   Powers.  Auxiliary police officers shall have all police powers, but
shall perform only such police duties as are assigned specifically in writing
by the Chief of Police or his or her designee and shall act only when they are
in the prescribed uniform.  The Chief of Police shall describe the time and
place such uniform shall be worn.  Auxiliary police officers shall obey the
chain of command within the Department, shall take orders from all regularly
appointed members thereof and shall be subject to the Rules and Regulations and
the Policies and Procedures of the Department.
   (E)   Rules and Regulations.  The Chief of Police, with the approval of the
Mayor, shall prescribe the rules and regulations for the appointment of
auxiliary police officers, their conduct and the control of the auxiliary
police force.
   (F)   Conditions of Service.  Auxiliary police officers shall serve on a
voluntary basis, shall not be compensated in any manner by the City, and shall
in no manner be considered employees of the City because of their membership in
the police auxiliary.  Auxiliary police officers shall be responsible for all
expenses incurred for training, uniforms, medical insurance and liability
insurance.
(Ord. 89-92.  Passed 11-23-92.)
232.13   FEES FOR BOMB DISPOSAL UNIT SERVICES.
   (A)   Unless specifically excepted by this section, a fee will be imposed on
each and every occasion that the Police Department responds to the need or
request to provide disposal service in order to dispose of explosive materials
or devices.  The person or other entity that is in possession or control of the
property, premises or residence to which the police are directed for disposal
services shall be held liable and responsible for payment of the fee whether
that person is the owner, tenant, lessee, occupant or officer of the premises
or in some other manner exercises possession and control of the premises,
property or residence.
   (B)   The fees charged for disposal services provided by the Police
Department shall be as follows:
      (1)   Calls within Allen County shall be charged at three hundred forty
dollars ($340.00) per call, unless such call requires more than four hours from
the time of dispatch to the time the bomb disposal unit completes all duties
relating to the call, in which case an additional fee of eighty-five dollars
($85.00) per hour will be charged.  In addition, if required, any and all other
incidental expenses, such as, but not limited to, the cost of nonreusable
equipment and/or the cost of any and all damage incurred to equipment, shall be
added to the fee.
      (2)   Calls outside of Allen County shall be charged at three hundred
forty dollars ($340.00) per call, unless such call requires more than four
hours from the time of dispatch to the time the bomb disposal unit completes
all duties relating to the call, in which case an additional fee of eighty-five
dollars ($85.00) per hour will be charged.  In addition, if required, any and
all other incidental expenses, such as, but not limited to, the cost of
nonreusable equipment and/or the cost of any and all damage incurred to
equipment, shall be added to the fee.  Mileage for calls outside Allen County
shall be in addition to the above charges and shall be determined in accordance
with current Federal standards.
      (3)   All calls for such services from the City, from agencies and
offices of the government of Allen County, and from all schools in Allen
County, shall be exempt from the fee provided for above.
      (4)   The fee charged under this section shall be paid within thirty days
after the date of billing from the Police Department.  The notification of the
fee incurred by the Bomb Disposal Unit of the Police Department may be made by
ordinary mail addressed to the person in charge or control of the property or
business.  If the person in charge or control of the property or business fails
to pay such fee within thirty days after being notified in writing of the
amount thereof, such fee may be collected by the taking of a judgment against
such person, and the Director of Law is hereby authorized to bring suit or to
take other necessary legal action to collect all such expenses or costs
incurred by the City pursuant to this section.
   (C)   All moneys received under this section will be used specifically for
the training and purchasing of equipment for the Police Department's Bomb
Disposal Unit. 
   (D)   No fee shall be charged for services under this section when such 
fees  are  reimbursed pursuant to agreement between the city and the Bureau of
Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and explosives (ATF), as determined by the Chief of
Police.
(Ord. 125-92.  Passed 9-23-92.; Ord. 024-05. Passed 2-7-05.)
CHAPTER 234
Fire Department
   EDITOR'S NOTE: The City enters into Agreements from time to time with the
International Association of Fire Fighters, Local 334, AFL-CIO, which
Agreements provide for rights, privileges, duties and immunities of the City
and Fire Department personnel, conditions and incidents of employment, benefits
and the like. In the event of a conflict or inconsistency between any of the
provisions of this chapter and a provision of such Agreements, the latter
controls. Copies of such Agreements and of all relevant legislation may be
obtained, at cost, from the Clerk of Council.

234.01   ESTABLISHMENT AND COMPOSITION.
   A Fire Department is hereby established in and for the City. The Department
shall consist of the Fire Chief and such other officers and employees as may be
determined from time to time by Council.
(1956 Code Sec. 139.01)
234.015   MAXIMUM AGE FOR ORIGINAL APPOINTMENTS.  (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE:  Section 234.015 was repealed by Ordinance 40-95, passed
April 10, 1995.)
234.02   DUTIES OF FIRE CHIEF.
   The Chief of the Fire Department shall also act as Chief of the Bureau of
Fire Prevention. In the event of the temporary absence or disability of the
Chief of the Fire Department, all the authority herein conferred upon the Chief
to act as Chief of the Fire Prevention Bureau shall be vested in the Acting
Chief of the Fire Department.
(1956 Code Sec. 139.02)
234.03   ORDER OF RANK; PROMOTIONS.
   (a)   Promotion within the Fire Department shall be by successive ranks
established as follows:
      (1)   Fire Chief;
      (2)   Deputy Chief;
      (3)   Battalion Chief;
      (4)   Fire Captain;
      (5)   Fire Lieutenant; and
      (6)   Fire-fighter.
   (b)   Within the ranks below that of Fire Lieutenant, Council may establish
such special positions having special duties with preferential pay as Council
deems necessary, but the existence of such special positions shall not
establish eligibility for promotion to the next higher rank. No special
position established by Council within the ranks below that of Fire Lieutenant
shall be filled without promotional examination.
   (c)   The positions of fire alarm inspector, fire mechanic, fire prevention
inspector, and fire-fighter clerk shall carry the rank of fire-fighter.
   (d)   When an examination is held for any rank above fire-fighter, all
incumbents of the next lower rank who meet the seniority and efficiency
standards established by the Civil Service Board shall be eligible. If no more
than one incumbent of the next lower rank meets such requirements, the Civil
Service Board shall be authorized to open the examination to incumbents of the
next lower rank.
(Ord. 130-66. Passed 6-28-66; Ord. 168-11. Passed 8-8- 11; Ord. 275-12. Passed
12-17-12.)
234.04   CHAIN OF COMMAND.
   The chain of command within the Fire Department is established as follows:
The superior officer below the rank of Fire Chief shall be determined by
seniority within each rank.
(Ord. 127-57. Passed 10-7-57.)
234.05   FILLING OF TEMPORARY VACANCIES.
   The Mayor is hereby authorized and directed to make temporary appointments
to fill such vacancies in the Fire Department as may be occasioned by the
sickness, disability or vacation of the regular employees in the Department.
(1956 Code Sec. 139.03)
234.06   ESTABLISHMENT OF A FIFTY-SIX HOUR WEEK.
   (a)   In order to provide for the establishment of a fifty-six hour week,
except as otherwise stipulated herein, on and after July 1, 1969, the Fire
Chief shall be required to divide the membership of the Fire Department into
not less than three platoons and to operate the Department as a three-platoon
system by at all times keeping one platoon on duty twenty-four consecutive
hours. The average work week shall not exceed fifty-six hours per week, except
in cases of emergency.
   (b)   The provisions of subsection (a) hereof relative to the establishment
of a fifty-six hour week shall not apply to the following positions and class
titles in the Fire Department: Fire Chief, Deputy Chief, fire prevention
inspector I, fire prevention inspector II, arson investigator I, arson
investigator II, and any trainee during his probationary period. The
requirements of subsection (a) hereof shall not apply during any period of
emergency.
(Ord. 276-12. Passed 12-17-12.)
234.07   UNIFORM FUNDS.
   (a)   Uniform Account; Establishment and Purpose. There is hereby
established a Uniform Account for the members of the Fire Department for the
purpose of allocating money for the purchase of uniforms and clothing for
Department members required to wear the same in the line of duty. The Uniform
Account shall be placed under the supervision of the City Auditor and disbursed
under his direction in the manner herein stipulated.
   (b)   Use of Account. The Uniform Account shall be used for the sole purpose
of purchasing various items of official uniforms and clothing required to be
worn by Fire Department members, which items of uniforms and clothing so
purchased shall at all times remain the property of the City.
   (c)   Uniform Emergency Replacement Account. In the event that a uniform or
portion of a uniform worn by a member of the Fire Department is damaged beyond
repair or destroyed while a Fire Department member is engaged in performing a
particular assignment in the line of duty, then upon special application by
such member, approved by the Fire Chief and by the Mayor, the City Auditor is
authorized to disburse from a special account, known as the Uniform Emergency
Replacement Account, a sufficient sum of money to be applied by the City toward
the purchase of wearing apparel and uniforms to replace the articles of
clothing so damaged or destroyed. In order to authorize the purchase of such
apparel from the Uniform Emergency Replacement Account the City Auditor shall
be satisfied that such application is within the scope of the provisions of
this section and that such expenditure is not required because of reasonable
wear and tear experienced by the Fire Department member with respect to such
clothing but is in fact required as a result of unforeseen and extraordinary
circumstances.
   (d)   Records. The City Auditor is hereby authorized and directed to keep a
separate ledger account of each individual member of the Fire Department,
disclosing the amount made available for the purchase of clothing by action of
Council, as the same may be amended from time to time, the items of clothing
and apparel purchased for such member by the City, the date of the order, the
date of the delivery of the clothing, the cost thereof and such other
information as the City Auditor may deem advisable or necessary.
   The City Auditor is further authorized and directed to make any additional
regulations necessary for the purpose of properly administering the provisions
of this section.
   (e)   Control of Funds by Council. Council shall appropriate from year to
year an amount sufficient to cover the requirements of the Fire Department by
reason of the amounts allocated to each individual member in the manner herein
set forth and shall furthermore appropriate such amount of money as may be
deemed advisable to be placed in the Uniform Emergency Replacement Account
provided for in subsection (e) hereof. No individual Fire Department member
shall have a vested right in any amount of money allocated in the manner herein
set forth, and, upon severance of his connection with the Department, whether
such severance is by voluntary act of the member, by action of the appointing
authority or by death, any unused amount of money for such purpose shall be
retained by the City and shall revert to the General Fund. 
(Ord. 100-83. Passed 5-23-83; Ord. 277-12. Passed 1-7-13.)
234.08   SUBSISTENCE ALLOWANCE. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section 234.08 was repealed by Ordinance 203-77, passed
December 5, 1977.)
234.09   EMERGENCY FIRE PROTECTION TO OUTSIDE AREAS NOT COVERED BY CONTRACT.
   Pursuant to the authority granted by Ohio R.C. 9.60, the services of the
Fire Department and the use of its fire apparatus and personnel may be extended
beyond the corporate limits to areas not covered by special contracts for fire
protection or by contracts for mutual aid if the following conditions are met:
   (A)   The dispatching of the personnel and equipment of the Fire Department
to areas not covered by contract may be made in the event of a public disaster,
catastrophe, general conflagration or extreme emergency.
   (B)   The dispatching of the equipment and personnel of the Fire Department
to the scene of the fire shall be made only upon the authority of the Fire
Chief or of the officer in charge of the Department at the time thereof and
shall be made only when consistent with the proper protection of the City, as
determined by such officer and upon a finding by such officer that such action
is justified.
(Ord. 69-82. Passed 6-7-82.)
234.10   APPLICATION FOR FIRE PROTECTION SERVICE.
   Any person, groups of persons, township trustees or other public bodies or
private partnerships or corporations owning or having an interest in real
estate outside the corporate limits and desiring fire protection services from
the City shall make an application therefor in writing to the Fire Chief.
   The application shall be accompanied by a plat, if required, showing the
location of the property as well as the location of all buildings thereon and
shall contain such other information as may be required by the Mayor and the
Fire Chief.
   Upon receipt of the application for services, the Mayor, with the advice of
the Fire Chief, shall determine whether it is feasible for the Fire Department
to render fire protection to the property of the applicant.
(Ord. 230-71. Passed 10-11-71.)
234.11   CONTRACT NEGOTIATION; REQUIREMENTS.
   The Mayor, with the approval of the Fire Chief, when satisfied that the
extension of fire service to any applicant under the provisions of this chapter
is advisable, may enter into a contract with the applicant, based upon the
payment of the fee prescribed by Section
234.13, whereby the City shall undertake to furnish such fire protection as
shall be determined by the Fire Chief to the property of the applicant.
   The contract shall in no event confer a right of action for damages on any
property owner or any other person, township trustees, groups of persons, firms
or corporations for the operation or failure to operate thereunder. The City
will not establish any fire houses or fixed equipment outside of the City
limits.
   The period of such contract shall not exceed three years.
(Ord. 230-71. Passed 10-11-71.)
234.12   CITY'S RIGHT TO FIRE PROTECTION.
   At no time, notwithstanding any of the provisions of this chapter or any
contract made hereunder, shall the City be required to furnish any fire
protection which cannot be reasonably spared from the fire-fighting force
necessary to protect the City; it shall be understood at all times that any
service required to be performed hereunder shall be secondary to the
requirements of the City and its residents. If, at the time of any call from
the township trustees or other property owners under contract for the
furnishing of services and equipment, the Fire Department is engaged in
answering fire calls within the City, the call from such township or property
owner under contract may be postponed until such equipment, apparatus and
personnel have completed a similar call or calls within the City.
(Ord. 230-71. Passed 10-11-71.)
234.13   FIRE PROTECTION SERVICE FEES.
   The fee for fire protection services extended to the unincorporated area of
a township and to persons, groups of persons, private partnerships or
corporations, except as otherwise provided, shall be as follows:
   (A)   In the case of a contract executed with the trustees of a township,
which will be for residential fires only, the fee shall be two thousand, five
hundred dollars ($2,500) per hour or any part thereof. Statements shall be
submitted by the City Treasurer to the Township Clerk, and the amount specified
therein shall be due and payable within thirty days of the submission thereof.
Until such payment is made to the City, when due, the City may withhold any
fire protection or other services authorized by such contract.
   (B)   In the case of a contract executed with persons, groups of persons,
private partnerships or corporations, exclusive of a contract with the trustees
of a township or a municipal corporation, the fee shall be a sum of money equal
to the product of the total property tax valuation of the applicant, consisting
of real estate and personal property, multiplied by .5 mill for a low risk
factor; for a medium risk factor, the fee shall be calculated at 1.0 mill; and
for a high risk factor, the fee shall be calculated at 1.5 mills. Risk factor
shall be as determined by the Ohio Basic Building Code. The computation shall
be made by the City Treasurer, and billing shall be made in the same manner as
provided in subsection (A) hereof. The fee shall be considered as being due and
payable semiannually in advance, and unless paid within thirty days from the
submission of the statement, the City shall be entitled to withhold or
terminate any fire protection service authorized by such contract. The Mayor
may require the initial semiannual payment to be made at the execution of the
contract and prior to the time such fire protection services are required to
begin. There will be a charge of two thousand, five hundred dollars ($2,500)
per hour, or any part thereof, for each fire protection response. The annual
base charge will be credited to the first response. A contract will not be
signed when the other party is so situated that it can annex to the City.
   (C)   Assistance of manpower and equipment, in addition to two engine
companies, one staff car or medic unit, one officer and five firefighters,
which shall be provided under the agreements provided for in subsections (A)
and (B) hereof, shall be charged as follows:
      (1)   For an engine company, $1,000 per hour or any part thereof;
      (2)   For a ladder company, $1,500 per hour or any part thereof; and
      (3)   For a medic unit, $500.00 per hour or any part thereof.
   (D)   In the event of a state of emergency or major life hazard, the Fire
Department will respond to an official request for assistance with all
available equipment and manpower, at no cost.
   (E)   Except for a state of emergency or major life hazard, if the Fire
Department requests assistance from another department, the responding
department will be compensated at the rates set forth in subsection (a) hereof.
(Ord. 84-88. Passed 7-11-88.)
234.14   EMERGENCY RESCUE SERVICE; FIRE HYDRANT INSPECTION.
   In addition to undertaking to provide fire protection service consisting of
personnel and equipment as authorized by the provisions of this chapter, the
Mayor, with the approval of the Fire Chief, may also include such other matters
as emergency rescue service and fire hydrant inspection.
   The Mayor and the Director of Law shall also be authorized to incorporate as
a provision of such contracts any additional stipulation deemed advisable to
protect the best interests of the City or incidental to the primary subject
matter of such contract.
(Ord. 230-71. Passed 10-11-71.)
234.15   RENEWAL OR ASSIGNMENT OF CONTRACTS.
   Renewal or assignment of contracts for fire protection service shall be made
as in the case of original applications. Applications for renewal shall be made
not less than sixty days before the expiration of the established contract.
Should any real estate protected under the provisions of this chapter be sold,
conveyed or transferred, it is permissible to assign the contract for fire
protection to the purchaser or transferee thereof, provided that such
assignment is first approved in writing by the Mayor, with the approval of the
Fire Chief.
(Ord. 230-71. Passed 10-11-71.)
234.16   SUPERVISION AT FIRES.
   The Fire Chief or his designated representatives shall have the sole
supervision of the City fire-fighters and fire equipment, as well as of the
amount of such equipment, to be furnished at a fire upon the premises of any
contracting party, except as may be otherwise provided in the contract.
(Ord. 230-71. Passed 10-11-71.)
234.17   PRIVATE AUXILIARY FIRE ALARM SYSTEMS.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section
234.17 was repealed by Ordinance 86-14, passed March 24, 2014.)
234.18   ARSON BUREAU; ESTABLISHMENT AND DUTIES.
   There is hereby established within the Fire Department an Arson Bureau,
which shall be operated under the supervision of the Fire Chief.  It shall be
the duty and responsibility of the Arson Bureau to enforce and investigate
violations of laws or ordinances relating to the crime of arson or in which
fires, false fire alarms, explosions, stink bombs, smoke bombs, fire safety
devices, disruption of fire communications and interference with fire- fighters
or rescue crews in the performance of their official duties is involved.
234.181   ARSON INVESTIGATORS; POLICE POWERS.
   (a)   An employee appointed as an Arson Investigator in the Fire Department
shall have the duty to conserve the peace and enforce all laws within the City
and shall have the authority to arrest violators of the ordinances of the City
and the laws of the State, within the City, and to serve summonses, warrants
and all other legal writs and processes.  The appropriate peace officer's
training, as determined by the Ohio Peace Officer's Training Council, shall be
required for this position.
   (b)   The Arson Investigator is permitted to carry a firearm while acting in
the capacity of an arson investigator.  In order to carry a firearm, as
referenced herein, the arson investigators shall meet annual qualification
requirements described in Ohio Revised Code 109.801 and shall complete, at a
minimum, training in the use of firearms, arrest techniques, and use of force. 
   (c)   It shall be within the power and sole discretion of the Fire Chief to
provide for any additional qualifications or requirements for an Arson
Investigator to carry a firearm, and  to suspend or revoke an Arson
Investigator’s ability to carry a firearm while on duty with the Lima Fire
Department. 
   (d)   The Arson Investigator is hereby also authorized to prevent noise and
disturbance and indecent and disorderly conduct, preserve the peace and good
order and protect the property of the City beyond the geographic limits of the
City on property owned by the City, pursuant to Ohio R.C. 715.49 and 715.50.
(Ord. 14-93.  Passed 1-25-93; Ord. 278-12. Passed 12-17-12.)
234.19   FEES FOR HELICOPTER STANDBY SERVICE.
   (A)   When the Lima Fire Department is requested by an agency, person or
corporation to standby in the event of a helicopter take-off or landing, to
protect against an emergency, which would require the services of the Lima Fire
Department, the following fees shall be charged:
      (1)   A five hundred dollar ($500.00) per hour fee per engine company,
ladder company, or rescue unit required;
      (2)   A minimum charge of five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each call-
out for said engine company, ladder company, or rescue unit;
      (3)   For each quarter hour, or portion thereof, required in excess of
the initial one-hour period, there shall be a charge of fifty dollars ($50.00)
per quarter hour.
   (B)   The Lima Fire Department will not standby during the period between
the landing and the take-off of a particular helicopter.
   (C)   A landing and then subsequent take-off of a particular helicopter
within a 24-hour time period shall be considered a part of the same call-out,
and the same minimum fee for one call-out shall apply, and the time involved
shall be the total time added together which includes the time spent on the
scene upon the landing plus the time spent on the scene upon take-off.
   (D)   All non-profit corporations, as defined by the regulations of the
Internal Revenue Service, shall receive a 50% reduction in the fee charged for
the services described in division (A) of this section.
(Ord. 4-91.  Passed 1-7-91.)
234.20   FIRE SAFETY INSPECTORS; POLICE POWERS.
   The employees appointed as Fire Safety Inspectors in the Fire Department
shall have the duty to conserve the peace and enforce all laws within the City
and shall have the authority to arrest violators of the ordinances of the City
and the laws of the State, within the City, and to serve summonses, warrants
and all other legal writs and processes.  The individuals in this position are
not authorized to carry weapons involving their duties prescribed herein.
(Ord. 25-93.  Passed 2-8-93.)
234.21   FIRE REPORT FEE.
   Upon proper application to the Fire Department, an agency, person or
corporation requesting a report concerning a fire shall be charged a fee of
three dollars ($3.00) per report, effective July 1, 1993.
(Ord. 40-93.  Passed 3-8-93.)
234.22   COST RECOVERY POLICY.
   (A)   The Mayor is hereby authorized to adopt a Cost Recovery Policy for the
Lima Fire Department to obtain reimbursement for funds expended in the clean-up
of hazardous materials incidents, upon the terms and conditions he or she deems
appropriate.
   (B)   The Auditor of the City is authorized and directed to receive all such
funds and deposit and record them in the appropriate account, and to issue his
or her warrant or warrants against the appropriate account in payment of the
obligation herein authorized upon presentation of the proper voucher or
vouchers therefor.
(Ord. 90-00.  Passed 5-8-00.)
234.23   FEES FOR RESPONSE TO MOTOR VEHICLE ACCIDENTS.
   The Fire Department is hereby authorized to charge a service fee for
responding to motor vehicle accidents.  The Fire Chief shall establish a policy
outlining the various levels of service provided for motor vehicle responses
and setting forth the fee for each such level of service, which must be
approved by the Mayor.
(Ord. 151-02.  Passed 11-4-02.)
234.24   EMERGENCY MEDICAL TRANSPORTATION SERVICES.
   To complement existing fire protection and emergency rescue services, the
Fire Department is authorized to provide complete emergency medical
transportation services within the City, including the transportation of
patients from an original call-for-service location to a hospital or urgent
medical care facility located within the City.  The Fire Department is
authorized to charge a fee for such services as authorized by the Mayor. 
(Ord. 310-09. Passed 12-21-09.)

236.01   ESTABLISHMENT AND COMPOSITION.
   A Department of Utilities is hereby established in and for the City. The
Department shall be composed of the following divisions: Administration, Water
Supply and Sewage Pumping, Water Pumping, Water Distribution, Water Treatment,
Sewage Treatment and Sewer.
(Ord. 56-72. Passed 3-27-72.)
236.02   DIRECTOR OF UTILITIES.
   The Director of Utilities shall be the head of the Department of Utilities
and shall have complete supervision and control of all divisions within the
Department. Whenever the title "General Superintendent of the Department of
Water and Sewage Treatment" appears in these Codified Ordinances, as the same
may be amended, such title shall refer to the Director of Utilities. 
(Ord. 102-53. Passed 7-13-53.)
236.03   UNIFORM ALLOWANCE.
   (A)   Establishment. A uniform allowance, payable from the Water
Distribution Expense in the manner specified in subsection (C) hereof, is
hereby established for the following employees in the Division of Water
Distribution of the Department of Utilities:
      (1)   Meter readers;
      (2)   Consumers servicemen; and
      (3)   Meter reader foremen.
   (B)   Records; Rules and Regulations. An account of the disbursements for
such purpose shall be maintained by the City Auditor. The Mayor is authorized
to establish rules and regulations governing the use, type and purchase of the
uniforms in accordance with the provisions of this section. The uniforms so
purchased shall at all times remain the property of the City and shall be
returned upon separation from the service of such employees for any reason.
   (C)   Amount of Allowance; Use. An initial uniform allowance of ninety
dollars ($90.00) shall be credited to each employee listed in subsection (a)
hereof, except that no new employee shall receive such credit until successful
completion of a three-month probationary period. After the expiration of one
year from receipt of the initial uniform allowance, each employee shall be
credited with an annual uniform allowance of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) for
the cost of replacement of items when needed. The allowance, or any portion
thereof, shall be disbursed after purchase of authorized uniform items. Each
employee shall maintain his own uniform.
   (D)   Utilities Security Officer. The Utilities Security Officer, during
such time as he or she is required to wear an official uniform, shall receive
an allowance not exceeding three hundred dollars ($300.00) in any calendar
year. Such sum shall be cumulative. If such sum is not fully used in one
calendar year, the balance shall be credited to such member for use in
subsequent years. No new employee shall receive such credit until successful
completion of a three-month probationary period.
   Subsection (B) hereof shall apply to the uniform allowance for the Utilities
Security Officer, except that one-half of the expense shall be paid out of the
Water Works Administration Account and one-half out of the Sewage Disposal
Administration Account.
(Ord. 62-86. Passed 5-5-86.)
236.04   UTILITIES SECURITY OFFICER; POLICE POWERS.
   (A)   The employee appointed as Utilities Security Officer in the Utilities
Department shall have the duty to conserve the peace and enforce all laws
within the City and shall have the authority to arrest violators of the
ordinances of the City and the laws of the State, within the City, and to serve
summonses, warrants and all other legal writs and processes. The appropriate
peace officer's training, as determined by the Ohio Peace Officer's Training
Council, shall be required for this position.
   (B)   The Utilities Securing Officer is hereby also authorized to prevent
noise and disturbance and indecent and disorderly conduct, preserve the peace
and good order and protect the property of the City beyond the geographical
limits of the City on property owned by the City, pursuant to Ohio R.C. 715.49
and 715.50.
(Ord. 9-93.  Passed 1-25-93.)

   EDITOR'S NOTE: The City enters into Agreements from time to time with the

Association of Fire Fighters, Local 334, AFL-CIO, and the American Federation
of State, County and Municipal Employees, Ohio Council 8, Local 1002, AFL-CIO,

and regular part-time employees of the City (listed in Appendix A of the AFSCME
Agreement), conditions and incidents of employment, benefits and the like. In

Clerk of Council.
