244.01   UNCLASSIFIED EMPLOYEES; PHYSICAL EXAMINATIONS.
   Whenever it appears to the responsible appointing authority to be in the
best interest of the City, such appointing authority may require a prospective
appointee or the holder of an appointive position in the unclassified service
of the City to undergo a physical examination, the result of which shall be
certified to the responsible appointing authority by the examining physician.
(Ord. 79-63. Passed 4-29-63.)
244.02   APPLICATION OF COLLECTIVE BARGAINING AGREEMENTS; PARITY ORDINANCE
   (A)   The provisions in this Chapter shall apply to employees who:
      (1)   are not covered by a collective bargaining agreement, or
      (2)   are not AFSCME Parity Employees as defined in C.O.L. Section
244.25, or
      (3)   are not granted specific employment benefits by separate
ordinance. 
   (B)   Employees who are members of a collective bargaining unit shall
receive employment benefits as set forth in those agreements.  The provisions
of those agreements shall apply to those employees and shall supercede any
conflicting provisions in this Chapter.  If a collective bargaining agreement
is silent on a provision contained in this Chapter, then the provision of this
Chapter shall apply for the issue not addressed in the collective bargaining
agreement.
   (C)   Employees who are AFSCME Parity Employees as defined in C.O.L. section
244.25 shall receive employment benefits as set forth in C.O.L. 244.25.  The
applicable provisions of the applicable AFSCME collective bargaining agreement
shall apply to those employees as set forth in C.O.L. 244.25, and shall
supercede any conflicting provisions in this Chapter. If the AFSCME  collective
bargaining agreement applicable in C.O.L. 244.25 is silent on a provision
contained in this Chapter, then the provision of this Chapter shall apply for
the issue not addressed in the AFSCME collective bargaining agreement.
(Ord. 48-85. Passed 3-11-85, Ord. 142-14. Passed 6-9-14.)
244.03   SICK LEAVE; RETIRE/REHIRE EMPLOYEES.
   (A)   Employees shall be entitled to sick leave and vacation leave benefits,
including payment for accumulated sick leave and vacation leave, in accordance
with any applicable collective bargaining provision or other Ordinance or
provision of this Chapter.
   (B)   Any employee who has retired or resigned from City employment and who
has subsequently been rehired (a retire/rehire employee), shall not be entitled
to carry forward any unused sick leave balance or vacation leave balance which
accumulated during the prior employment period.
      (1)   Any such retire/rehire employee shall not be entitled to any
payment or payout for sick leave or vacation leave which accumulated during the
time of the rehired employment.
      (2)   The first paragraph of this subsection (B) shall not apply to
retire/rehire employees who were rehired prior to the date of passage of
Ordinance 143-14 (June 9, 2014); however, subsection (B)(1) above which
prevents a second sick leave and vacation leave payout shall be applicable to
such employees.
   (C)   The provisions of this section shall supercede any conflicting
provisions regarding sick leave that may be contained in any other section of
this Chapter which was enacted prior to the date of passage of Ordinance 143-14
(June 9, 2014).
(Ord. 99-83, Passed 5-23-83; Ord. 143-14, Passed 6-9-14; Ord. 154-14, Passed 6-
23-14.)
244.031   MATERNITY LEAVE.
   Female employees shall be granted maternity leave beginning no earlier than
two months prior to the anticipated delivery date. At the option of the
employee, filed in writing with her appointing authority, sick leave, vacation
time or a leave without pay, or any combination thereof, may be taken. If the
employee elects to utilize sick leave and/or vacation time, the remaining time
of any leave shall be taken without pay. Maternity leave shall terminate two
months after birth, unless the employee's physician certifies in writing that a
longer recovery period is necessary, in which case the leave may be extended
not to exceed an additional two months. Any employee who receives maternity
leave shall be returned to the position occupied by her prior to the leave, and
shall not be treated as a new employee.
(Ord. 211-76. Passed 12-20-76.)
244.032   INJURY LEAVE.
   (A)   Any employee of the City who is injured while working within the scope
of his employment, and who is temporarily totally disabled by such injury,
shall receive his usual and normal salary and compensation during such period,
provided such employee turns over to the Auditor all temporary total disability
payments received by him from the Bureau of Worker's Compensation. Injury leave
provided herein shall not  exceed twelve months from the date of injury, and
shall terminate sooner in the event Worker's Compensation payments for
temporary total disability are sooner terminated. An employee who exhausts his
total injury leave shall be eligible for an additional three months leave,
providing his physician certifies in writing that he will be able to return to
work within this additional time period and return at 100 percent (100%)
capability to perform his required job duties,
   (B)   The employee shall be eligible to apply for and qualify for Worker's
Compensation for the above temporary disability benefits. Sick leave used
during the period of application shall be reinstated upon approval of Worker's
Compensation payments.
(Ord. 79-83. Passed 5-23-83.)
244.04   LEGAL HOLIDAYS.
   (A)   The legal holidays observed by the City shall be as follows: New
Year's Day, Martin Luther King Day, President's Day, Good Friday, Memorial Day,
Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day, the Friday following
Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day, one-half day Christmas Eve, one-half day New
Year's Eve and the employee's birthday.
   (B)   When any holiday enumerated in subsection (A) hereof falls on Sunday,
the following day shall be a holiday for City employees. In such instances, the
one-half day holidays before Christmas and New Year's Days shall be taken on
the Fridays preceding Christmas and New Year's Day.
   (C)   When any holiday enumerated in subsection (A) hereof falls on
Saturday, the preceding day shall be a holiday for City employees.
   (D)   In those years in which Christmas Day and New Year's Day fall on
Saturdays, the one-half day New Year's Eve, as set forth in subsection (A)
hereof, shall not be a holiday, but instead the entire day on the Thursday
immediately preceding Christmas Day shall be a legal holiday.
   (E)   When an employee is required to work on a holiday established by this
section, he shall be paid at one and one-half times his regular rate of pay for
that day and shall also receive an additional work lay off with pay, such day
to be determined by his department head.
   (F)   An employee's birthday holiday may be used as a personal leave day on
a different date, with the approval of the department head, provided that the
employee gives notice of his intention to utilize the leave day privilege ten
working days in advance of his birthday.
   (G)   It is the intent of this section to excuse from working, whenever
possible, employees who are scheduled to work on days observed as holidays, as
specified herein.
(Ord. 200-76. Passed 12-13-76.)
   (H)   Holidays for members and employees of the Police Department, Fire
Department personnel under the platoon system, irregular shift employees in the
Public Works Department and personnel of the Water and Sewage Treatment Plants
shall be governed by Section
244.05. Holidays for employees of the Municipal Court, and employees in other
departments or offices assigned to work with the Municipal Court, shall be
governed by statute, or rule of Court.
(Ord. 7-77. Passed 1-3-77.)
244.05   HOLIDAYS LEAVES FOR POLICE DEPARTMENT MEMBERS, FIRE DEPARTMENT MEMBERS
UNDER THE PLATOON SYSTEM, WATER AND SEWAGE TREATMENT PLANT EMPLOYEES AND
CERTAIN EMPLOYEES IN THE PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT.
   (A)   Members of the Police Department, Certain Members of the Utilities and
Public Works Department.
      (1)   Each employee of the Police Department, each employee of the Sewage
and Water Treatment Plants of the City and employees in the Department of
Public Works assigned to irregular shifts shall be granted one day holiday
leave or part thereof in lieu of working on each of the following legal
holidays or part thereof: New Year's Day, Martin Luther King Day, President's
Day, Good Friday, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day,
the Friday following Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day and the employee's
birthday. Such employees shall be granted one-half day holiday leave or part
thereof in lieu of working on each of the following half-day legal holidays or
part thereof: one-half day Christmas Eve and one-half day New Year's Eve. The
department heads shall have authority to designate the day or part thereof
which may be taken by their employees in lieu of holidays. Such days may be
granted separately or consecutively, regardless of whether the specific holiday
has passed in a particular year.
      (2)   An employee shall be compensated at one and one-half his hourly
rate of pay in the following instances:
         (a)   If an employee is required to work on Independence Day, Labor
Day, Thanksgiving Day and/or Christmas Day, or part thereof; or
         (b)   If an employee is unable to take his holiday leaves other than
Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day during any
calendar year because of the personnel requirements of the department to which
he is assigned, payment for which shall be made on the first payday after the
end of the calendar year.
      (3)   An employee's birthday holiday may be used as a personal leave day
on a different date, with the approval of the department head, provided the
employee gives notice of his intention to utilize the leave day privilege ten
working days in advance of his birthday.
      (4)   For purposes of this section, an employee's first four days of
holiday leave in any calendar year shall be in lieu of the days set forth in
subsection (a)(2)A. hereof.
   (B)   Members of the Fire Department.
      (1)   All members of the Fire Department working twenty-four hour tours
of duty shall be entitled to eight tours of duty off with pay in lieu of the
holidays celebrated by other City employees. Members of the Fire Department
normally assigned a forty hour work week shall celebrate holidays in accordance
with the provisions of this section covering other similarly situated City
employees. Members of the Fire Department required to work on Independence Day,
Labor Day, Thanksgiving and/or Christmas Day shall be paid time and one-half
their normal rate of pay.
      (2)   Members of the Fire Department receiving eight tours of duty off
with pay in lieu of set holidays, shall be able to utilize up to three of such
tours as priority personal days. Such priority personal days may be taken upon
the request of the employee, providing that the request is made at least forty-
eight hours in advance of the beginning of the tour to be taken off and that no
more than two other employees are taking the same tour off by exercising their
right to a priority personal day.
      (3)   The remaining five tours shall be taken as holiday tours off with
the Chief of the Fire Department assigning the days to be taken if the member
of the Fire Department fails to utilize such time. All holiday time shall be
approved in advance by the Chief of the Fire Department.
      (4)   In the event a member of the Fire Department is unable to take his
holiday time off during the calendar year in which it is earned due to the
City's refusal to let the member take the time off throughout the year, such
member shall be paid for such unused compensatory time at his regular hourly
rate of pay in the first pay period in January.
(Ord. 138-83.  Passed 7-25-83.)
244.06   LEAVES OF ABSENCE FOR MILITARY SERVICE; COMPENSATION AND HEALTH CARE
BENEFITS.
   (A)   Compensation.
      (1)   Each City officer and employee who is a member of the Ohio National
Guard, the Ohio State Guard, the Ohio Naval Militia or any other reserve
component of the Armed Forces of the United States shall be entitled to leaves
of absence from employment  duties for the time such person is in military
service, on field training, or on active duty, for periods not exceeding thirty
days in any calendar year.
      (2)   Any City officer or employee on military leave of absence shall be
entitled to receive pay in accordance with any applicable collective bargaining
agreement, state or federal law.
      (3)   An officer or employee returning from extended military leave,
which shall be defined herein as being greater than 30 calendar days, will
receive applicable pay step time credit for the period the person was on
extended military leave.  The City’s share of pension contribution for an
officer or employee on extended military leave will be made in accordance with
USERRA and relevant state law.
      (4)   An officer or employee returning from extended military leave who
has not been promoted because of being on active military service will receive
promotion upon return in accordance with USERRA, the City Charter, a relevant
collective bargaining agreement, and City ordinance.  Classified civil service
employees must appear on an eligibility list at the time of promotion
opportunity to be eligible for promotion upon return.  Being on an eligibility
list does not guarantee promotion, the person returning from extended military
leave will only be eligible for promotion if the sole reason the person was not
promoted was due to the absence for active military service.       
   (B)   Group Health Care Benefits. For officers or  employees on extended
military leave, health care benefits will terminate on the last day of the
month in which the officer or employee last receives pay from the City of
Lima.  As defined by Federal Law, while on extended military leave, an officer
or employee and their family members will have access to health care without
cost through the military’s health care delivery system.  However, officers or
employees eligible for extended military leave will also have options available
for a 24 month period for providing health care benefit coverage for their
qualified dependents during the period of extended military leave as follows:
      (1)   Continue their health coverage at 102 percent of the full premium
rate in accordance with Federal Law.   
      (2)   Continue their health coverage at the normal full-time employee
contribution rate payable by the first of the month that the coverage will be
provided.  Coverage will be as defined in the City’s health plan document. 
      (3)   Discontinue health care benefit coverage and receive mileage
reimbursement for travel to out-of-county Tri-Care Prime providers for health
care services that are covered under the City’s health plan.  The rate of
reimbursement will be the standard mileage rate as determined by the Auditor’s
office.  The Human Resource Department will be responsible for verifying that a
trip qualifies for reimbursement.  Requests for reimbursement must include
proof of a visit to an out-of-county Tri-Care Prime provider and must be
submitted within 60 days of the visit.
(Ord. 194-06. Passed 8-7-06.)
244.07   FUNERAL LEAVE.
   (A)   Each employee shall be entitled to a funeral leave of not to exceed
three work days, in the event of the death of such employee's father, mother,
spouse, child, brother, sister, grandfather, grandmother, grandchild, spouse's
mother, spouse's father or a person standing in place of the employee's
parents. Such funeral leave shall be utilized within seven days of the funeral.
   (B)   For purposes of this section, three work days shall be considered as
one twenty-four hour day for Fire Department employees on the platoon system,
as provided in Section
234.06. Notwithstanding subsection (A) hereof, an employee on the platoon
system shall also be entitled to funeral leave for the balance of any work day
on which death occurs.
   (C)   Upon the request of an employee, a department head shall permit the
employee to attend the funeral of a fellow City employee, provided that
overtime is not caused thereby and the operation of the department is not
impaired.
(Ord. 41-80. Passed 3-31-80.)
244.08   VACATIONS.
   (A)   This section shall apply to employees not covered by a collective
bargaining agreement.
   (B)   Each employee having more than one year's service with the City shall
be entitled to vacation leave each calendar year, together with his regular
pay, as follows:
      (1)   One work week vacation to all employees who have worked one year
but less than two years;
      (2)   Two work weeks vacation to all employees who have worked two years
but less than eight years;
      (3)   Three work weeks vacation to all employees who have worked eight
years but less than fifteen years;
      (4)   Four work weeks vacation to all employees who have worked fifteen
years but less than twenty-five years;
      (5)   Five work weeks vacation to all employees who have worked twenty-
five years or more.
   (C)   In addition, each employee who has accumulated more than ninety days
sick leave shall receive one additional day of vacation for each three days of
unused sick leave accumulated during the preceding year in excess of ninety
days, but not in excess of 105 days, or at the option of the employee, he shall
be paid his normal rate of pay for such time. Such vacation time or payment in
lieu thereof shall be charged against the employee's accumulated sick leave.
Employees shall also have the option to take none of the above and accrue the
time as sick leave.
   (D)   Each classified employee who has been previously employed by the City
with an interruption in his term of service not exceeding five years for
whatever reason, shall be entitled to a credit for such prior service for
purposes of computing vacation time and accumulated sick leave only.
   (E)   Prior service shall mean service within the classified service of the
City, irrespective of whether such service was within a safety division, under
the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act (CETA), or as a result of any
other program. Prior service shall not mean service within the unclassified
service as an elected official or as part-time, temporary or seasonal employee
of the City. Subsections (c) and (e) hereof shall not apply to retired
employees who are rehired by the City.
   (F)   Vacations shall be taken at such times as are authorized by the
employee's department head. If an employee is unable to receive his vacation
due to work requirements, he may accumulate and carry over unused vacation time
for a period not to exceed three years, or, upon authorization of the
appointing authority, shall be paid for unused time at his normal rate of pay.
Effective January 1, 1986, the above three years shall be reduced to one year,
except for the Police Chief, the Fire Chief, Police Inspectors and Assistant
Fire Chiefs.
   (G)   Vacation may be taken within the year in which an anniversary falls
for additional vacation. If an employee should terminate City employment before
the anniversary date upon which vacation is accumulated, any unaccumulated
vacation time will be deducted from his final paycheck.
   (H)   Divisional seniority, within classification, will be used for the
purpose of vacation scheduling. This will allow the employee with the most
seniority a preference in the time of year he will use his vacation time.
Vacation requests must be submitted prior to April 15. This schedule must be
approved by the employee's department head. No employee will have a choice of
more than two weeks vacation unless he uses all of his vacation consecutively.
After all requests have been scheduled, further requests will be processed, as
above, until April 30. All remaining vacation time will be assigned by the
department head.
(Ord. 49-85. Passed 4-8-85.)
244.09   PAYMENT OF ACCUMULATED VACATION TIME.
   In the event of the retirement of any City employee, payment for accrued,
but unused, vacation time shall be made to the employee In a lump sum.
   In the event of the death of an employee, such payment shall be made to the
estate of the decedent or, in the event there is no estate, to any person
authorized to receive such payment by a court having jurisdiction of the
matter. However, no payment shall be made until a certified copy of letters of
appointment or release from administration is presented to the City Auditor.
(Ord. 54-74. Passed 2-25-74.)
244.10   MILEAGE ALLOWANCE.
   Each officer or employee of the City, including the Bailiff of the Municipal
Court, who is required to use his or her private automobile on official City
business, shall, when authorized by his or her department head, be paid the sum
per mile for such use, as calculated by deducting two cents (2¢) from the rate
allowed by the Internal Revenue Service as of the first day of January of the
year in which the automobile is used.
   The mileage allowance provided herein shall be payable monthly in the manner
prescribed by the City Auditor, upon vouchers approved by the Mayor, except
that vouchers of employees of the Municipal Court may be approved by a Judge of
that Court.
(Ord. 41-90.  Passed 3-12-90.)
244.11   REIMBURSEMENT OF EXPENDITURES.
   The City Auditor is hereby authorized to issue his or her warrant, upon
receipt of a proper voucher therefor, to reimburse the Mayor, the City Auditor,
the Director of Law, the President of Council, the Director of Administrative
Coordination, the members of Council, the Director of Public Works, the
Director of Utilities, the Finance Director, the Director of Community
Development, the Deputy Director I of Public Works, the Deputy Director II of
Public Works, the Chief of Police, the Fire Chief, the Deputy Director of
Utilities and the Human Resources Director, for expenditures of their personal
funds.  Such warrant shall be in an amount not exceeding one hundred dollars
($100.00) per day on each occasion for work which is for the sole benefit of
the City.  Each expenditure by Council members shall be approved by the
President of Council, all other expenditures shall be approved by the Mayor,
and all expenditures herein shall be subject to the same procedures that govern
all City expenditures.  Reimbursement of expenditures in excess of one hundred
dollars ($100.00) per day may be made, subject to the approvals and procedures
described above, if such reimbursement is also authorized by a duly adopted
motion of Council.
   The expenditures to be reimbursed are limited to the purchase of hospitality
items for individuals and groups (e.g. the purchase of coffee, pastries, meals
or refreshments); for recognition items for employees, citizens or visitors
(e.g. service awards, token retirement gifts, flowers, trophies or plaques);
for convening, attending and conducting meetings (e.g. rental costs for
facilities or equipment, material costs, fees for trainers or speakers); for
attending dinners or events; or for obtaining such other amenities or services
as the Mayor and/or President of Council determines to be necessary and proper
to perform a function or to exercise a power specially conferred by Charter or
by statute or implied therefrom.
(Ord. 27-93.  Passed 2-22-93.)
244.111   MAYOR'S EXPENSE ALLOWANCE.
   The Mayor, within the limits of public funds appropriated by Council, is
hereby authorized to expend such public funds for the purchase of hospitality
for individuals and groups (e.g. the purchase of coffee and pastries, meals or
refreshments), for recognition for employees, citizens or visitors (e.g. 
service awards, token retirement gifts, flowers, trophies or plaques), for
convening, attending and conducting meetings (e.g. rental costs for facilities
or equipment, material costs, fees for trainers or speakers), for attending
dinners or events, or for obtaining such other amenities or services as the
Mayor determines to be necessary and proper to perform a function or to
exercise a power specially conferred upon the Mayor by Charter or by statute or
implied therefrom.  This section shall supersede any provisions of Section
244.11 in conflict herewith.
(Ord. 128-92.  Passed 9-28-92.)
244.12   WORK UNIFORMS.
   (A)   The Mayor is hereby authorized to issue work uniforms to employees
performing manual labor in the Departments of Public Works and Utilities and to
the meter repairmen employed in the Police Department.
   (B)   The work uniforms shall consist of five work shirts, five pairs of
work pants and five coveralls for each employee. Work uniforms shall be
maintained by the employee and shall at all times remain the property of the
City.
   (C)   The Mayor is hereby authorized to establish suitable regulations
governing the use of such work uniforms.
   (D)   This section shall not apply to those employees of the Department of
Utilities already covered by the provisions of Section
236.03.
(Ord. 302-74. Passed 12-23-74.)
244.13   CLOTHING ALLOWANCE. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section
244.13 was repealed by Ordinance 203-77, passed December 5, 1977.)
244.14   GROUP HEALTH INSURANCE.
   (A)   Effective the first day of the first month after the completion of 30
days of employment, the City shall pay the entire premium of a family
prescription drug insurance plan providing a two dollar ($2.00) deductible
amount for each prescription, and also of hospitalization and surgical group
insurance, for all employees and their immediate families, including those
employees over the age of 65 years. The  policy shall provide that employees
over the age of 65 years shall have the same benefits as younger employees,
except for those costs and expenses covered by Medicare.  The policy shall also
provide full coverage for hospital and emergency room treatment and shall
further provide for payment of the usual, customary and reasonable charges for
doctor's services in childbirth for those employees who have a family policy.
   (B)   For employees who become eligible for Medicare before January 1, 1984,
effective the first day of the first month after the completion of thirty days
of employment, the City shall reimburse each employee over the age of sixty-
five years for premiums paid by him or her for Medicare coverage for himself or
herself and his or her spouse, unless such payments are made by another pension
or retirement fund.
   (C)   This section shall not apply to elected officials, members of boards
and commissions, provisional employees, temporary or seasonal employees who do
not work 12 months per year and students who are employed on a part- time
basis.
   (D)   The City shall pay only the premium for one policy of insurance if
both a husband and wife are employees of the City. An appointing authority
shall have full power to determine to which employee such policy shall be
issued.
(Ord. 38-84. Passed 4-9-84.)
244.141   GROUP DENTAL INSURANCE.
   The City shall provide a group dental insurance plan for the benefit of all
employees of the City, participation in which shall be voluntary and at the
sole expense of the employee. The Auditor shall establish a payroll deduction
system for payment of the premium by the employee.
(Ord. 209-76. Passed 12-20-76.)
244.142   CONFIDENTIALITY OF HEALTH RECORDS.
   (A)   Any information concerning an employee gained as a result of any
record required or used in administering the City Employee Health Insurance
Plan or Dental Insurance Plan shall be confidential. Information shall only be
disclosed upon consent of the employee, judicial order or in administering the
Plan.
   (B)   Any person disclosing information in violation of division (a) of this
section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree.
(Ord. 135-83. Passed 7-11-83.)
244.143   HEALTH INSURANCE FOR LIMA MUNICIPAL JUDGES AND CLERK OF LIMA
MUNICIPAL COURT.
   (A)   The City shall pay sixty percent of the entire premium of group
hospitalization, surgical and prescription drug insurance for the Lima
Municipal Court Judges and the Lima Municipal Clerk of Court and their
immediate families.  The City shall continue to pay sixty percent of the entire
premium regardless of any increase in such premium.
   (B)   The premium for the Lima Municipal Clerk of Court shall not be paid
until the term beginning January 1, 1992.
(Ord. 193-91.  Passed 8-5-91.)
244.144   EMPLOYEE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM.
   (A)   There is hereby established an Employee Assistance Program to provide
personal assessment and counseling professional services to eligible employees
and their families or dependents.
   (B)   The following shall be eligible to participate in the Employee
Assistance Program:
      (1)   Employees who work full-time for the City;
      (2)   Employees who are otherwise eligible for medical coverage as an
employee benefit;
      (3)   Elected officials;
      (4)   Family members or dependents of any of the above.
   (C)   The Employee Assistance Program shall be coordinated by the Director
of Human Resources or such other person as the Mayor may determine, in
accordance with the terms of any contract with an independent health care
professional as approved by Council.
(Ord. 142-99.  Passed 8-9-99.)
244.15   GROUP LIFE INSURANCE.
   (A)   Effective the first day of the first month after the completion of
thirty days of employment, the City shall pay the entire premium of a five
thousand dollar ($5,000) group life insurance policy for each employee.
   (B)   This section shall not apply to elected officials, members of boards
and commissions, provisional employees, temporary or seasonal employees who do
not work 12 months per year, and students who are employed on a part- time
basis.
(Ord. 80-83. Passed 5-9-83.)
244.16   DEATH OF EMPLOYEE.
   In the event of the death of any person while an employee of the City,
whether or not in the course of his employment, the position held by such
employee shall become vacant at the time of death.
(Ord. 52-74. Passed 2-25-74.)
244.17   HOURS OF WORK IN CERTAIN DEPARTMENTS.
   (A)   Eight hours per day and 40 hours per week, performed on Monday through
Friday, shall constitute a week's work for all employees of the City, except
employees of the Fire Department under the platoon system, the Police
Department, part-time and seasonal employees and employees on regularly
scheduled trick operations. Forty hours per week shall constitute a week's work
for members of the Police Department, part-time and seasonal employees and
employees on regularly scheduled trick operations, except for members of the
Fire Department under the platoon system.
   (B)   When, in the opinion of an appointing authority, it is necessary to
change the work days of an employee in order to provide services to residents
of the City, the appointing authority may assign an employee to work days other
than Monday through Friday, either on a temporary or permanent basis.
(Ord. 102-83. Passed 5-23-83.)
244.18   OVERTIME GENERALLY.
   (A)   It is the policy of the City that overtime work shall be discouraged.
If a department head believes that work in excess of the established work week
is required, he shall obtain the approval of the Mayor prior to authorizing
such overtime for any employee.
   (B)   When overtime is authorized by the Mayor, time in excess of 40 hours
per week or eight hours per day shall be paid at one and one-half times the
employee's regular rate of pay. At the option of the employee, compensatory
time-off may be taken by the employee in lieu of overtime pay, but shall be
scheduled with the approval of the employee's department head. Compensatory
time shall be computed at one and one-half times the hours worked, but shall
not be accumulated in excess of 40 hours; provided, however, that sworn
officers of the Police Department may accrue compensatory time to a maximum of
60 hours. Any overtime which would cause total compensatory time to exceed the
applicable limit shall be paid to the employee. Compensatory time shall not
accrue for work on holidays as set forth in Section
244.05.
   (C)   Members of the Fire Department whose established work week exceeds 40
hours, or whose established work day exceeds eight hours, shall be paid
overtime rates, or granted compensatory time, only in the event that work is
performed in excess of the established work day or week.
(Ord. 78-83. Passed 5-23-83.)
244.19   EMERGENCY OVERTIME PAYMENTS.
   (A)   Any employee who is recalled to work after leaving work or on a day
when he is not scheduled to work shall receive a minimum of four hours pay at
his regular hourly rate, or one and one-half times his regular hourly rate for
the time worked, whichever is greater, providing that the time worked or paid
for does not abut the employee's workday. This provision shall apply only once
in any four hour period.
   (B)   Notwithstanding subsection (A) hereof, in the Sewer Maintenance
Division on all emergency call-outs, a Mechanic or C&M II and one C&M I shall
be called out to investigate the complaint. They shall receive four hours pay
for such call-out. If the complaint requires the callout of a crew, subsection
(A) hereof shall then apply.
   (C)   Notwithstanding subsection (A) hereof, in the Water Supply and
Treatment Division, if it becomes necessary to restart a raw water pump station
at other than regular duty hours an employee shall be guaranteed four hours pay
for each callout. Multiple call-outs within a four hour period shall be
considered as a single callout. If the employee called determines that the
problem is more serious than a "restart" after reporting to the site, he shall
advise the Supervisor who may call out a crew, in which case subsection (A)
hereof shall then apply.
   (D)   This section shall not apply to employees covered by Section
244.20.
(Ord. 86-83. Passed 5-23-83.)
244.191   OVERTIME PAYMENT FOR ATTENDANCE AT CITY COUNCIL MEETINGS.
   (A)   No classified employee shall be paid for attendance at City Council
meetings or Council committee meetings unless directed to attend by the Mayor,
Council, Director of Law or Auditor. If the employee is directed to attend by
the Mayor, Council, Director of Law, or Auditor, then he shall be paid time and
one-half his rate of pay for the time spent at the meeting.
   (B)   Notwithstanding subsection (A) hereof, department heads shall not be
paid for attendance at City Council meetings or Council committee meetings.
(Ord. 63-84. Passed 6-4-84.)
244.20   OVERTIME IN THE POLICE DEPARTMENT.
   (A)   Any on-duty police officer who is called to work at any time other
than his regular hours of employment for the purpose of testifying in criminal
or civil proceedings in Allen County, Ohio to which he is not a party, due to
his position as a police officer of the City, shall, when such court duty does
not extend into or become an extension of his regular hours of employment, be
paid in accordance with the following:
      The officer shall receive a minimum of four hours pay at his regular
hourly rate or one and one-half times his regular hourly rate for the time
worked, whichever is greater, providing the time worked or paid does not abut
the employee's workday and applies only once in any four hour period.
   (B)   For purposes of this section, an on-duty officer is one who works any
hours between 11:00 p. m. of one day and 11:00 p. m. of the following day. An
off- duty officer is one who does not work within any such periods.
   (C)   The provisions of this section shall not apply to any on-duty officer
called to work more than once in any three-hour period or to any off-duty
officer called to work more than once in any four-hour period.
(Ord. 83-83. Passed 5-23-83.)
244.21   SALARIES AND WAGES.
   Except as otherwise provided by the Charter and by the laws of the State,
the salaries of all officials of the City shall be fixed from time to time by
Council, and the wages of all other employees shall be fixed in such manner as
Council determines from time to time.
(1956 Code Sec. 169.01)
244.22    ACTING EMPLOYEES' COMPENSATION.
   (A)   An appointing authority may appoint an employee to an acting position
in a higher classification for up to, but not exceeding, twelve months with the
consent of the employee.
   (B)   An employee who is appointed to an acting position with a rate of pay
greater than the rate of pay he is regularly paid shall receive the higher rate
of pay after he has filled the assignment for more than eight hours in any one
week.
   (C)   An employee who is temporarily assigned to an acting position with a
lower rate of pay than he is regularly paid shall receive his regular rate of
pay.
(Ord. 176-83. Passed 11-21-83.)
244.23   COMPUTATION OF PAY DEDUCTIONS.
   Deductions from the pay of a City employee paid every two weeks shall be
figured by dividing his biweekly pay by the number of his work days in the
month. The daily rate thus computed shall be the deduction for each day's
absence.
244.24   PAYROLL DEDUCTIONS.
   (A)   The City Auditor shall deduct from the salary or wages of any City
employee who belongs to a labor union, employee association or the Lima City
Employees' Federal Credit Union, the dues, shares and premiums of such labor
union, employee association or the Lima City Employees' Federal Credit Union,
provided that the employee signs a request in writing authorizing the City
Auditor to make any such deductions. Deductions shall not include initiation
fees or special assessments. Such authorization shall be revocable by written
notice of the employee. The City Auditor is hereby authorized to draw his
warrant on the City Treasurer in favor of the labor union, employee association
or the Lima City Employees' Federal Credit Union for the amounts authorized and
due such organization.
(Ord. 94-67. Passed 5-10-67.)
   (B)   The City Auditor is further authorized to promulgate rules and
regulations for the administration of the voluntary wage deductions authorized
in subsection (A) hereof, including, but not limited to, the preparation of
necessary forms, lists of names, the time for the filing of the authorization
for a deduction and the time for filing the cancellation of a deduction.
(Ord. 140-61. Passed 7-17-61.)
244.25   BASIC PAY PLAN AND BENEFITS FOR EMPLOYEES NOT REPRESENTED IN
COLLECTIVE BARGAINING.
   (A)   AFSCME Parity Employees are hereby defined to be those City employees
and officials who are not members of an employee organization recognized by the
City for the purposes of collective bargaining or otherwise certified by the
State Employees Relations Board for collective bargaining.
      (1)   This section does not apply to employees of the municipal court
judges or employees of the municipal court clerk, unless the wages of such
employees are determined by council under state law. 
      (2)   This section does not apply to non-union employees who are members
of the Lima Police Department or the Lima Fire Department; except this section
does apply to the positions of Secretary to the Police Chief and Secretary to
the Fire Chief.
   (B)   AFSCME Parity Employees shall be paid according to the biweekly pay
ranges and pay schedules established under the collective bargaining agreement
(CBA) with the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees,
Ohio Council 8, Local 1002, AFL-CIO (AFSCME), as such CBA may then be in effect
over time.  AFSCME Parity Employees paid according to pay ranges 26 through 35
shall receive the same percentage increases as provided to the lower pay
ranges, and the Auditor is authorized to amended the pay schedules for pay
ranges 26-35 by the same percentages accordingly.  Such ranges shall be applied
to the several classes or positions for AFSCME Parity Employees established by
Council or unless otherwise specified by Council.
      (1)   This subsection does not apply to City employees, administrators,
or officials whose pay is established by other separate ordinance.
   (C)   In addition to the basic pay plans in (B) above, the AFSCME Parity
Employees are entitled to receive those same economic benefits as are set forth
in the AFSCME CBA, as may then be effective.  This shall include but is not
limited to lump sum payments or bonuses, health care benefits, overtime pay
rate, holidays, personal days, vacations, sick leave, funeral leave, jury duty,
longevity pay, and shall specifically exclude all non-economic benefits
including but not limited to the provisions referring to work time, discipline,
discharge and benefits specifically related to union representation.  The City
Auditor shall make the final determination of what constitutes an economic or
non-economic benefit, unless otherwise determined by Council.
      (1)   Any provision in the AFSCME CBA regarding a lump sum payment or
bonus shall not apply to City employees, administrators, or officials whose pay
is established by other separate ordinance.
(Ord. 150-95.  Passed 12-18-95; Ord. 196-98.  Passed 12-7-98; Ord. 87-02. 
Passed 7-1-02; Ord. 77-04. Passed 5-3-04. Effective 5-8-04; Ord. 106-04. Passed
6-7-04. Effective 5-8-04; Ord. 17-05. Passed 1-24-05. Effective 1-1-05; Ord.
043-08. Passed 3-10-08; Ord. 24-12. Passed 1-23-12.)

244.254   BASIC PAY PLAN AND BENEFITS FOR THE CLERK OF COUNCIL.
   (A)   The paid holidays for the Clerk of Council shall be as follows:
      New Year's Day      Labor Day
      President's Day      Thanksgiving Day
      Martin Luther King Day   Friday after Thanksgiving Day
      Good Friday         1/2 day Christmas Eve
      Memorial Day      Christmas Day
      Independence Day      1/2 day New Year's Eve
   (B)   The paid vacation time for the Clerk of Council shall be as follows:
      None the first year
      Second year         1 week
      Years 2 through 7      2 weeks
      Years 8 through 14      3 weeks
      Years 15 through 24   4 weeks
      Years 25 plus      5 weeks
   Vacation time cannot be accumulated from one year to the next, but must be
taken in the year that it is earned.
   (C)   The paid sick leave for the Clerk of Council shall be as follows:  One
and one- quarter days per month of service accumulated without limit. 
   (D)   The paid disability compensation for the Clerk of Council shall be as
follows:  Fully paid injury leave (not deducted from sick leave) for up to
twelve months for employees injured on the job once they qualify for temporary
total disability payments from the Bureau of Workers' Compensation.
   (E)   The severance pay for the Clerk of Council shall be as follows:  Upon
termination, an employee may cash in unused sick leave at the rate of one day
for each five days accumulated.
   (F)   The funeral leave for the Clerk of Council shall be as follows:  Three
days per occurrence for the immediate family, defined as the spouse, mother,
father, sister, brother, grandparent, mother-in-law, father-in-law, brother-in-
law, sister-in-law, child, step-child, son-in-law or daughter-in-law of the
Clerk of Council.  Sick leave may be used for any other relative subject to
Council approval.
   (G)   The medical insurance average for the Clerk of Council shall be as
follows:
   Employer paid hospital/surgical, major medical and prescription drug
coverage:
         $ 100.00 deductible per person on major medical
         $ 200.00 deductible per family on major medical
         $ 2.00 co-pay (non-generic) on prescriptions
If the Clerk waives medical coverage through the City, the Clerk shall be paid
an annual lump sum payment equal to five hundred dollars ($500.00) after one
full year of service.
   (H)   The life insurance for the Clerk of Council shall be as follows: 
Twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) with additional optional employee and
dependent coverage available at the employee's expense.
   (I)   The pay range of the Clerk of Council shall be twenty-three thousand
dollars ($23,000.00) to twenty-nine thousand dollars ($29,000.00).  There shall
be a performance evaluation after the first six months and the first 12 months
and annually thereafter.  The Clerk of Council shall be eligible for annual
salary increases based on performance.
(Ord. 7-96.  Passed 1-10-96.)
244.255   BASIC PAY PLAN AND BENEFITS FOR THE FIRE CHIEF AND DEPUTY FIRE
CHIEFS.
   (A)   An employee holding the position of Fire Chief or Deputy Fire Chief is
an exempt salaried employee of the City, and shall be paid an annualized salary
as follows, effective January 1, 2012:
      (1)   Fire Chief:         $87,846.00
      with EMT-B certification      $89,603.00
      with EMT-P certification      $93,117.00
      (2)   Deputy Chief:         $75,494.00
      with EMT-B certification      $77,004.00
      with EMT-P certification      $80,024.00
   (B)   The annual salary of the Fire Chief and Deputy Fire Chiefs shall be
increased thereafter by the same percentage as any percentage wage increase
granted to International Association of Firefighters, Local 334 members of the
fire department pursuant to a collective bargaining agreement between the IAFF
and the City.
   (C)   An employee holding the position of Fire Chief or Deputy Chief is an
exempt salaried employee of the City, and shall receive and be subject to those
same economic and health care employee benefits as are set forth in the
currently valid collective bargaining agreement between The City of Lima, Ohio,
and the International Association of Firefighters, Local #334, except for those
provisions relating to overtime, hours of work, discipline, union
representation, or that are otherwise inconsistent with the treatment of
salaried employees.
(Ord. 23-97.  Passed 1-27-97; Ord. 202-98.  Passed 12-21-98; Ord. 11-01. Passed
1-22-01; Ord. 26-04. Passed 2-23-04; Ord. 128-07. Passed 6-18-07; Ord. 005-10.
Passed 1-4-10; Ord. 25-12. Passed 2-6-12; Ord. 311-17. Passed 12-4-17.)
244.256   BASIC PAY PLAN AND BENEFITS FOR THE CHIEF OF THE POLICE DEPARTMENT
AND MAJORS.
   (A)   An employee holding the position of Police Chief or Major is an exempt
salaried employee of the City, and shall receive and be subject to those same
economic and health care employee benefits as are set forth in the currently
valid Collective Bargaining Agreement between the City and the Fraternal Order
of Police, Ohio Labor Council, Inc, (Sergeants/Lieutenants) except for those
provisions relating to overtime, hours of work, discipline, union
representation, or that are otherwise inconsistent with the treatment of
salaried employees.
   (B)   An employee holding the position of Police Chief or Major shall be
paid the following annual salary for calendar year 2002:
      Chief of Police:   $71,610.50
      Major:      $66,306.24
   (C)   The annual salary of the Chief and Majors shall be increased
thereafter by the same percentage as the percentage wage increase granted to
Sergeants and Lieutenants of the Police Department pursuant to a collective
bargaining agreement.
(Ord. 27-97.  Passed 2-10-97; Ord. 215-99.  Passed 12-6-99; Ord. 122-00. 
Passed 8-7-00;  Ord. 189-02.  Passed 12-2-02.)
244.257   MINIMUM STARTING SALARY FOR DEPARTMENT HEADS, CERTAIN DEPUTY
DIRECTORS AND THE SECRETARY TO THE MAYOR.
   (a)   This section shall apply to the following mayoral appointees:
      (1)   Chief of Staff;
      (2)   Director of Finance;
      (3)   Director of Public Works;
      (4)   Deputy Public Works Director I;
      (5)   Deputy Public Works Director II;
      (6)   Director of Community Development;
      (7)   Director of Utilities;
      (8)   Deputy Utilities Director;
      (9)   Director of Human Resources; and
      (10)   Secretary to the Mayor.
   (b)   A new appointee who fills a vacancy in a position set forth in
subsection (a) above shall be paid at a starting pay level not to exceed ninety
percent of the ending pay of the previous appointee in that position.
   (c)   In addition to the minimum starting salary set forth herein, and in
addition to any other ordinance establishing pay raises or benefits for such
positions, employees described in subsection (a) of this section shall receive
those same benefits as are set forth in the effective Agreement with the
American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, Ohio Council 8,
Local 1002, AFL-CIO, except for the provisions referring to work time,
discipline and discharge, and benefits specifically relating to union
representation.
   (d)   Council may make exceptions to the pay levels set forth herein due to
special circumstances as determined by Council.
(Ord. 9-96.  Passed 1-22-96; Ord. 172-16.  Passed 8-8-16.)

244.261   COST OF LIVING ADJUSTMENT. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Former Section
244.261 was repealed by Ordinance 88-83, passed May 23, 1983.)
244.262   DECLARED EMERGENCY COMPENSATION.
   (A)   During an emergency declared by the Mayor, pursuant to Section
648.01, an employee who is unable to report for work or who is ordered not to
report for work by his or her supervisor, department head or appointing
authority shall receive his or her normal rate of pay.
   (B)   An employee who is ordered to report for work or who does report when
not ordered to do so shall receive his or her normal rate of pay and any
overtime compensation, plus compensatory time off for each day or part thereof
worked during his or her normally scheduled hours.
(Ord. 44-80. Passed 3-31-80.)
244.27   POSITION TITLES.
   The meanings of the position titles for the classified service shall be
defined by specifications contained in the Position Classification Plan, an
official copy of which shall be maintained in the offices of the Civil Service
Board.
(Ord. 145-56. Passed 10-1-56.)
244.28     SALARIES AND BENEFITS FOR ELECTED CITY OFFICIALS
   The following salaries shall be paid for the respective elected officials as
set forth below:
   (A)   Mayor.  The Mayor shall continue to be paid the annual salary as set
forth in Section
244.28(A) of Ordinance 247-04 through the term of office of Mayor ending
November 30, 2017.  Thereafter, beginning December 1, 2017, the Mayor’s salary
shall remain the same and shall not be increased.  Beginning December 1, 2019,
and beginning December 1 of each year thereafter, the Mayor’s salary shall be
adjusted in accordance with the Cost of Living Adjustment percentage as set
forth in subsection (G) below.
   (B)   Director of Law. 
      (1)   Part-time Law Director.  The Director of Law who does not elect to
work full-time as set forth below shall continue to be paid the annual salary
as set forth in Section
244.28(B)(1) of Ordinance 247-04 through the term of office of Director of Law
ending December 31, 2017.  Thereafter, beginning January 1, 2018 the Law
Director’s salary shall remain the same and shall not be increased.  Beginning
January 1, 2020, and beginning January 1 of each year thereafter, the Law
Director’s salary shall be adjusted in accordance with the Cost of Living
Adjustment percentage as set forth in subsection (G) below.
      (2)   Full-time Law Director.  Notwithstanding subsection (1) above, if
(a) the Director of Law elect notifies the City Auditor, in writing, before
being sworn in to office, that the Director of Law will serve as a full- time
Director of Law during the entire term of office, will not engage in the
private practice of law, will devote his or her entire time to the duties of
the office and will not engage in any other remunerative employment of any kind
during the entire term of office, and if (b) the Director of Law elect has at
least 5 years of experience in the practice of law in the State of Ohio prior
to being sworn in to office, then the Director of Law shall be paid as follows:
  The Director of Law shall continue to be paid the annual salary as set forth
in Section
244.28(B)(2) of Ordinance 247-04 through the term of office of Director of Law
ending December 31, 2017.  Thereafter, beginning January 1, 2018 the Law
Director’s salary shall remain the same and shall not be increased.  Beginning
January 1, 2020, and beginning January 1 of each year thereafter, the Law
Director’s salary shall be adjusted in accordance with the Cost of Living
Adjustment percentage as set forth in subsection (G) below.
      (3)   In the event of a vacancy in office during the term of Director of
Law, any person appointed to fill the position for the remainder of the term
shall be granted 60 days from the date of appointment to notify the City
Auditor whether such appointee will serve under the part-time or full-time
salary provisions of subsection (1) or (2) above.
   (C)   City Auditor.    The City Auditor shall continue to be paid the annual
salary in accordance with Ordinance 284-12 and receive the increase as set
forth in Section
244.28(C) of Ordinance 247-04, through December 31, 2017.  Thereafter,
beginning January 1, 2018, and beginning January 1 of each year thereafter, the
Auditor’s salary shall be adjusted in accordance with the Cost of Living
Adjustment percentage as set forth in subsection (G) below.
   (D)   President of Council.  The President of Council shall continue to be
paid the annual salary as set forth in Section
244.28(D) of Ordinance 247-04 through December 31, 2017.  Thereafter, beginning
January 1, 2018, and beginning January 1 of each year thereafter, the Council
President’s salary shall be adjusted in accordance with the Cost of Living
Adjustment percentage as set forth in subsection (G) below.
   (E)   Councillor.  Members of Council shall continue to be paid the annual
salary as set forth in Section
244.28(E) of Ordinance 247-04 through December 31, 2017.  Thereafter, beginning
January 1, 2018, and beginning January 1 of each year thereafter, all Council
Members salaries shall be adjusted in accordance with the Cost of Living
Adjustment percentage as set forth in subsection (G) below.
   (F)   In addition to the salaries set forth herein, the City shall provide
health care and life insurance benefits for the Mayor, the Director of Law, the
City Auditor, and their immediate families, in the same manner the City
provides for health care and life insurance benefits for AFSCME Parity
Employees. 
   (G)   Cost of Living Adjustment (COLA).  Beginning on the respective dates
set forth above for the respective elective offices, the salary of each
respective elected official shall be increased by the same percentage as the
Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers (CPI-U) reported by the U.S.
Bureau of Labor Statistics for the 12 month period ending through the month of
October preceding the effective date of the annual adjustment (the October CPI-
U).  For example, for a Cost of Living Adjustment  to be granted under this
section and scheduled to begin January 1, 2018, the CPI-U reported for the 12
month period ending through October 2017 (the October CPI-U) shall be the CPI-
U used to calculate a salary adjustment.
      (1)   Regardless of the reported October CPI-U, in no event shall a COLA
granted under this section exceed 3%.
      (2)   In the event the reported October CPI-U is a zero or a negative
number, then no COLA shall be granted for that respective year.
   (H)   Salaries of elected officials shall be payable in equal monthly
installments.
(Ord. 170-96.  Passed 12-16-96; Ord. 222-00.  Passed 11-20-00; Ord. 247-04.
Passed 12-20-04; Ord. 261-14, Passed 11-17-14.)
244.29   LONGEVITY PAY.
   (A)   Each employee who has continuous service with the City exceeding the
years set forth below, shall receive additional compensation over and above
that provided in the basic pay plan in Section
244.25 as follows:
      (1)   Upon the completion of ten years of continuous service with the
City: five hundred fifty dollars ($550.00).
      (2)   Upon the completion of fifteen years of continuous service with the
City: nine hundred dollars ($900.00).
      (3)   Upon the completion of twenty years of continuous service with the
City: one thousand two hundred fifty dollars ($1,250.00).
      (4)   Upon the completion of twenty-five years of continuous service with
the City: one thousand six hundred dollars ($1,600.00).
   (B)   Longevity pay shall be paid as follows:
      (1)   All employees covered under subsections (a) hereof shall begin
receiving their full longevity payments in December, 1987.
      (2)   Employees who become eligible for longevity payments in 1987, but
prior to December 1, 1987, shall receive their full longevity payment in
December, 1987.
      (3)   All employees becoming eligible for longevity payments subsequent
to December 1, 1987 and any year thereafter shall receive their longevity
payment the following December.
      (4)   All eligible employees who terminate employment prior to December 1
of any year shall receive as severance pay, the prorated share of their
longevity pay based on the number of months completed during the year that
termination occurs.
      (5)   All longevity payments, except those provided in division (b)(4) of
this section shall be made by separate check with the appropriate deductions.
   (C)   This section shall not apply to employees covered under Sections
244.291  and 244.292.
(Ord. 14-87. Passed 2-9-87.)
244.291   LONGEVITY PAY FOR CERTAIN MEMBERS OF THE LIMA POLICE DEPARTMENT.
   (A)   From and after April 1, 1983, each employee described in division (c)
of this section who has continuous service for the City exceeding the years set
forth herein, shall receive additional compensation over and above that
provided In the basic pay plan in Section
244.251 as follows:
      (1)   Upon the completion of ten years of continuous service with the
City: three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00) annually.
      (2)   Upon the completion of fifteen years of continuous service with the
City: seven hundred dollars ($700.00) annually.
      (3)   Upon the completion of twenty years of continuous service with the
City: one thousand fifty dollars ($1,050.00) annually.
      (4)   Upon the completion of twenty-five years of continuous service with
the City: one thousand four hundred dollars ($1,400.00) annually.
   (B)   This section shall be implemented as follows:
      (1)   Employees presently receiving longevity payments shall have such
amount modified to conform to the schedule in division (A) of this section,
effective April 1, 1983.
      (2)   Employees who have not received longevity prior to April 1, 1983,
but become eligible due to passing the appropriate anniversary date of
employment, shall commence receiving longevity according to the schedule in
division (A) of this section as of the date of eligibility.
      (3)   Employees shall have their longevity payments increased according
to the schedule in division (A) of this section upon completing the appropriate
length of service on their anniversary date.
   (C)   This section shall only apply to the following employees of the Police
Department: Chief of Police, inspectors, lieutenants, sergeants, detectives,
identification officers and patrolmen.
   (D)   Longevity pay as provided in this section shall be paid biweekly along
with regular compensation.
(Ord. 82-83. Passed 5-23-83.)
244.292   LONGEVITY PAY FOR NONCIVILIAN MEMBERS OF THE LIMA FIRE DEPARTMENT.
   (A)   From and after April 24, 1983, each noncivilian employee of the Lima
Fire  Department who has continuous service with the City exceeding the years
set forth below, shall receive additional compensation over and above that
provided for in the basic pay plan in Section
244.252 as follows:
      (1)   Upon completion of ten years of continuous service with the City:
three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00).
      (2)   Upon completion of fifteen years of continuous service with the
City: seven hundred dollars ($700.00).
      (3)   Upon completion of twenty years of continuous service with the
City: one thousand fifty dollars ($1,050.00).
      (4)   Upon the completion of twenty-five years of continuous service with
the City: one thousand four hundred dollars ($1,400.00).
   (B)   Longevity pay shall be paid as follows:
      (1)   During the first full pay period of December, 1983, employees
described in division (A) of this section shall receive two-thirds of the
appropriate new longevity scale.
      (2)   Employees who are not eligible to receive longevity prior to April
24, 1983, but become eligible prior to December 1, 1983, shall receive two-
thirds of the appropriate new longevity scale during the first full pay period
of December, 1983.
      (3)   All employees covered under division (A)(1) and (B)(1) of this
section shall begin receiving their full longevity payments in December, 1984.
      (4)   Employees who become eligible for longevity payments in 1984 but
prior to December 1, 1984, shall receive their full longevity payments in
December, 1984.
      (5)   All employees who become eligible for longevity payments subsequent
to December 1, 1984 and a year thereafter, shall receive their longevity
payment the following December. All eligible employees who terminate employment
prior to December 1 of any year shall receive, as severance pay, the prorated
share of their longevity pay based on the number of months completed during the
year the termination occurs.
      (6)   All longevity payments except those provided in division (B)(5) of
this section shall be made by separate check with the appropriate deductions.
   (C)   This section shall not apply to employees covered under Sections
244.29 and
244.291.
(Ord. 104-83. Passed 5-23-83.)
244.30   ADMINISTRATION OF THE PAY PLAN.
   (A)   The first five steps of the pay ranges shall be interpreted as
follows:
      (1)   Step A is the minimum rate and shall normally be the hiring rate
for the class. In cases where it is difficult to secure qualified personnel,
the appointing authority, with the authorization of the Civil Service Board and
Council, may hire at Step B or C.
      (2)   Step B is an incentive advancement to encourage an employee to
improve his work. Employees shall be advanced to Step B at the beginning of the
pay period following the completion of six months of satisfactory service.
      (3)   Step C represents the middle value of the salary range and is the
rate at which a fully qualified, experienced and conscientious employee may
expect to be paid after a reasonable period of satisfactory service. An
employee shall be advanced to Step C at the beginning of the pay period after
the completion of 18 months of service in the class. After one year at Step B,
an employee may be advanced to Step C, provided that the advancement is
recommended by the appointing authority and approved by the Civil Service
Board.
      (4)   Step D is to reward employees who have completed long service with
the City. An employee shall be advanced to Step D at the beginning of the pay
period after the completion of thirty-six months of service in the class.
      (5)   Step E is to reward employees who have completed longer service
with the City. An employee shall be advanced to Step E at the beginning of the
pay period after the completion of sixty months of service in the class.
   (B)   In any case where, by reason of unusual circumstances, rigid adherence
to the foregoing principles relating to salary adjustments would cause a
manifest injustice, Council, on recommendation of the Civil Service Board, may
make such order relating thereto as ln its discretion is proper.
   (C)   Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this section, an employee
who is promoted or reclassified from one class to another, which has a higher
or overlapping salary range, shall be placed in Step A of the new range or in a
step above his or her old salary, whichever is higher.
   (D)   Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this section, an employee
who is promoted from one class to another shall advance to the next pay step
upon the completion of six months ln the pay step established pursuant to
subsection (C) hereof.  Thereafter, the employee shall again advance to the
next pay steps after successive completion of the required time periods.
   (E)   When one employee continuously occupies two or more positions
concurrently, the highest salary range provided for one of the positions
occupied shall be the appropriate range for determining the total compensation.
   (F)   For purposes of this section, employees who have resigned and are
subsequently duly reinstated shall be considered, for pay purposes, the same as
original appointees. Employees separated from the service because of injury or
physical disability and subsequently duly reinstated to the same or similar
positions and employees laid off because of shortage of funds or work and
subsequently re-employed shall be given credit for previous service.
(Ord. 50-80. Passed 3-31-80.)
244.31   ELIGIBILITY REGULATIONS FOR EMPLOYEES.
   Anything in this chapter to the contrary notwithstanding, it is hereby
provided that the step status of any employee who has had five years of service
with the City as of the effective date of this section (Ordinance 261-68,
passed October 7, 1968), who is not now in Step E and who was promoted during
the period from January 1, 1963, to July 1, 1968, shall be recomputed from the
date of such employee's last promotion to determine the date of his eligibility
for Steps D and E following six and eighteen months of service in the class.
Such employees who were promoted during the period from January 1, 1963, to
July 1, 1968, and who have not completed at least six months of service in the
class shall be placed in Step C until their eligible date is reached.
(Ord. 261-68. Passed 10-7-68.)
244.32   COMPENSATION OF ACTING MAYOR.
   Any person serving in the capacity of Acting Mayor under the provisions of
Section 71 of the City Charter shall be compensated at the rate of seventy-one
dollars and eighty-one cents ($71.81) per day for each day of service to the
City.
   The compensation for the Acting Mayor shall be payable in equal monthly
installments and shall be computed on the basis of a five-day week, performed
Monday through Friday.
   Effective January 1, 1992, any person serving in the capacity of Acting
Mayor under the provisions of Section 71 of the City Charter shall be
compensated at the rate of 1/365th of the current Mayor's salary for each day
served which falls on Monday through Friday. If the Acting Mayor serves on
Saturday and/or Sunday, then the salary for those days must be separately
approved by Council at the rate then determined by Council. The compensation
shall be payable in equal monthly installments.
(Ord. 19-90.  Passed 2-26-90.)
244.33   BONDS.
   A blanket bond shall be provided by the City for the faithful performance of
the duties of all City officers and employees. Such blanket bond shall be in
the indicated amounts for the following offices or appointments:
      Mayor            $20,000
      Auditor            100,000
      Chief Deputy Auditor      100,000
      Treasurer            100,000
      Clerk of the Municipal Court   100,000
      Finance Director         100,000
      Bailiff of the Municipal Court   20,000
      Deputy Bailiff of the Municipal Court   20,000
      All other officers and employees of the City            20,000 each
   The City shall pay the premiums on the bonds set forth in this section.
   All bonds shall be subject to the approval of Council. All other bonds
required by this section shall be delivered to the City Treasurer, who shall in
a like manner record and preserve them.
(Ord. 147-89.  Passed 8-7-89.)
244.34   FREE TRANSPORTATION.
   Each employee of the City shall have the privilege of free transportation as
a passenger on all bus lines operated by a franchise holder, its successors and
assigns, as and for a fringe benefit, in addition to the regular compensation
and other benefits now enjoyed by such employee.
(Ord. 78-75. Passed 4-14-75.)
244.35   JURY OR WITNESS SERVICE.
   (A)   Each employee shall be paid his usual and normal salary and
compensation during such time as he is called for jury duty, or serves as a
member of a jury, or as a subpoenaed witness, In any case ln any court,
provided such employee turns over the compensation received by him for court
service to the Auditor. If an employee's jury or witness service consumes only
a portion of a work day, the employee shall report to work for the remainder of
the work day.
   (B)   This section shall not apply to police officers who serve as witnesses
pursuant to Section
244.20.
(Ord. 215-76. Passed 12-20-76.)
244.36   EMPLOYEE PERSONNEL FILES.
   Each employee may inspect his personnel file maintained by the Mayor, the
Mayor's department head or the employee's supervisor, at such times as are
determined to be reasonable by the persons having custody and control of the
files. Upon written request of the employee, all items more than two years old,
except copies of letters of appointment or job applications, shall be removed
from the files and destroyed.
(Ord. 46-80. Passed 3-24-80.)
244.37   PRIOR SERVICE CREDIT.
   Each classified employee of the City, who had been previously employed by
the City, with an interruption in his term of service not exceeding five years,
for whatever reason, shall be entitled to a credit for such prior service for
purposes of computing vacation time and accumulated sick leave only.
   Prior service shall mean service within the classified service of the City,
irrespective of whether such service was within a safety division, under the
Comprehensive Employment Training Act or as a result of any other program.
Prior service shall not mean service within the unclassified service, as an
elected official, or as a part-time, temporary or seasonal employee of the
City.
   This section shall not apply to retired City employees who are rehired by
the City. 
(Ord. 22-77. Passed 1-24-77.)
244.38   WAIVERS.
   An employee may waive any portion of his or her compensation or any benefit
established by Council. All such waivers shall be effective upon filing
therefor with the City Auditor, except that employees in the classified service
must also file the written consent therefor of the Civil Service Board. If an
employee withdraws any such waiver or files a new waiver, the Auditor shall
immediately notify the employee's appointing authority in writing.
(Ord. 8-79. Passed 1-8-79.)
244.39   CONTRIBUTIONS TO PUBLIC EMPLOYEES RETIREMENT SYSTEM AND POLICE AND
FIREMEN'S DISABILITY AND PENSION FUND.
   (A)   Effective for the payroll period beginning January 1, 1988, the
employee contribution to the Public Employees Retirement System (PERS), which
must be paid by employees of the City who are members of PERS, shall be paid
directly to PERS by the City on behalf of employees as a salary reduction
"pick-up," subject to the following provisions.
      (1)   The "pick-up" by the City shall be mandatory for all employees who
are members of PERS. No employee shall have the option of choosing to receive
such amounts directly instead of having them paid on his or her behalf directly
to PERS.
      (2)   The "pick-up" by the City shall not affect the employee's salary or
benefits otherwise provided for in these Codified Ordinances, or any payment
which is determined with reference to such salary or benefits.
   (B)   Effective for the payroll period beginning January 1, 1988, the
employee contribution to the Police and Firemen's Disability and Pension Fund
(PFDPF), which must be paid by employees of the City who are members of such
Fund, shall be paid directly to such Fund by the City on behalf of employees as
a salary reduction "pick-up," subject to the following provisions.
      (1)   The "pick-up" by the City shall be mandatory for all employees who
are members of PFDPF; no employee shall have the option of choosing to receive
such amounts directly instead of having them paid on his or her behalf directly
to PFDPF.
      (2)   The "pick-up" by the City shall not affect the employee's salary or
benefits otherwise provided for in these Codified Ordinances, or any payment
which is determined with reference to such salary or benefits.
   (C)   This section establishes a "pick-up" program in which every employee's
contribution to the Public Employees Retirement System or to the Police and
Firemen's Disability and Pension Fund is paid by the City directly to such Fund
on behalf of such employee. The Mayor or his or her designee is hereby directed
to take all acts necessary and appropriate to initiate implementation of this
section, including, but not limited to, making applications to the Internal
Revenue Service for a private letter ruling concerning Federal tax treatment of
the "pickup" plans and making applications to the boards administering the PERS
and PFDPF programs to determine the requirements of such boards in connection
with such "pick-up" plans.
   (D)   The City Auditor is hereby authorized and directed to take all
necessary actions to implement the "pick-up" plans authorized by this section.
(Ord. 149-87. Passed 12-21-87.)
244.40   EMPLOYEE SUGGESTION PROGRAM.
   (A)   An Employee Suggestion Program is hereby established in order to
develop and implement programs which will reduce the cost and improve
productivity of City government and to involve employees in this process by
soliciting their input and rewarding their efforts. Department directors,
deputy directors and elected officials are excluded from said program.
   (B)   Incentive awards for employees participating in the Employee
Suggestion Program are established as follows:
      Amount of Savings      Cash Award
      $   1,000         $   50.00
         2,000            100.00
         3,000            150.00
         4,000            200.00
         5,000            250.00
         6,000            300.00
         7,000            350.00
         8,000            400.00
         9,000            450.00
        10,000+            500.00
       100,000+            1,000.00
   (C)   An Employee Suggestion Program Committee is hereby formed, consisting
of the Auditor, Finance Director, Administrative Coordinator, the appropriate
department director, and the union representative of the union of which the
employee making the suggestion is a member. If the employee is not a union
member, then the union representative position shall be filled by the Human
Resources Director. Said Committee is hereby given the authority to review
suggestions and to determine what suggestions will be adopted, to authorize the
award to be given to the employee, and to determine eligibility for said award.
(Ord. 80-91.  Passed 3-25-91.)
244.41   BONUS FOR MEDICAL COST SAVINGS.
   A policy is hereby established by and for the City whereby upon receipt and
realization of a savings of the cost of medical expenses, by revealing medical
cost billing errors, the employer who is responsible for such cost savings
shall be entitled to a bonus of ten percent of the applicable cost savings that
the Mayor acknowledges to have been attributable to said employee. Eligibility
for said bonus is to be determined by the Mayor.
(Ord. 81-91.  Passed 3-25-91.)
244.42   EMPLOYEE SERVICE AWARDS PROGRAM.
   (A)   An Employee Service Awards Program is hereby established in order to
develop and implement programs which will improve the productivity of City
government and to involve employees in this process by rewarding their efforts.
   (B)   The City Auditor is hereby authorized and directed to issue his or her
warrants against the proper appropriation item in payment of the obligation
herein authorized upon presentation of the proper voucher or vouchers therefor.
(Ord. 102-92. Passed 7-27-92.)
244.43   REIMBURSEMENT OF EXPENSES FOR GRATUITIES AND TIPS WHILE ON CITY
BUSINESS.
   There is hereby adopted in and for the City a policy allowing for the
reimbursement to City employees of gratuity and other tip expenses incurred
while on City business during the course of City employment.  However, the
maximum amount for reimbursable gratuities or tips shall be fifteen percent of
the underlying cost of the service and/or goods provided, and the maximum
amount for reimbursable gratuities or tips for which there is no underlying
cost or charge shall be five dollars ($5.00).  Further, no such gratuity or tip
shall be subject to reimbursement unless it is accompanied by a proper receipt.
(Ord. 87-95.  Passed 7-24-95.)
244.44   PART- TIME EMPLOYEE BENEFITS.
   (A)   Employees of the City shall be determined to be part-time employees
under  the  following conditions:
      (1)   Hourly employees. Those City employees who work less than thirty
hours per week, on a regular basis; except that hourly employees for the Police
Support Services Program shall be considered part-time if they work less than
forty hours per week on a regular basis; and
      (2)   Salaried employees. Those City employees who earn an annual salary
of less than nine thousand dollars ($9,000.00).
   (B)   Part-time employees shall have the following employment benefits:
      (1)   Sick leave.  For part-time employees, sick leave and the sell-back
option shall be governed by the Ohio Revised Code and not by Section
244.02.
      (2)   Vacation.  Vacation for part-time  employees  shall  accrue  based 
upon  actual hours worked.
      (3)   Life Insurance.  Part-time employees shall receive the same life
insurance benefit as full-time employees, at the level of the hourly employee’s
annual salary, not to exceed twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00).
      (4)   Longevity pay.  Part-time employees shall not receive longevity pay
except for part-time employees already qualified for the longevity pay for the
current year, but not in any subsequent years.
      (5)   Holiday pay.  Part-time employees shall not receive pay for
holidays off; however, if a part-time employee works on a holiday, then he or
she shall receive pay of time and one-half for each hour worked.
      (6)   Personal days.  Part-time employees shall not be granted personal
days.
      (7)   Maternity leave.  Maternity leave is governed by the Ohio Revised
Code, the Family Leave Act and Section
244.031.
      (8)   Injury leave.  Part-time employees shall receive injury leave as
set forth in Section
244.032.
      (9)   Funeral leave.  Part-time employees shall be granted up to three
days leave and, if one or more of the days falls on a normally scheduled
workday, the pay will be based upon hours scheduled to be worked.
      (10)   Health care benefits.  Part-time employees shall not be afforded
health care benefits.
(Ord. 130-95.  Passed 10-23-95; Ord. 105-04. Passed 6-7-04; Ord. 102-15. Passed
5-18-15.)
244.45   NON-DISCRIMINATION IN EMPLOYMENT ACTIONS.
   Except as may be permitted by law because of a bona-fide physical, medical,
skill, knowledge, experience, or education qualification or because of a bona-
fide employment policy, rule, law, or court order involving civil rights or
veterans preferences, no employee of the City of Lima and no person seeking
employment by the City of Lima shall be employed or appointed, refused
employment or appointment, suspended, reduced, laid off, discharged, promoted,
demoted, or in any way favored or discriminated against because of such
person's race, color, religion, gender, gender identity, sexual orientation or
preference, military status, national origin, disability, age, or ancestry.
(Ord. 306-09. Passed 12-7-09.)
