   Falsification - see GEN. OFF.

   Billposting and handbills - see GEN. OFF.

   Misrepresenting price or quality - see GEN. OFF.
608.03
816.01   ADDING MERCHANDISE TO THE SUBJECT MATTER OF DISTRESS SALE.
   No person shall add, permit to be added, sell or permit to be sold any
goods, wares or merchandise which are not a part of the subject matter, as
represented, of a sale which is claimed to be the result of fire, wreck,
bankruptcy, closing out, going out of business or similar circumstances. No
person shall bring any such falsely represented material into the place where
such distress sale is being or is to be held. However, the provisions of this
section shall not apply to judicial sales.
(1956 Code Sec. 905.03)
816.02   FALSE REPRESENTATION OF DISTRESS SALES.
   No person shall represent by advertisement by newspaper, loudspeaker, radio,
poster, bill or otherwise that he is operating, offering or maintaining a fire
sale, wreck sale, bankruptcy sale, closing out or going-out-of-business sale or
a similar sale whereby the public is led to believe that it is being offered
merchandise at reduced prices on account of a fire, wreck, bankruptcy, closing
out or discontinuance of business, when, in fact, such sale is not a bona fide
fire sale, wreck sale, bankruptcy sale or closing-out or going-out-of-business
sale.
(1956 Code Sec. 905.04)
816.99   PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
802.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 818
Entertainment Centers

818.19   Authority of the Director of Public Works.
818.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Use or possession of drug paraphernalia - see GEN. OFF.
624.07
   Endangering children - see GEN. OFF.
636.13
   Contributing to the unruliness or delinquency of a minor - see GEN. OFF.
636.14
   Disorderly conduct - see GEN. OFF.
648.04
   Recreation centers - see B.R. & T.
810.01
818.01   FINDINGS; PURPOSE.
   This chapter is an exercise of police power for the protection of the
welfare, health and safety of those children who attend and patronize
entertainment centers. The City Council hereby finds and declares that the
pervasive problems of runaway children, violence, drug abuse and abuse of
children are problems of such magnitude that they are a matter of City concern
and are contributed to by unregulated teen entertainment centers.  As such,
this chapter shall regulate entertainment centers concerning the admission of
persons under the age of twenty-one years.
(Ord. 51-94.  Passed 5-23-94.)
818.02   INTERPRETATION.
   The provisions of this chapter shall be construed liberally for the
accomplishment of the purposes thereof. Nothing contained in this chapter shall
be deemed to repeal or modify any other provision of these Codified Ordinances
relating to teen entertainment centers or licensing. 
(Ord. 51-94.  Passed 5-23-94.)
818.03   CONFLICTS OF LAWS.
   In the event of a conflict between any of the provisions of this chapter and
any other provision of these Codified Ordinances, the provision of this chapter
shall apply.
(Ord. 51-94.  Passed 5-23-94.)
818.04   DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter and unless the context plainly requires
otherwise the following definitions are adopted:
   (A)   "Department" means Department of Public Works of the City.
   (B)   "Director" means Director of Public Works of the City.
   (C)   "Knowingly" shall have the definition set forth in Section
606.02 of the General Offenses Code.
   (D)   "Person" means a natural person, a corporation, a partnership or an
unincorporated association.
   (E)   "Public dance" means any dance that is readily accessible to the
public and which:
      (1)   Is held and conducted for a profit, direct or indirect; or
      (2)   Requires a monetary payment or contribution from any of the persons
admitted.
   (F)   "Teen dance" means any public dance which permits the entry of persons
under the age of twenty-one years.
   (G)   "Teen entertainment center" means any place where a teen dance or
other form of entertainment, which is specifically advertised or promoted as an
activity for persons under the age of twenty-one years, is conducted, operated
or maintained, or which actually attracts a substantial number of persons (more
than fifteen) under the age of twenty-one years on a regular basis, and
includes the premises in which the teen dance or entertainment is conducted,
operated or maintained, including, but not limited to, all parking areas,
hallways, bathrooms and all adjoining areas on the premises accessible to the
public during the dance or entertainment.
   (H)   "Recklessly" shall have the definition set forth in Section
606.02 of the General Offenses Code.
(Ord. 51-94.  Passed 5-23-94.)
818.05   TEEN ENTERTAINMENT CENTERS; LICENSE REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS.
   (A)   In General.  No person shall conduct or operate a teen dance or teen
entertainment center unless the person who is conducting or operating such teen
dance or teen entertainment center has obtained a license in accordance with
the provisions of this chapter.
   (B)   Exceptions.
      (1)   The requirements of this chapter shall not apply if the teen
entertainment center is sponsored by an accredited educational institution.
      (2)   The requirements of this chapter shall not apply if the teen
entertainment center is sponsored by a non-profit tax-exempt organization,
corporation or association recognized by the United States of America as exempt
from Federal income taxation pursuant to 501(c)(1) or (3) of the Internal
Revenue Code of 1986, 96 U.S.C. 501, as amended.
      (3)   If the Teen Entertainment Center is managed or operated by the
City, the requirements of this chapter may be waived by the Mayor.
      (4)   The following specific businesses are exempted from the provisions
of this chapter: skating rinks and bowling alleys.
   (C)   One-Day Events.
      (1)   Persons wishing to conduct a teen dance or other entertainment
oriented to persons under the age of twenty-one, open to the public, and which
begin and end within a twenty-four hour period, shall be required to obtain a
special one-day permit for the same, for which there shall be a fifteen dollar
($15.00) permit fee.
      (2)   A sworn affidavit providing and verifying the same information as
is required for a license under this chapter shall be required to obtain this
permit.
      (3)   A one-day event permit shall be allowed only twice in each calendar
year for the same location or for the same person or other entity.
      (4)   The denial or revocation of this permit shall be for the same
reasons as are set forth for the denial or revocation of a license.
      (5)   All other requirements set forth for licenses under this chapter
shall be applicable to this special permit.
      (6)   Operating a teen dance or other entertainment oriented to persons
under the age of twenty-one, without a permit, shall be subject to the
penalties set forth in Section
818.99.
(Ord. 51-94.  Passed 5-23-94.)
818.06   LICENSE APPLICATION; REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   The person desiring to conduct and/or operate a teen entertainment
center shall be responsible for obtaining a teen entertainment center license.
Each applicant shall complete an application which shall include the following
information:
      (1)   The name and address of the applicant;
      (2)   The names and addresses of the operator, manager and employees of
the teen entertainment center;
      (3)   The name and address of the owner of the premises on which the teen
entertainment center is located;
      (4)   The name of the unincorporated association, corporation or
partnership, and the names and addresses of the limited partners, partners,
officers and directors thereof, if the information given pursuant to paragraphs
(a)(1) to (3) hereof involves an unincorporated association, corporation or
partnership;
      (5)   A statement of any and all measures to be used to ensure that
adequate traffic control and crowd protection, both within and without the
premises, will be maintained;
      (6)   Proof of indemnification required by Section
818.18;
      (7)   A statement from the applicant that the premises are in compliance
with all City laws, including, but not limited to, the Planning and Zoning
Code, the Building and Housing Code, the Fire Prevention Code, and the Property
Maintenance Code, and a statement that the applicant will, in the conduct and
operation of the teen entertainment center, comply with all City laws,
including, but not limited to, the noise control ordinance;
      (8)   Such other information as may be reasonably required by the
Director of Public Works; and
      (9)   An oath or affirmation that the information listed is true under
penalty of perjury.
   (B)   The applicant must hold a Certificate of Occupancy for the premises.
(Ord. 51-94.  Passed 5-23-94.)
818.07    LICENSE DENIAL.
   The Director shall deny a license if:
   (A)   The applicant has failed to comply with all State, County and City
laws, including, but not limited to, the Planning and Zoning Code, the Building
and Housing Code, the Fire Prevention Code and the Property Maintenance Code;
   (B)   The applicant or any of the applicant's officers, directors, partners,
operators or employees, or any other person involved in the operation of the
teen entertainment center, has:
      (1)   Committed any act which, if committed by a licensee, would be
grounds for the suspension or revocation of a license or permit;
      (2)   Been convicted within the last ten years of:
         (a)   Any offense of violence, as defined in Ohio R.C. 2901.01(I) or
Section
606.01(i) of the General Offenses Code, or any felony under Ohio R.C. Chapter
2925 or any felony under Ohio R.C. 2923 involving weapons violations, or
similar state laws of other states; or
         (b)   Contributing to the dependency or delinquency of a minor; or
         (c)   A crime involving prostitution, solicitation or assault on a
juvenile; or
         (d)   A crime involving any drug offense; or
      (3)   Been convicted of any sex offense involving a minor prohibited by
the Ohio Revised Code or the laws of the City of any other similar state law of
other states; or
      (4)   The applicant has been refused a license or has had a license
revoked under the provisions of this chapter, provided, however, that any
applicant denied a license may re-apply if the basis for such denial no longer
exists.
(Ord. 51-94.  Passed 5-23-94.)
818.08   LICENSE SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION.
   A license issued pursuant to this chapter may be suspended or revoked upon a
finding that any one or more of the following conditions exist:
   (A)   The license was procured by fraud or false representation or omission
of a material fact in the license application;
   (B)   The applicant or licensee, or any officer, director or agent thereof,
knowingly has made any false statement or given any false information in
connection with an application for a license or a renewal of a license;
   (C)   The licensee, or any employee, agent, partner, director, officer or
manager thereof, has knowingly allowed or permitted:
      (1)   A felony involving a crime of violence, as defined in Ohio R.C.
2901.01(I) or Section
606.01(i) of the General Offenses Code, or any felony under Ohio R.C. Chapter
2925 for drug offenses, to occur in or upon the teen entertainment center
premises;
      (2)   A crime involving prostitution, solicitation or assault on a
juvenile, to occur in or upon the teen entertainment center premises;
      (3)   Any sex offense prohibited by the Ohio Revised Code or the laws of
the City, to occur in or upon the teen entertainment center premises;
      (4)   The possession of any weapon, or the possession or consumption of
alcohol, marijuana, cocaine or any other controlled substance (as defined in
the Ohio Revised Code or in these Codified Ordinances, as amended) in or upon
the teen entertainment center premises; or has knowingly failed to remove from
such premises any person who appears to be under the influence of or affected
by the use of alcohol or any controlled substance or whose conduct poses a
physical danger to the safety of others present;
   (D)   The licensee or any employee, agent, partner, director, officer or
manager thereof violated any of the provisions of this chapter or committed any
act which is a ground for denial of a license issued pursuant to this chapter;
or
   (E)   The building, structure, equipment or location of the business or
dance for which the license was issued does not comply with the requirements or
fails to meet the standards of the applicable health, zoning, building,
property maintenance, electrical or fire and/or safety laws of the State and
the City, or the requirements of this chapter.
(Ord. 51-94.  Passed 5-23-94.)
818.09   SECURITY PERSONNEL.
   (A)   It shall be the obligation of every person licensed under this chapter
to ensure that an adequate number of qualified security personnel are employed
and in attendance upon the teen entertainment center premises during and
following each teen dance, or other form of entertainment, as is necessary to
maintain order and ensure compliance with the laws of the State and the
ordinances of the City.  An "adequate number of security personnel" shall
include at least two persons trained as law enforcement personnel, which may
include off-duty Lima police officers. At no time shall fewer than twenty-five
percent of the security personnel in attendance at a teen dance or other form
of entertainment have training as law enforcement personnel. Those security
personnel not having law enforcement training must have received formal
training in crowd control by an agency not associated with the licensee.
Additional security measures may be required from time to time by the Director
of Public Works.
   (B)   It shall be the further obligation of every person licensed under this
chapter to employ, during and following each teen dance or other form of
entertainment, at least one off-duty Lima police officer to patrol the
sidewalks and public areas abutting the teen entertainment center.
(Ord. 51-94.  Passed 5-23-94.)
818.10   AGE RESTRICTIONS; IDENTIFICATION REQUIREMENTS FOR TEEN DANCES AND TEEN
ENTERTAINMENT CENTERS.
   (A)   No person conducting or operating a teen dance or teen entertainment
center shall permit, either by act or omission, any person under the age of
fifteen years to enter or remain on the premises without a parent or legal
guardian present.
   (B)   No person conducting or operating a teen dance or teen entertainment
center shall permit, either by act or omission, any person twenty-one years of
age or older to enter or remain upon the premises, except a parent or legal
guardian accompanying a person under the age of twenty-one years, and except
bona fide employees of the person conducting or operating such teen dance or
teen entertainment center.
   (C)   The person conducting and/or operating a teen dance or teen
entertainment center shall require identification showing the age of each
person admitted or seeking to be admitted.
   (D)   No person shall, by affirmative misrepresentation of age, obtain
admittance to or permission to remain in any teen dance or teen entertainment
center in violation of this chapter.
   (E)   No person shall knowingly or recklessly permit a person to enter or
remain at any teen dance or teen entertainment center in violation of this
chapter.
(Ord. 51-94.  Passed 5-23-94.)
818.11   HOURS OF OPERATION.
   No teen dance or teen entertainment center shall be conducted, operated or
otherwise open to the public between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 8:00 a.m.,
and the exclusion or attempted exclusion during those eight hours of persons
under twenty-one years of age shall not relieve any person operating,
maintaining or conducting such a dance or teen entertainment center from this
prohibition. In no event shall activities be conducted which would cause or
allow a violation of the curfew laws for the City, as set forth in Section
648.10 of these Codified Ordinances.
(Ord. 51-94.  Passed 5-23-94.)
818.12   RE-ADMISSION FEE.
   No person conducting or operating a teen dance or teen entertainment center
shall permit any person, other than an employee, to leave the dance or teen
entertainment center and return unless that person pays a re-admission fee
equal to, or greater than, one-half of the original price of admission.
(Ord. 51-94.  Passed 5-23-94.)
818.13   ACCESS BY PEACE OFFICERS AND DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS.
   All peace officers of the City and/or the Director, or his designee, shall
have free access to teen dances and the teen entertainment center when a dance
or other form of entertainment is being conducted, for the purpose of
inspection and to enforce compliance with the provisions of this chapter. The
licensee must provide access to all peace officers and/or the Director, or his
designee, whether the teen entertainment center is open for operation or not.
(Ord. 51-94.  Passed 5-23-94.)
818.14   LICENSE FEE.
   The annual fee for a teen entertainment center license shall be as provided
in Section
868.01. The fee is nonrefundable if the license is denied.
(Ord. 51-94.  Passed 5-23-94; Ord. 178-17.  Passed 8-21-17.)
818.15   EFFECT OF PREVIOUSLY ISSUED LICENSES.
   All licenses or permits issued prior to the effective date of this chapter
shall entitle the holder of such license or permit to a period of thirty-five
days, following the effective date of this chapter, to comply with the
provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 51-94.  Passed 5-23-94.)
818.16   TRANSFERABILITY OF LICENSES.
   Any license issued under the provisions of this chapter shall apply to a
single licensee and to a single location only and shall not be transferable to
other locations or to other persons.
(Ord. 51-94.  Passed 5-23-94.)
818.17   EFFECTIVE PERIOD OF LICENSES.
   Each license issued by the Director under this chapter shall be valid for a
period of one year.
(Ord. 51-94.  Passed 5-23-94.)
818.18   INDEMNIFICATION; INSURANCE.
   (A)   A licensee under this chapter shall indemnify the City and hold it
harmless from any and all losses, claims, actions or damages suffered by any
person or persons by reason of or resulting from any negligence of the licensee
or its agents, employees or patrons, or on account of any act or omission of
the licensee in the exercise of its license, use or occupancy of the premises.
In the event that any suit or action is brought against the City, the licensee
shall, upon notice of the commencement thereof, defend the same, at no cost and
expense to the City, and promptly satisfy any final judgment adverse to the
City or adverse to the City and the licensee jointly, provided, however, that
the City shall retain the right to participate in such action if it chooses to
do so. The above liability shall not be diminished by the fact, if it be a
fact, that any such death, injury, damage, loss, cost or expense may have been,
or may be alleged to have been, contributed to by the negligence of the City or
its officers, employees or agents, provided, however, that nothing contained in
this section shall be construed as requiring the licensee to indemnify the City
against liability for damages arising out of bodily injury to persons or damage
to property caused by or resulting from the sole negligence of the City or its
officers, employees or agents.
   (B)   As a condition precedent to obtaining a license, the licensee shall,
at no expense to the City, secure and maintain, during the full term of the
license, general comprehensive liability insurance issued by one or more
companies authorized to do business in the State, which insurance shall be
subject to the approval of the Law Director, as to company, form and coverage,
and which insurance must fully protect the City from any and all claims and
risks in connection with any activity performed by the licensee and provide the
following minimum coverage:
      (1)   One million dollars ($1,000,000) per person, per occurrence;
      (2)   One million dollars ($1,000,000) annual aggregate.
   Said policy must specifically name the City as an additional insured party
thereunder in the following manner:
   The City of Lima is an additional insured for all coverages provided by this
policy of insurance and shall be fully and completely protected by this policy
and for any claim, suit, injury, death, damage or loss of any kind sustained by
any person, organization or corporation in connection with any activity upon or
use or occupancy of establishments regulated by
Chapter 818 of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Lima.
   The coverages provided by this policy to the City or any other named insured
shall not be terminated, reduced or otherwise changed in any respect without
providing at least thirty days prior written notice to the Director.
   (C)   The licensee shall deliver to the Director a copy of all policies
required under this section and all endorsements thereto or other evidence, to
the reasonable satisfaction of the Director, that the licensee has secured or
renewed and is maintaining insurance as required by this section.
   (D)   The procuring of the insurance required by this section shall not be
construed to limit the licensee's liability hereunder.
   (E)   The licensee shall provide for the prompt and efficient handling of
all claims for injury, death, damage or loss arising out of the acts or
omissions of the licensee. The licensee shall agree that all such claims,
whether processed by the licensee or its insurer, either directly or by means
of an agent, will be handled by a person with a permanent office within the
corporate limits of the City.
(Ord. 51-94.  Passed 5-23-94.)
818.19   AUTHORITY OF THE DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS.
   The Director is authorized to:
   (A)   Grant, renew, deny, suspend or revoke licenses according to the terms
of this chapter;
   (B)   Collect fees for the application or transfer process according to the
terms of this chapter;
   (C)   Promulgate and enforce any rules or regulations necessary to implement
the provisions or purposes of this chapter.
(Ord. 51-94.  Passed 5-23-94.)
818.99   PENALTY.
   (A)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter, for which no penalty is otherwise provided, is guilty of a misdemeanor
of the fourth degree for a first offense and shall be fined not more than two
hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not more than thirty days, or
both.  For any subsequent offense, such person shall be guilty of a misdemeanor
of the third degree and shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars
($500.00) or imprisoned not more than sixty days, or both.
   (B)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of
Section
818.10 shall be subject to the penalty provided in Section
802.99.
(Ord. 51-94.  Passed 5-23-94.)

CHAPTER 824
Frozen Desserts
824.01   Definition.
824.02   License Required.
824.03   Compliance with Other Law.
824.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Home solicitation sales - see Ohio R.C.1345.21 et seq.
   Frozen desserts - see Ohio R.C. 3717.51 et seq.
   Sale of goods and services within right of way of interstate and other State
highways - see Ohio R.C. 5515.07
   Littering - see GEN. OFF.
660.02
   Solicitors, peddlers and vendors - see B.R. & T. Ch.
848
824.01   DEFINITION.
   As used in this chapter, "frozen desserts" includes ice cream, frozen
custard, milk sherbet, ice or iced sherbet and imitation ice cream.
(Ord. 5-56. Passed 1-16-56.)
824.02   LICENSE REQUIRED.
   Any owner of a cart of other vehicle used in the business of selling frozen
desserts shall pay an annual license fee in the amount specified in Section
868.01 for each cart and in the amount specified in Section 868.01 for each
motorized vehicle used for the sale of such products.  The license issued shall
be affixed to such cart or other vehicle at all times.
(Ord. 161-91.  Passed 7-8-91; Ord. 204-17.  Passed 9-11-17.)
824.03   COMPLIANCE WITH OTHER LAW.
   In addition to compliance with this chapter, each licensee shall comply with
all applicable provisions of these Codified Ordinances and other ordinances and
with State law and the health regulations relating to the sale of frozen
desserts.
(Ord. 5-56. Passed 1-16-56.)
824.99   PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
802.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 828
Junk Dealers
828.01   Junk Dealer Defined.
828.02   License Required.
828.03   Application.
828.04   Issuance; Rejection.
828.05   Fee; Regulations.
828.06   Revocation; Suspension.
828.07   Display of License.
828.08   Display of Sign.
828.09   Inspection of Premises Prior to Issuance of License.
828.10   Change of Business Location.
828.11   Location of Business; Prohibited Operation.
828.12   Hours of Operation.
828.13   Arrangement of Stock.
828.14   Minimum Period for Retention of Articles.
828.15   Records.
828.16   Restrictions on Location of Business.
828.17   Enclosure of Premises.
828.18   Orderly Condition of Premises.
828.19   Periodic Inspection of Premises.
828.20   Dealing with Minors and Intoxicated Persons.
828.21   Removal of Flammable Substances from Tanks.
828.22   Open Storage of Combustible Material.
828.23   Fireproof Construction for Storage Buildings.
828.24   Daily Reports to Police.
828.25   Minimum Period for Destruction of Motor Vehicle Identity; Exception.
828.26   Motor Vehicles with Identification Marks Removed.
828.27   Compliance with State Law.
828.28   Reports to Police upon Demand.
828.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Secondhand dealers and junk yards - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4737
   Receiving stolen property - see GEN. OFF.
672.02
   Storage of flammable liquids and gases - see F.P.
1602.04 et seq.
828.01   JUNK DEALER DEFINED.
   As used in this chapter, "junk dealer" means any person who keeps, conducts
or maintains any building, structure, yard or place for keeping, storing or
piling, whether temporarily, irregularly or continually, or for buying, selling
or dealing in, at retail or wholesale, any old, used or secondhand materials or
property of any kind, including cloth, rags, mattresses, clothing, paper,
rubbish, bottles, rubber, iron, brass, copper or other metal, furniture, used
or abandoned vehicles, machinery, equipment, devices or other articles or
property, which, because of its condition, is practically useless for the
purpose for which it was originally made or intended and which is commonly
classed as junk.
(1956 Code Sec. 551.01)
828.02   LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall engage in the business of a junk dealer without first
obtaining and paying for a license to engage in such business as provided in
this chapter.
(1956 Code Sec. 551.02)
828.03   APPLICATION.
   Each applicant for a license to engage in the business of a junk dealer
shall file with the City License Clerk a written application upon a form
prepared and provided by the City, signed and sworn to by the applicant before
a notary public or other officer authorized to administer oaths in the City.
The application shall state:
   (A)   The name and residence address of the applicant, if an individual, or,
if a partnership, association, firm or corporation, the names and residence
addresses of the principal officers;
   (B)   The nature of the business to be conducted and the kind of materials
to be collected, bought, stored, kept, sold or otherwise handled; and
   (C)   The place where such business is to be conducted.
   Each application shall contain an agreement that the applicant accepts the
license, if granted, upon the condition that it may be suspended or revoked for
cause at any time by the Mayor as provided in Section
828.06. (1956 Code Sec. 551.03)
828.04   ISSUANCE; REJECTION.
   Upon the filing of the application, as provided in Section
828.03, and the payment by the applicant of the license fee required by Section
828.05, the Mayor, after investigation, shall issue to the applicant a license
to engage in the business of a junk dealer. No license shall be refused except
for noncompliance with the regulations governing junk dealers. The reason for a
refusal shall be specified by the Mayor in writing, and a copy thereof shall be
sent by registered mail, addressed to the applicant at the residence address
given in the application. No applicant to whom a license has been refused shall
make further application unless he can show that the reason for such rejection
no longer exists.
(1956 Code Sec. 551.04)
828.05   FEE; REGULATIONS.
   (A)   Each junk dealer shall pay an annual license fee in the amount
specified in Section 868.01, which fee shall apply only to one location.  Any
license issued hereunder shall expire on December 31 of the year in which
issued.  All licenses shall state clearly the location of the business, the
issuance date and expiration of the license, and the name and address of the
licensee.
   (B)   Whenever a license is lost or destroyed, without fault on the part of
the holder or his agent or employee, a replacement license under the original
application, shall be issued by the City License Clerk upon the filing of an
affidavit setting forth the facts and circumstances of the loss or destruction
and upon the payment of a fee specified in Section 868.01.
   (C)   The amount of the fees herein provided is declared to be commensurate
with the reasonable cost of enforcement of the regulations pertaining to such
business, together with the cost of issuing such licenses.
(Ord. 166-91. Passed 7-8-91; Ord. 205-17. Passed 9-11-17.)
828.06   REVOCATION; SUSPENSION.
   Upon the written complaint of any City official or resident to the City
License Clerk that any licensee has violated, or is violating, any of the
provisions of this chapter, the Mayor shall summon such licensee to appear
before him at the time specified in the summons, which time shall be not less
than five days after the date of the service thereof, to show cause why his
license should not be suspended or revoked. The Mayor shall proceed to hear the
matter. If he finds that the allegations of the complaint are correct, he shall
suspend or revoke the junk dealer's license.
   If the license is suspended, the suspension shall be for a period of not
less than thirty days and until the licensee has shown, to the satisfaction of
the Mayor, that the reason for the suspension no longer exists.
   When any license is so suspended or revoked, no refund of any unused portion
of the license fee shall be made. No license shall be granted to any person
whose license has been revoked within a period of one year from the date of
such revocation.
   Notice of suspension or revocation and the written reasons therefor shall be
served by the Mayor upon the licensee named in the application, by mailing the
same to the address given in the application and filing a copy thereof with the
City License Clerk.
   When any license is suspended or revoked, the licensee shall deliver such
license to the City License Clerk, who shall cancel or hold the same as the
Mayor may direct. No person whose license has been suspended or revoked
pursuant to this section shall engage in the business of a junk dealer during
the period of such suspension or revocation.
(1956 Code Sec. 551.06)
828.07   DISPLAY OF LICENSE.
   Each holder of a junk dealer's license shall, at all times, keep the license
posted, while in business, in a conspicuous place on the premises described in
the application for the license. No person shall post such license upon
premises other than the premises mentioned in the application or knowingly
deface or destroy such license.
(1956 Code Sec. 551.07)
828.08   DISPLAY OF SIGN.
   Each licensed junk dealer shall keep a sign on the outside and in front of
his place of business, on which sign shall be clearly set forth in conspicuous
letters his name and the words "Junk Dealer."
(1956 Code Sec. 551.08)
828.09   INSPECTION OF PREMISES PRIOR TO ISSUANCE OF LICENSE.
   Before any license is issued under this chapter, the City License Clerk
shall report the application to the Chief of Police, the Health Commissioner,
the Fire Chief and the Building Commissioner, who shall inspect, or cause to be
inspected, the location and structures proposed to be devoted to the business
of a junk dealer to determine whether they comply with all laws, ordinances,
rules and regulations applicable to such business. Such inspection shall be
made and a written report thereof filed with the City License Clerk within ten
days after the application for a license is made.
(1956 Code Sec. 551.09)
828.10   CHANGE OF BUSINESS LOCATION.
   No licensee shall move his place of business from the place designated in
the license without first securing a written permit from the Mayor and having
the same endorsed upon the license.
(1956 Code Sec. 551.10)
828.11   LOCATION OF BUSINESS; PROHIBITED OPERATION.
   No junk dealer shall carry on his business at or from any place other than
the place designated in the license therefor, nor shall such business be
carried on after the license has been suspended or revoked or has expired.
(1956 Code Sec. 551.11)
828.12   HOURS OF OPERATION.
   No junk dealer shall make any purchase from any person or receive any
article on Sunday or between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. on any
weekday.
(1956 Code Sec. 551.12)
828.13   ARRANGEMENT OF STOCK.
   The contents of the premises of each junk dealer shall be arranged in an
orderly manner, with all similar things located together and stored or piled in
such a manner as to facilitate and make possible inspection by the proper
authorities. The premises of each junk dealer shall be subject to inspection by
the proper City authorities at all reasonable times.
(1956 Code Sec. 551.13)
828.14   MINIMUM PERIOD FOR RETENTION OF ARTICLES.
   All articles received by any junk dealer in the course of his business shall
be retained for fifteen days before disposal to allow for inspection by the
proper City authorities. This section shall not apply to old rags, paper,
bottles or rubbish; any such property may be disposed of at any time within the
fifteen-day period, after forty-eight hours written notice to the Chief of
Police containing a description thereof.
(1956 Code Sec. 551.14)
828.15   RECORDS.
   Each junk dealer shall keep, in such form as the Chief of Police may
prescribe and legibly written in ink or indelible pencil, a daily record, in
the English language, of each article and material purchased, including an
accurate description of such article or material, the name and residence
address of the person from whom such article or material was purchased, the
name of the employer of such person, if any, the day and hour of the purchase
and the price paid.
   Such records shall be kept for a period of one year and shall, at all
reasonable times, be open to tile inspection of any police officer, the Mayor,
the Chief of Police, any magistrate or person duly authorized in writing for
such purpose by the Chief of Police or any magistrate, who shall exhibit such
authorization to the junk dealer, his agent or employee. No entry in such
records shall be changed, erased, obliterated or defaced.
   In the case of motor vehicles there shall be kept, in addition to the above-
mentioned record, a personal description of the person from whom the vehicle
was purchased and a complete description of the vehicle, including the trade
name, motor and manufacturer's number, style of body, model, color and license
number, if any.
   In the case of motor vehicle parts there shall be kept, in addition to the
abovementioned record, a personal description of the person from whom the part
was purchased and a complete description of the part, including the trade name,
if any, and the serial number or other identification mark.
(1956 Code Sec. 551.15)
828.16   RESTRICTION ON LOCATION OF BUSINESS.
   The business of a junk dealer shall be carried on only in districts duly
authorized for such use by the Zoning Code, and the conducting of such business
in any other district is expressly prohibited.
(1956 Code Sec. 551.16)
828.17   ENCLOSURE OF PREMISES.
   The premises upon which the business of a junk dealer is to be conducted
shall be enclosed by a screened fence not less than six feet in height. Such
enclosure shall be maintained in good condition at all times and shall not have
more than one opening on any public street. Such opening shall be more than
twenty feet wide at minimum, shall be equipped with a screened gate or door of
the same height as the fence and shall be kept securely closed at all times
when the premises are not open for business.
(1956 Code Sec. 551.17)  (Ord. 139-16.  Passed 6-20-16.)
828.18   ORDERLY CONDITION OF PREMISES.
   The premises upon and all structures in which the business of a junk dealer
is carried on shall be so situated and constructed that such business may be
carried on in a sanitary manner, shall contain no fire hazards and shall be
arranged so that thorough inspection may be made at any time by the proper
health, fire, building and police authorities.
(1956 Code Sec. 551.18)
828.19   PERIODIC INSPECTION OF PREMISES.
   The Mayor shall cause all premises used for the business of a junk dealer to
be inspected not less than once every fifteen days to determine whether any of
the provisions of this chapter is being violated. Inspections shall be made by
such person as the Mayor shall designate; such person shall make and file a
written report of each inspection with the City License Clerk setting forth:
   (A)   The name of the licensee;
   (B)   A description of the premises inspected;
   (C)   The hour and date of the inspection;
   (D)   A detailed statement of the condition of the premises; and
   (E)   Such other information as may be required by the Mayor.
   Such reports shall be open for inspection to all persons interested therein.
(1956 Code Sec. 551.19)
828.20   DEALING WITH MINORS AND INTOXICATED PERSONS.
   No junk dealer shall purchase or acquire from any person under the age of
eighteen years any junk, other than old rags, paper or bottles, without the
written consent of a parent or guardian of such minor. No items shall be
acquired from any intoxicated person.
(1956 Code Sec. 551.29)
828.21   REMOVAL OF FLAMMABLE SUBSTANCES FROM TANKS.
   No gasoline tanks or parts of automobiles in which gasoline is contained
shall be stored on the premises upon which the business of a junk dealer is
being conducted unless all gasoline, oil and other flammable substances have
been removed therefrom.
(1956 Code Sec. 551.21)
828.22   OPEN STORAGE OF COMBUSTIBLE MATERIAL.
   No cloth, rags, clothing, paper, rubbish or other combustible material of
any kind shall be kept, stored or piled in the open on the premises upon which
the business of junk dealer is being conducted.
(1956 Code Sec. 551.22)
828.23   FIREPROOF CONSTRUCTION FOR STORAGE BUILDINGS.
   No building or other structure shall be used for the business of a junk
dealer wherein is kept, stored or piled any combustible materials, unless such
building or structure is of fireproof construction.
(1956 Code Sec. 551.23)
828.24   DAILY REPORTS TO POLICE.
   It shall be the duty of every licensed junk dealer handling junk motor
vehicles or parts thereof to deliver, or cause to be delivered, to the Chief of
Police or his representative, every day except Sunday or a legal holiday,
before the hour of 12:00 noon, a copy of the records required by Section
828.15 and such other information as the Chief of Police may require relating
to the secondhand motor vehicles, parts and accessories acquired, wrecked or
left in his possession for sale, storage, remodeling or wreckage on the
preceding day or, if such day is a Sunday or a legal holiday, on the two
preceding days. All reports required by this section shall be made on blanks
prepared and furnished by the Chief of Police, and each report shall be signed
at the bottom by the licensee or his duly authorized representative. The Chief
of Police shall cause a record to be kept of all reports, showing the date and
time each report is received and the name and address of the licensee making
the report. Upon obtaining the written consent of the Chief of Police, any
licensee may dispense with making the required report to the Chief for any part
or accessory whose original value was not more than ten dollars ($10.00).
(1956 Code Sec. 551.24)
828.25   MINIMUM PERIOD FOR DESTRUCTION OF MOTOR VEHICLE IDENTITY; EXCEPTION.
   No licensee, acting either for himself or by or through is agent or
employee, shall wreck, tear down, paint or otherwise destroy the identity of,
dispose of or allow to be taken out of his possession any secondhand motor
vehicle, part or accessory purchased or otherwise acquired, or left for sale
with him, until forty-eight hours after the report provided for in Section
828.24 has been made to the Chief of Police. The Chief of Police may, after
proper report is made to him, grant a special written permit to a licensee
permitting a secondhand motor vehicle, part or accessory described in such
permit to be sold or disposed of and delivered to another when he has
investigated and determined that there is no question as to the ownership of
such vehicle, part or accessory.
(1956 Code Sec. 551.25)
828.26   MOTOR VEHICLES WITH IDENTIFICATION MARKS REMOVED.
   No person shall knowingly buy, sell, receive, dispose of, conceal or have in
his possession any motor vehicle, part or accessory from which the
manufacturer's serial number or any other number or identification mark has
been removed, defaced, covered, altered or destroyed for the purpose of
concealing or misrepresenting the identity of such vehicle, part of accessory.
Any person to whom is offered for sale, storage or wreckage ally motor vehicle,
part or accessory from which the manufacturer's serial number or any other
number or identification mark has been removed, defaced, covered, altered or
destroyed shall immediately notify the Chief of Police of such offer.
(1956 Code Sec. 551.26)
828.27   COMPLIANCE WITH STATE LAW.
   Each licensed junk dealer handling junk motor vehicles shall comply with the
laws of the State relating to the sale or transfer of used motor vehicles.
(1956 Code Sec. 551.27)
828.28   REPORTS TO POLICE UPON DEMAND.
   Each junk dealer, upon being served with a written notice to do so by a
member of the Police Department, shall make a report to the Chief of Police, on
blank forms to be furnished by the Police Department, giving an accurate
description of all goods, articles or things purchased or received by him in
the course of his business at the time and during the period specified in the
notice, stating the amount paid therefor and the name, residence and general
description of the person from whom such goods, articles or things were
acquired.
(1956 Code Sec. 551.28)
828.99   PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree and shall be fined not
more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not more than
thirty days, or both. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day
during or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues.
CHAPTER 830
Massage Establishments and Technicians
830.01   Policy and Definitions.
830.02   License Required.
830.03   Exemptions.
830.04   Application for Massage Establishment License; Fee.
830.05   Issuance or Denial of Establishment License; Effective Period.
830.06   Revocation or Suspension of Establishment License.
830.07   Application for Massage Technician License; Fee.
830.08   Issuance or Denial of Technician License; Effective Period.
830.09   Revocation or Suspension of Technician License.
830.10   Required Facilities.
830.11   Operating Requirements.
830.12   Responsibility of License Holders and Owners
830.13   Out-call Services.
830.14   Transfer of Licenses.
830.15   Rules and Regulations.
830.16   Application to Current Practices.
830.17   Nuisance.
830.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Spreading contagion - see GEN. OFF.
660.01
   Sex related offenses - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
666
830.01   POLICY; DEFINITIONS.
   (A)   It is hereby declared that the business of operating massage
establishments as defined herein is a business affecting the public health,
safety, and general welfare.
(Ord. 090-05. Passed 5-9-05.)
   (B)   For the purposes of enforcing this chapter, the following words are
defined and shall have the meaning ascribed to them as hereinafter set forth:
      (1)   "Employee" means any and all persons, other than the massage
technician, who render any service to the operator and who receive compensation
directly from the operator.
      (2)   "Massage" means any method of pressure on, friction against or
stroking, kneading, rubbing, tapping, pounding, vibrating or stimulating of the
external soft parts of the body with the hands or with the aid of any
mechanical or electrical apparatus or appliance, with or without such
supplementary aids as rubbing alcohol, liniments, antiseptics, oils, powder,
creams, lotions, ointments or other similar preparations commonly used in this
practice, for a purpose other than the treatment of disorders of the human
body.
      (3)   "Massage establishment" means any establishment having a fixed
placed of business where any person, firm, association or corporation engages
in, carries on, or permits to be engaged in or carried on, any of the
activities referred to in subsection (a) hereof for any consideration
whatsoever.
      (4)   "Massage technician" means any person who, for any consideration
whatsoever, engages in the practice of massage as defined in subsection (a)
hereof.
      (5)   "Operator" means the permit operator of a massage establishment.
      (6)   "Out-call massage service" means any business, the function of
which is to perform massages at a location designated by the customer or client
rather than at a massage establishment.
      (7)   "Person" means any individual, copartnership, firm, association,
joint stock company, corporation, or combination of individuals, of whatever
form or character.
      (8)   "Sexual or genital area" means the genitals, pubic area, buttocks,
anus or perineum of any person, or the vulva or breasts of a female.
(Ord. 66-92.  Passed 4-20-92.)
830.02   LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (A)   No person shall engage in, conduct or carry on, or permit to be
engaged in, conducted or carried on, in or upon any premises in the City, the
operation of a massage establishment, as herein defined, unless such massage
establishment shall be licensed under this chapter.
   (B)   No person shall engage in the business of, or be employed as, a
massage technician in the City unless he or she has obtained a license from the
City.
(Ord. 66-92.  Passed 4-20-92.)
830.03   EXEMPTIONS.
   (A)   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the following:
      (1)   Hospitals, nursing homes and public health centers;
      (2)   The offices of a person who is licensed or registered by the State
of Ohio Medical Board which are used while performing the licensed or
registered profession;
      (3)   A licensed barber shop, beauty salon, school of cosmetology or
barber school, while used to perform the licensed vocation;
      (4)   The offices of a licensed chiropractor or physical therapist while
used to perform the licensed profession.
   (B)   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the following:
      (1)   A person licensed or registered by the State of Ohio Medical Board
while performing the licensed or registered profession.
      (2)   A licensed cosmetologist, registered barber, registered barber
apprentice, licensed chiropractor, licensed practical nurse, registered nurse,
licensed physical therapist or licensed physical therapist assistant, while
performing the said profession or vocation.
      (3)   A person working under the direction or supervision of individuals
referred to in paragraphs (B)(1) and (2) hereof while performing the said
profession or vocation.
(Ord. 66-92.  Passed 4-20-92.)
830.04   APPLICATION FOR MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENT LICENSE; FEE.
   (A)   Application for a license to operate a massage establishment,
including a renewal license, shall be made pursuant to this chapter. Each
application shall include a filing fee in the amount specified in Section
868.01, which shall not be refundable.
   (B)   The application for a license to operate a massage establishment shall
set forth the exact nature of the massage to be administered, the proposed
place of business and the facilities therefor.
   (C)   In addition to the foregoing, the applicant for a license, including
any partner of a partnership and any officer or director of a corporate
applicant, shall furnish the following information:
      (1)   His or her name, address and social security number;
      (2)   A certified copy of the applicant's birth certificate, which
evidences that the applicant is at least eighteen years of age;
      (3)   All of the applicant's residential addresses for the past three
years;
      (4)   The applicant's physical description, including height, weight and
color of eyes and hair;
      (5)   The business, occupation or employment of the applicant for the
three years immediately preceding the date of the application;
      (6)   The business history of the applicant regarding previous licenses
obtained or refused from any governmental agency, including revocations and
suspensions and the reasons therefor;
      (7)   The applicant's criminal history, including the date, time and
place of convictions for all violations except traffic offenses;
      (8)   A set of fingerprints obtained by the Police Department and a
recent two-inch x two-inch color photograph of the applicant; and
      (9)   If the applicant is a corporation or a partner of a partnership
which is incorporated, the name of the corporation, which shall be set forth
exactly as it is shown in its articles of incorporation.
(Ord. 66-92.  Passed 4-20-92; Ord. 206-17.  Passed 9-11-17.)
830.05   ISSUANCE OR DENIAL OF ESTABLISHMENT LICENSE; EFFECTIVE PERIOD.
   (A)   The Mayor, pursuant to the terms of this chapter, shall issue the
license to maintain, operate or conduct a massage establishment to a designated
person for a specific location upon receipt of an application, unless the Mayor
finds:
      (1)   That the operation, as proposed by the applicant, if permitted,
would not be in compliance with applicable laws, including, but not limited to,
the building, health, planning, housing, zoning and fire codes of the City or
the State, as well as the provisions of this chapter;
      (2)   That the applicant and any other person who will be directly or
indirectly engaged in the management and operation of a massage establishment
has been convicted of any sex offense within the past five years, as defined by
Chapter 2907 of the Ohio Revised Code or
Chapter 666 of these Codified Ordinances, unless the applicant can demonstrate
that said conviction was for conduct that bears no reasonable relationship to
the applicant's fitness for a license; or
      (3)   That the application does not contain all the required information,
or that the application contains a material misrepresentation.
   (B)   A massage establishment license issued pursuant to this chapter shall
terminate on December 31 following the date of its issuance, unless subject to
suspension or revocation.
(Ord. 66-92.  Passed 4-20-92.)
830.06   REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF ESTABLISHMENT LICENSE.
   (A)   The Mayor shall notify the applicant of his intention to refuse to
issue or renew a massage establishment license or may revoke or suspend such
license when he finds that:
      (1)   A section of this chapter was violated upon the establishment
premises when the operator was at fault;
      (2)   A violation of the Ohio Revised Code or of these Codified
Ordinances was committed upon the establishment premises when the operator was
at fault;
      (3)   A material misrepresentation was made upon the application for a
massage establishment permit;
      (4)   A law enforcement officer or health inspector was refused
permission to inspect the premises or operation of the massage establishment
during the hours of operation;
      (5)   A person who is not a licensed massage technician has administered
a massage at the premises of the massage establishment.
   (B)   The issuance, renewal, denial, suspension or revocation of a massage
establishment license shall be made pursuant to the provisions of this chapter
and subject to the hearing requirements of Section
802.09 of these Codified Ordinances, unless a prior hearing is not feasible
because of an immediate threat to the health, safety or welfare of the
community.
(Ord. 66-92.  Passed 4-20-92.)
830.07   APPLICATION FOR MASSAGE TECHNICIAN LICENSE; FEE.
   (A)   Application for a massage technician license, as required by Section
830.02, including a renewal license, shall be made pursuant to the terms of
this chapter. Each application shall include a filing fee in the amount
specified in Section
868.01, which shall not be refundable.
   (B)   The application for a permit to operate as a massage technician shall
contain the following information:
      (1)   The applicant's name, residence address and social security number;
      (2)   A physical description of the applicant, setting forth the
applicant's weight, height, hair color and color of eyes;
      (3)   A recent two-inch by two-inch color photograph of the applicant and
a set of fingerprints obtained by the Police Department.
      (4)   A certified copy of the applicant's birth certificate, which
evidences that the applicant is at least eighteen years of age;
      (5)   The business, occupation and employment of the applicant for a
three-year period preceding the date of the application;
      (6)   The applicant's criminal history, including the date, time and
place of all convictions for all violations except traffic offenses; and,
      (7)   A statement that the massage technician has undergone annual
physical examinations performed by a licensed physician who has certified that
the massage technician continues to be free from communicable diseases.
(Ord. 66-92.  Passed 4-20-92; Ord. 207-17.  Passed 9-11-17.)
830.08   ISSUANCE OR DENIAL OF TECHNICIAN LICENSE; EFFECTIVE PERIOD.
   (A)   The Mayor, pursuant to this chapter, shall issue the license to engage
in the business of or to be employed as a massage technician in the City upon
receipt of an application therefor, unless the Mayor finds:
      (1)   That the applicant has been convicted of any sex offense, as
defined in Chapter 2907 of the Ohio Revised Code or
Chapter 666 of these Codified Ordinances, within the past five years, unless
the applicant can demonstrate that said conviction was for conduct that bears
no reasonable relationship to the applicant's fitness for a license; or
      (2)   That the application does not contain all the required information
or that the application contains material misrepresentations.
   (B)   A massage technician license issued pursuant to this chapter shall
terminate on December 31 in the year the license is issued, unless subject to
suspension or revocation. 
(Ord. 66-92.  Passed 4-20-92.)
830.09   REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF TECHNICIAN LICENSE.
   (A)   The Mayor shall notify the applicant of his intention to refuse to
issue or renew a massage technician license, or may revoke or suspend such a
license, when he finds any of the following:
      (1)   The massage technician has been convicted of any sex offense, as
defined in Chapter 2907 of the Ohio Revised Code or Section 666 of these
Codified Ordinances, within the past five years, unless the applicant can
demonstrate that said conviction was for conduct that bears no reasonable
relationship to the applicant's fitness for a license.
      (2)   The massage technician violated any of the provisions of this
chapter.
   (B)   The issuance, renewal, denial, suspension or revocation of a massage
technician license shall be pursuant to the provisions of this chapter and
subject to the hearing requirements of Section
802.09 of these Codified Ordinances, unless a prior hearing is not feasible
because of an immediate threat to the health, safety or welfare of the
community.
(Ord. 66-92.  Passed 4-20-92.)
830.10   REQUIRED FACILITIES.
   No license to conduct a massage establishment shall be issued, renewed or
continued unless an inspection discloses that the establishment complies with
each of the following minimum requirements:
   (A)   A readable sign shall be displayed at the main entrance, identifying
the establishment as a massage establishment.  Such signs shall be in
compliance with these Codified Ordinances;
   (B)   Adequate equipment for disinfecting and sterilizing any instruments
used for massage is provided;
   (C)   Hot and cold running water is provided;
   (D)   Closed cabinets are utilized for the storage of clean linen;
   (E)   Adequate dressing and toilet facilities are provided to patrons;
   (F)   All walls, ceilings, floors, steam or vapor rooms and all other
physical facilities for the establishment are kept in good repair and
maintained in a clean and sanitary condition;
   (G)   Clean and sanitary towels and linen are provided for patrons receiving
massage services; no common use of towels or linen shall be permitted; and
   (H)   Doors to rooms within the massage establishment that are utilized to
perform massages are not capable of being secured from the inside.
(Ord. 66-92.  Passed 4-20-92.)
830.11   OPERATING REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   No license to conduct a massage establishment or to engage in the
business of, or to be, a massage technician shall be issued, renewed or
continued unless each of the following provisions is complied with by the
massage establishment and/or massage technician:
      (1)   No massage technician shall administer a massage upon another
person of the opposite gender.
      (2)   No massage technician shall administer a massage unless he or she
is completely clothed in clean non-transparent garments at all times. The term
"completely clothed" shall mean having on the upper portion of the body
undergarments and either a blouse or shirt which covers all the upper body
except the arms, and on the lower body undergarments plus either pants, a
skirt, a dress or similar such clothing which shall cover the area from the
waist to a point at least two inches above the knee;
      (3)   The massage patron's private parts shall be covered by a towel,
cloth or undergarments when in the presence of a massage technician or massage
establishment employee;
      (4)   A massage technician and massage establishment shall display their
license in a conspicuous place where the massage is being administered;
      (5)   The massage establishment facilities shall be subject to inspection
by law enforcement officers or health inspectors during working or operating
hours to assure compliance with the provisions of this chapter;
      (6)   A massage technician shall not fondle, touch or massage the sexual
or genital area of any patron;
      (7)   A massage establishment operator shall provide the names of all
employees and massage technicians working for the establishment to the City
License Clerk within two days of the date the individual is employed;
      (8)   Every person or entity operating a massage establishment under the
provisions of this chapter shall maintain a record of the date and hour of each
massage, the name and address of the patron, and the name of the massage
technician administering such massage.  Such records shall be maintained on the
premises of the massage establishment.  Such records shall be open to
inspection and copying by city officials responsible for the enforcement of the
provisions of this chapter or
Chapter 880 of the Codified Ordinances of Lima.  Such records shall be
maintained for a period of two years.
      (9)   Every holder of a license for a massage establishment shall cause
to be displayed in a conspicuous place, readily seen by persons entering the
premises, a sign listing the services provided by the establishment and the
cost of such services.  No service shall be rendered which is not so listed. 
The sign shall prominently include the statement that massage technicians are
not permitted to give massages to persons of the opposite gender.
      (10)   Massage establishment shall not be open for business except
between the hours of 9 a.m. and 9 p.m., Sunday through Saturday.
      (11)   No massage establishment shall be equipped with any device or
mechanism that is designed, intended, or used as an internal warning or
notification system, and no person shall use any such device or mechanism for
alerting persons in other portions of the establishment or building.
      (12)   No one-way, mirrored, film-covered, or otherwise opaque glass
shall be installed in any massage establishment.
      (13)   A massage establishment license holder must also obtain and
maintain a Vendor’s License.
      (14)   At all times during the operation of the establishment, it shall
be open for inspection by an authorized individual from the Police Department,
City License & Permit Office, or from the County Health Department.
   (B)   Every massage establishment operator shall provide proof of liability
insurance in the minimum amount of $250,000.00 per occurrence for bodily injury
which may occur on the premises.  Such insurance shall be provided by a company
authorized to do business as an insurance company in the State of Ohio.  The
policy shall require that the City be notified in the case of any cancellation
or non-renewal.
   (C)   Every massage establishment operator shall be required to post a bond
with the City in the amount of $3,000.00, in the form of cash or a form of
credit or guaranty as approved by the Mayor, to secure the performance and
compliance of the provisions of this chapter.  The Mayor may order such bond to
be forfeited, in full or in part, upon the filing of a violation of this
chapter.
   (D)   No massage technician or massage establishment operator shall violate
a provision of this section.
(Ord. 66-92.  Passed 4-20-92; Ord. 090-05. Passed 5-9-05.)
830.12   RESPONSIBILITY OF LICENSE HOLDERS AND OWNERS.
   (A)   The owner of the premises where a massage establishment is located
shall have the responsibility to ensure that a valid massage establishment
license has been issued for such premises and remains in full force and effect
during the operation of such premises as a massage establishment.  The owner
shall also have the responsibility to ensure that each person employed in the
establishment as a massage technician has a valid license under this chapter.
   (B)   Every holder of a license for a massage establishment shall have the
responsibility to ensure that each person employed in the establishment as  a
massage technician has a valid license under this chapter.
   (C)   Every holder of a license for a massage establishment shall exercise
close supervision over the acts of massage technicians, and other persons on
the premises.  The acts of massage technicians or other employees when in
violation of any provision of this chapter may constitute grounds for
revocation or suspension of the massage establishment license.
   (D)   Every owner who leases, rents, or otherwise allows his property to be
utilized as a massage establishment shall require as a condition of such use
that the premises be used in compliance with the provisions of this Chapter.  A
violation of this Chapter constitutes a public nuisance, and if a violation of
this Chapter occurs and when notified by the City the owner shall be
responsible for taking all available legal action to evict or otherwise prevent
the continued operation of the massage establishment business on the owner’s
property.
   (E)   An owner’s property may be found to be a public nuisance and subject
to abatement, if a violation of this Chapter occurs thereon, regardless of the
owner’s actual knowledge of or participation in such violation, under section
830.17.
(Ord. 090-05. Passed 5-9-05.)
830.13   OUT-CALL SERVICES.
   No massage technician or massage establishment shall provide out-call
massage services which are not in compliance with the provisions of this
chapter.
(Ord. 66-92.  Passed 4-20-92.)
830.14   TRANSFER OF LICENSES.
   (A)   No license issued under this chapter shall be transferable to another
person or location without the express written authorization of the Mayor.
   (B)   The change of location of a massage establishment shall require the
submission of a new application and the issuance of a new license.
(Ord. 66-92.  Passed 4-20-92.)
830.15   RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Mayor may make and enforce reasonable rules and regulations to carry out
the intent of this chapter.
(Ord. 66-92.  Passed 4-20-92.)
830.16   APPLICATION TO CURRENT PRACTICES.
   Any person who is actually engaged as a massage technician or an operator of
a massage establishment upon the effective date of this chapter shall have
sixty days from that date to comply with the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 090-05. Passed 5-9-05.)
830.17   NUISANCE.
   A violation of any provision of this chapter by a licensee is hereby
determined to be a public nuisance, and the premises where the massage
establishment is located shall be subject to abatement under Ohio R.C. 715.44,
the Charter or any applicable provision of the Ordinances of the City of Lima,
or any other law of the State of Ohio.
(Ord. 090-05. Passed 5-9-05.)
830.99   PENALTY.
   (A)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree and shall be fined not
more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not more than
thirty days, or both. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day
during or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues.
   (B)   The Mayor may also assess a civil penalty not to exceed the amount of
$1,000.00 per violation of any provision of this chapter, which may be
collected against the bond required in section
830.11(C).  A separate violation shall be deemed committed each day during or
on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues.
(Ord. 090-05. Passed 5-9-05.)
CHAPTER 832
Mechanical Amusement Devices
832.01   Definitions.
832.02   License Required.
832.03   Application.
832.04   Issuance.
832.05   Fees; Transfer of Location.
832.06   Hours or Operation.
832.07   Operation by Minors.
832.08   Prizes Prohibited; Seizure of Unlawful Devices.
832.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   State license to sell cigarettes required - see Ohio R.C. 5743.15
   Gambling - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
630
   Tampering with coin machines - see GEN. OFF.
672.06
   Making or using slugs - see GEN. OFF.
672.15
   Loitering - see GEN. OFF.
648.11
   Disorderly houses; patronizing - see GEN. OFF.
648.18
832.01   DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (A)   "Mechanical amusement device" means any machine or device which, as a
result of the deposit of a coin, by and through an automatic or mechanical
operation, affords amusement, whether or not accompanied by the automatic
vending of any mints, candies, confections, pictures or other commodities, and
which, by means of such operation, registers a score or indicates the results
of such operation, whether or not accompanied by the return of tokens, slugs or
any other evidence of the result of such operation.
   (B)   "Mechanical amusement device arcade" means any place containing three
or more mechanical amusement devices wherein the operation of such devices
constitutes the principal business carried on at such place.
(1956 Code Sec. 523.01)
832.02   LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person, as owner, lessee or agent for another, shall keep, exhibit,
operate or permit to be kept, exhibited or operated for gain any mechanical
amusement device arcade without first obtaining a license to do so and paying
the license fee required in Section
832.05.
(1956 Code Sec. 523.03)
832.03   APPLICATION.
   Application for a license for a mechanical amusement device arcade shall be
made to the City License Clerk upon forms provided by the City for that purpose
at least forty-eight hours prior to the date upon which the license is to take
effect. The application shall set forth the name and the residence and business
addresses of the applicant and operator of the mechanical amusement device
arcade, the proposed location of the arcade and an accurate and complete
description of each mechanical amusement device to be contained therein.
(1956 Code Sec. 523.04)
832.04   ISSUANCE.
   All licenses shall be granted by the Mayor after payment by the applicant of
the license fee required in Section
832.05. Before the application is acted upon by the Mayor, he may require the
approval thereof by the Chief of Police, the Fire Chief and the City Engineer.
(1956 Code Sec. 523.05)
832.05   FEES; TRANSFER OF LOCATION.
   (A)   All license fees for mechanical amusement device arcades shall be paid
in full to the City License Clerk at or before the issuance of the license.
Except as otherwise provided by law, such license fee shall be deposited in the
City Treasury to the credit of the General Fund. The annual fee for each
mechanical amusement device arcade shall be the amount provided in Section
868.01.  For all licenses granted between January 1 and July 1, the full annual
fee shall be paid. For all licenses granted between July 1 and January 1, one-
half the annual fee shall be paid. All licenses shall expire at 12:00 midnight
on December 31st of each year. No refund or rebate shall be made to a licensee
retiring from business, and no license shall be sold or transferred to a new
owner or proprietor.
   (B)   Any such license granted shall be valid only for the location
specified in the application therefor. If the licensee thereafter desires to
change the location of such mechanical amusement device arcade, he may do so
upon an application to the City License Clerk and the payment of a transfer fee
specified in Section 868.01.  The request for transfer of location shall be
approved by the Mayor.
(Ord. 167-91. Passed 7-8-91; Ord. 243-17. Passed 10-9-17.)
832.06   HOURS OF OPERATION.
   No person, whether or not he is the holder of a license for a mechanical
amusement device arcade, shall keep, exhibit, operate or permit to be kept,
exhibited or operated for gain any mechanical amusement device between the
hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. On each weekday or between the hours of
12:00 midnight and 12:00 noon on Sunday.
(1956 Code Sec. 523.07)
832.07   OPERATION BY MINORS.
   No person, either as owner, lessee, exhibitor or agent for another, whether
or not he is a holder of a mechanical amusement device arcade license, shall
permit the operation of a mechanical amusement device by any minor under the
age of sixteen years unless such minor is accompanied by his parent, guardian
or other adult person having charge of him.
(1956 Code Sec. 523.08)
832.08   PRIZES PROHIBITED; SEIZURE OF UNLAWFUL DEVICES.
   No person shall offer or give rewards or prizes of any kind based upon the
score obtained or the result of the operation of any mechanical amusement
device, redeem for cash, merchandise or other thing of value any token, slug or
other evidence of the result of the operation of such device; or replay or
permit to be replayed such device by means of any token, slug or other evidence
of the result of the operation of such device. Any mechanical amusement device
which is knowingly permitted to be used in violation of this section by the
licensee or by the exhibitor thereof shall be subject to immediate seizure by
any law enforcement officer of the City.
(1956 Code Sec. 523.09)
832.99   PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
802.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 836
Pawnbrokers
836.01   Definition.
836.02   Reports to Police Department; Fee.
836.03   Records.
836.04   Minimum Period for Holding Purchased Property.
836.05   Certain Purchases Prohibited.
836.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Pawnbrokers - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4727
   Receiving stolen property - see GEN. OFF.
672.02
836.01   DEFINITION.
   As used in this chapter, "pawnbroker" means any person, firm, partnership,
association or corporation engaged in the business of lending money on deposit
or pledges of personal property or other valuable things, other than securities
or printed evidence of indebtedness, in the business of purchasing personal
property, choses in action or other valuable things and selling or agreeing to
sell the same back to the seller at a price other than the original price of
purchase or in the business of purchasing personal property other than
household furniture, automobiles or junk.
(Ord. 129-74. Passed 5-13-74.)
836.02   REPORTS TO POLICE DEPARTMENT; FEE.
   (A)   Each pawnbroker shall, before 12:00 noon on every business day, report
to the Chief of Police, on forms to be furnished by the Police Department, a
description of all articles received by him by pledge or sale on the business
day immediately preceding, together with the number of the ticket issued and
the amount loaned or advanced thereon.
   (B)   For services provided by the Police Department in keeping such
reports, each pawnbroker shall pay an annual fee in the amount specified in
Section
868.01.
(Ord. 168-91.  Passed 7-8-91; Ord. 208-17.  Passed 9-11-17.)
836.03   RECORDS.
   Each pawnbroker shall keep and use such books and forms as shall be approved
by the Chief of the State Division of Securities, in which shall be legibly
written in the English language, at the time each purchase or loan is made, an
accurate description of the goods, articles or things deposited, the time of
pledging or selling the same, the amount of money loaned thereon or paid
therefor, the rate of interest and charges to be paid on such loan, the time
within which such pawn is to be redeemed, the amount of any repurchase price
and the name, age, place of residence and a short description of the person of
the pledger or seller. When any watch is pledged is sold, the pawnbroker shall
also write in such book the number of the movement, the number of the case and
the name of the maker; when any jewelry or gold or silver articles of any kind
are pledged or sold, he shall write in such book all identifying letters or
marks inscribed thereon. Such book shall at all times be open to the inspection
of the Chief of Police, a police officer designated by him, or the Mayor. Upon
demand of any of such persons, the pawnbroker shall produce and show any
article thus listed and described which is in his possession.
   No pawnbroker shall purchase or receive in pawn any article without first
obtaining from the person wishing to sell or pawn such article proper
identification, giving a physical description and the place of residence of
such person. The pawnbroker shall note on his report the type of identification
presented and any identifying numbers appearing thereon.
(Ord. 129-74. Passed 5-13-74.)
836.04   MINIMUM PERIOD FOR HOLDING PURCHASED PROPERTY.
   No pawnbroker who purchases any item of personal property shall sell,
transfer, trade, barter, exchange or otherwise dispose of such article of
personal property, for a minimum period of two weeks from the date he acquired
such article.
(Ord. 129-74. Passed 5-13-74.)
836.05   CERTAIN PURCHASES PROHIBITED.
   No pawnbroker, his agent, employee, associate or other person on the
premises of any pawnbroker shall receive any pledge or purchase any articles
from any minor, from any person who is at the time intoxicated, from any known
habitual drunkard or from any person who is known or believed by such person to
be a thief, an associate of a thief or a receiver of stolen property.
(Ord. 129-74. Passed 5-13-74.)
836.99   PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter, for a first offense,
is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree and shall be fined not more
than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not more than thirty
days, or both; for a second or subsequent offense, such person is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the third degree and shall be fined not more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned not more than sixty days, or both.
CHAPTER 838
Photographers

838.01   DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (A)   "Studio photographer" means any person maintaining a studio within the
City for the purpose of taking photographs therein, for a consideration,
personally or through his agents or employees, and any person maintaining in
any one established place within the City complete studio equipment for the
taking of photographs, for a consideration, including all finishing processes,
whether such photographs are taken inside or outside of such place.
   (B)   "Itinerant photographer" means any person, his agent or employee, who
solicits orders for photographs, photographic enlargements or photographic
reproductions, but who does not maintain regularly and permanently a bona fide
studio in the City for the taking, enlargement or reproduction of pictures or
photographs.
(1956 Code Sec. 563.01)

solicit orders therefor upon the public streets or sidewalks of the City.
(1956 Code Sec. 563.07)
