   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
802.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 840
EMERGENCY AND MEDICAL TRANSPORT SERVICES
840.01   Definitions.
840.02   Licenses Required.
840.03   Emergency Medical Service Organization License; Application;
Standards.
840.04   Ambulance Licenses; Standards.
840.05   Ambulance Equipment.
840.06   Licenses for Drivers, Attendants and Attendant- drivers; Application;
Fee.
840.07   Standards for Drivers, Attendants and Attendant- Drivers.
840.08   Liability Insurance Required.
840.09   Duties of Inspection Officer.
840.10   Duties of License Officer; Mayor
840.11   License Renewal.
840.12   License Revocation and Suspension.
840.13   Reports and Inspections.
840.14   Registration Required.
840.15   Registration Form; Fee.
840.16   Emergency Calls; 911 Calls
840.99   Penalty.
840.01   DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Ambulance" means any motor vehicle or air craft that is specially
designed, constructed or modified and equipped and is intended to be used to
provide basic life support, intermediate life support, advanced life support,
or mobile intensive care unit services and transportation upon the streets  or
highway of persons who are seriously ill, injured, wounded, or otherwise
incapacitated or helpless.
   (b)   “Ambulette” means a motor vehicle that is specifically designed,
constructed, or modified and equipped and is intended to be used to provide
transportation upon the streets or highways of this state of persons who
require use of a wheelchair.
   (c)   "Attendant" means a State of Ohio certified emergency medical
technician (EMT) or State of Ohio certified emergency medical technician -
Basic (EMT-B) or State of Ohio certified emergency medical technician -
Intermediate (EMT-I) or State of Ohio certified emergency medical technician
paramedic (EMT-P) who is responsible for the operation of an ambulance and the
care of the patients, whether or not the attendant also serves as driver (See
Ohio R.C. 4765.01(B), (C), (D)).
   (d)   "Attendant-driver" means a person who is licensed as an attendant and
a driver.
   (e)   “Basic Medical Transport” means an unmodified motor vehicle used to
transport persons to medical service providers for non-emergency healthcare
services.
   (f)   "Code number 1 call"  means a call for nonemergency medical
assistance.
   (g)   "Code number 3 call" means a call for emergency medical assistance.
   (h)   "Driver" means an individual who is licensed by the State of Ohio to
drive or pilot an ambulance and who is at least a State of Ohio certified
emergency medical technician (EMT) at all times.
   (i)   "Emergency medical service"  means any of the services described in
Ohio R.C. 4765.35, 4765.37, 4765.38, and 4765.39, that are performed by first
responders, emergency medical technicians-basic, emergency medical technicians-
intermediate, and paramedics. "Emergency medical service" includes such
services performed before or during any transport of a patient, including
transports between hospitals and transports to and from helicopters.
   (j)   "Emergency Medical Service Organization (EMSO)"  means any person,
organization or entity using first responders, EMTs-basic, EMTs-I, or
paramedics, or a combination of first responders, EMTs-basic, EMTs-I, and
paramedics, to provide emergency and non-emergency medical services. This
includes such services performed before or during any transport of a patient,
including transports between hospitals and transports to and from helicopters
and nursing home or assisted living facilities.
   (k)   "Inspection Officer" means the person designated by the Fire Chief to
perform ambulance and Emergency Medical Service Organization inspections under
this chapter.
   (l)   "License Officer" means the person designated by the Mayor to
administer the licensing requirements under this chapter.
   (m)   (1)   "Nonemergency Medical Transport Organization” means a person
that does both of the following:
         (A)   Provides services, not otherwise defined as an emergency medical
service, to the public on a regular basis for the purpose of transporting
individuals to receive health care services; and,
         (B)   Provides the services for a fee, regardless of whether the fee
is paid by the person being transported, a third party payor, as defined in
Ohio Revised Code Section 3702.51, or any other person or governmental entity.
       (2)   “Nonemergency Medical Transport Organization” does not include a
health care facility, as defined in Ohio Revised Code Section 1751.01, that
provides  ambulance or ambulette services only to patients of that facility. 
   (n)   "Patient" means any individual who as a result of illness or injury
needs medical attention, whose physical or mental condition is such that there
is imminent danger of loss of life or significant health impairment, who may be
otherwise incapacitated or helpless as a result of physical or mental
conditions, or whose physical condition requires the use of a wheel chair.  For
purposes of nonemergency medical transportation a patient is any person seeking
medical attention from a health care provider. 
   (o)   "Person" means any individual, firm, partnership, association,
corporation, company, entity, group of individuals acting together for a common
purpose, organization or agency of any kind.
   (p)   “Registration Officer” means the person designated by the Mayor to
administer the registration requirements under this code. 
(Ord. 223-08. Passed 12-15-08.)
840.02   LICENSES REQUIRED.
   (A)   No person, either as owner, agent or otherwise, shall furnish,
operate, conduct, maintain, advertise or otherwise be engaged in or profess to
be engaged in the business or service of the transportation of patients upon
the streets, alleys or other public ways or places of the City unless the
person holds a currently valid Emergency Medical Service Organization license.
   (B)   No ambulance shall be operated for ambulance purposes, and no
individual shall drive, attend or permit it to be operated for such purposes,
on the streets, alleys or any public way or place of the City, unless such
ambulance has been duly licensed pursuant to this Chapter.
   (C)   No ambulance shall be operated for ambulance purposes, and no
individual shall drive, attend or permit it to be operated for such purposes,
on the streets, alleys or any public way or place of the City, unless (1) it is
operated by a driver or attendant-driver licensed under this Chapter; (2)  it
has sufficient personnel to handle a 200-pound patient; and (3) otherwise
complies with all standards for ambulances in this Chapter.
   (D)   No licenses shall be required under this Chapter for an ambulance, or
for the driver, attendant or attendant-driver of an ambulance, which:
      (1)    Is rendering assistance to licensed ambulances in the case of a
major catastrophe or emergency with which the licensed ambulances of the City
are insufficient or unable to cope; or
   (2)   Is operated from a location or headquarters outside the City in order
to transport patients who are picked up beyond the limits of the City to
locations within the City. However, no such ambulance shall be used to pick up
patients within the City for transportation to locations within the City unless
the driver, attendant, attendant-driver and person subject to the provisions of
subsection (A) hereof with respect to such ambulance hold currently valid
licenses issued pursuant to this chapter.
   (E)   No license issued under this Chapter shall be assignable or
transferable.
(Ord. 064-00. Passed 3-27-00.)
840.03   EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICE ORGANIZATION LICENSE; APPLICATION;
STANDARDS.
   (a)   Applications for an emergency medical service organization (EMSO)
license shall be made upon such forms as may be prepared or prescribed by the
License Officer and shall contain at least the following information:
      (1)   The names, social security numbers, dates of birth, and addresses
of the owner(s) of the EMSO;
      (2)   The corporate, trade or other fictitious name, if any, under which
the EMSO does business or proposes to do business;
      (3)   The experience of the EMSO in providing 911 Emergency response
services, primary advanced life support service, and the transportation and
care of patients;
      (4)   A description of the ambulances, including the make, model, year of
manufacture, motor and chassis number, the current State or Federal Aviation
Agency license number, the mileage and length of time the ambulances have been
in use, and a description and photograph of the color scheme, insignia, name,
monogram or other distinguishing characteristics to be used to designate the
ambulances;
      (5)   The location and a description of the place or places from which
the EMSO is intended to operate;
      (6)   Such other information as the License Officer shall deem necessary
to administer or effectuate the purposes of this chapter;
      (7)   An accompanying fee as specified in Section
868.01.
   (b)   To receive and maintain a license, each EMSO must meet all of the
following requirements:
      (1)   It shall have at least two or more fully equipped advanced life
support, paramedic-manned, licensed ambulances, staffed twenty-four hours a
day, seven days a week, 365 days a year.
      (2)   It shall also have one or more fully equipped advanced life support
ambulance(s) stationed within the City limits that can be placed into service
in the event one of the two primary ambulances are temporarily out of service.
      (3)   It shall have two primary ambulances with no greater than 250,000
vehicle miles.
      (4)   It shall have no ambulance in service with over 350,000 vehicle
miles.
      (5)   It shall have adequate facilities for housing ambulance vehicles in
a climate- controlled environment and shall have clean and suitable facilities
for all office and field personnel.  The location of the place or places from
which the EMSO is intended to operate shall be centrally located  within the
City.
      (6)   It shall have certified emergency medical dispatchers (EMD) or EMT
dispatchers and facilities continuously and effectively staffed twenty-four
hours a day, seven days a week, 365 days a year.
      (7)   It shall respond to emergency code number three calls within a
maximum of nine minutes after accepting such a call and respond to non-
emergency code number one calls within a maximum of fifteen minutes after
accepting such a call, with compliance rate of at least ninety-five percent
over any three-month period for each type of call.
      (8)   It shall have a medical director from either Lima Memorial Hospital
or St. Rita's Medical Center in Lima, who is a board certified physician and
possesses at least five years experience in emergency medicine.
      (9)   It shall have and maintain proof of insurance as required in this
chapter.
   (c)   An EMSO shall notify the License Officer of any change in personnel
within two working days of the change.
(Ord. 223-08. Passed 12-15-08; Ord. 218-18. Passed 9-24-18.)
840.04   AMBULANCE LICENSES; STANDARDS.
   (a)   Applications for an ambulance license shall be made upon such forms as
may be prepared or prescribed by the License Officer and shall contain such
information as the License Officer shall deem necessary to administer or
effectuate the purposes of this chapter; and shall contain at least the
following information: a description of the ambulance, including the make,
model, year of manufacture, motor and chassis number, the current State or
Federal Aviation Agency license number, the mileage and length of time the
ambulance has been in use, and a description and photograph of the color
scheme, insignia, name, monogram or other distinguishing characteristics to be
used to designate the ambulance.  The applicant shall provide the License
Officer a copy of their current State Board of Emergency Medical, Fire, and
Transportation Services Ambulance License and a copy of their most recent Ohio
Department of Public Safety, Division of  Emergency Medical Services, periodic
mechanical safety report for each ambulance to be licensed.  The mechanical
safety report must have been completed within the previous six calender
months.  Applicants are exempt from having to provide a mechanical report on
any ambulance that is less than one year old.  A fee in the amount specified in
Section
868.01 shall accompany the application for each license.
   (b)   In addition, to receive and maintain a license, each ambulance shall,
at all times when in use as such:
      (1)   Be suitable for the transportation of patients with regard to
health, sanitation and safety and be maintained in suitable premises;
      (2)   Contain equipment conforming to the standards, requirements and
regulations provided for in this chapter, which equipment shall be in proper
and good condition for such use;
      (3)   Comply with all applicable laws and local ordinances relating to
health, sanitation and safety;
      (4)   Be equipped with such lights, sirens, special markings and other
equipment or apparatus as may be required by State law or regulation;
      (5)   Have an insignia, logo, and/or color scheme as approved by the
License Officer to designate it as an ambulance;
      (6)   Be equipped with original equipment manufactured-approved safety
belts and harnesses for the driver and for a passenger in the front seat which
shall be worn pursuant to State and local laws;
      (7)   Be equipped to provide advanced life support with a minimum of one
EMT, EMT-B, or EMT-I and one paramedic;
      (8)   Be covered by and maintain proof of insurance as required in this
chapter.
   (c)   Any change in the ownership of an ambulance licensed under this
chapter shall terminate the license and shall require a new application.
(Ord. 223-08. Passed 12-15-08; Ord. 219-18. Passed 9-24-18.)
840.05   AMBULANCE EQUIPMENT.
   (A)   Required equipment in each ambulance shall include, at all times when
the ambulance is in use as such, equipment adequate, in the judgment of the
Inspection Officer, for light rescue, light protected extrication, dressing
wounds, splinting fractures, controlling hemorrhage, providing oxygen,
assisting respiration, monitoring blood pressure, pulse and respiration rates,
and assisting in emergency childbirth and management of the mentally deranged,
as well as a heart monitor, a defibrillator and drugboxes with appropriate
drugs.  Necessary equipment shall also include endotracheal intubation
equipment, pulse oximetry, blood glucose monitoring equipment, pediatric
advance life support equipment, vacuum splints, automatic resuscitators,
external cardiac pacer, and cellular phones.
   (B)   All ambulance vehicles shall display a current State of Ohio vehicle
inspection sticker.
   (C)   The Inspection Officer is hereby authorized and directed to promulgate
regulations, after public notice and opportunity for public hearing, and upon
approval by the Mayor, to implement the standards provided in this section as
to required equipment in ambulances. In determining the adequacy of equipment,
the Inspection Officer shall take into consideration the current list of
essential equipment for ambulances adopted by the American College of Emergency
Physicians or its duly authorized Committee on Trauma. Each licensee of an
ambulance shall comply with such regulations as may be promulgated by the
Inspection Officer and shall maintain in each such ambulance, at all times when
it is in use as such, all such equipment as may be prescribed by the Inspection
Officer.
   (D)   The EMSO must be capable of providing telephonic and radio
communication with the Fire Department and area hospitals at all times and the
EMSO shall report when such communication equipment is out of service and when
such communication system is back in service.
(Ord. 064-00. Passed 3-27-00.)
840.06   LICENSES FOR DRIVERS, ATTENDANTS AND ATTENDANT-DRIVERS; APPLICATION;
FEE.
   An application for a driver's, attendant's, or attendant-driver's license
shall be made upon such forms as may be prepared or prescribed by the License
Officer and shall contain:
   (A)   The applicant's full name, date of birth, social security number,
current residence, places of residence for the past five years and the length
of time the applicant has resided in the City;
   (B)   The applicant's age, height and color of eyes and hair;
   (C)   A statement as to whether or not the applicant has ever been convicted
of a felony or misdemeanor (including traffic offenses) and, if so, when, where
and for what cause;
   (D)   The applicant's training and experience in the transportation and care
of patients, a statement as to whether or not the applicant has previously been
licensed as a driver, chauffeur, attendant or attendant-driver and, if so,
when, where, whether or not the applicant's license has ever been revoked or
suspended in any jurisdiction, and if so for what cause;
   (E)   Affidavits of good character from two reputable citizens of the United
States and residents of the State who have personally known the applicant and
observed the applicant's conduct during five years prior to the date of
application;
   (F)   Two recent photographs of the applicant of a size designated by the
License Officer, one of which shall be attached by the License Officer to the
license;
   (G)   The applicant's work record for five years prior to the date of
application;
   (H)   Such other information as the License Officer deems reasonably
necessary to determine the applicant's suitability or ability to perform the
functions required by a holder of a license issued hereunder; and,
   (I)   An accompanying license fee in an amount as specified in Section
868.01.
(Ord. 223-08. Passed 12-15-08; Ord. 209-17. Passed 9-11-17.)
840.07   STANDARDS FOR DRIVERS, ATTENDANTS AND ATTENDANT-DRIVERS.
   (A)   All ambulance personnel must wear a name tag identifying them and
their level of certification over their right shirt pocket while on duty.
   (B)   Emergency medical technicians at all levels of certification,
ambulance drivers, attendant-drivers and attendants are subject to the
provisions in the Ohio Revised Code and Ohio Administrative Code concerning
license revocation and suspension. 
(Ord. 064-00. Passed 3-27-00; Ord. 024-13. Passed 1-28-13.)
840.08   LIABILITY INSURANCE REQUIRED.
   (A)   No ambulance license shall be issued under this chapter, no such
license shall be valid after issuance, and no ambulance shall be operated in
the City, unless there is at all times in force and effect insurance coverage,
issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in the State of Ohio,
providing for the payment of damages in the minimum amount of One Million
Dollars ($1,000,000) per Occurrence and three million dollars ($3,000,000)
single aggregate limit.  The City of Lima, Ohio shall be named as an additional
insured. 
   (B)   No EMSO license shall be issued under this chapter, no such license
shall be valid after issuance, and no EMSO shall be operated in the City,
unless there is at all times in force and effect Professional Liability
malpractice insurance coverage of at least One Million dollars ($1,000,000.00),
issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in the State of Ohio. 
The City of Lima, Ohio shall be named as an additional insured. 
   (C)   A copy of such policies shall be provided to the Mayor, Auditor, and
the Law Director.
   (D)   The insurance required in this section shall apply as follows:
       A)   For the injury or death of persons in accidents resulting from any
cause for which the owner of the ambulance would be liable because of liability
imposed by law, regardless of whether such ambulance was being driven by the
owner or the owner's agent; and
       (2)   For loss of or damage to the property of another, including
personal property, under like circumstances.
   (E)   The insurance policies shall be submitted to the License Officer for
approval prior to the issuance of each ambulance and EMSO license. Satisfactory
evidence that such insurance is at all times in force and effect shall be
furnished to the License Officer, in such form as the officer may specify, by
licensees required to provide such insurance under the provisions of this
chapter.
   (F)   Each insurance policy required herein shall contain provisions that
liability thereunder shall continue to the full amount thereof, notwithstanding
any recovery thereon, that the liability of the insurer shall not be affected
by the insolvency or the bankruptcy of the insured and that, until the policy
is revoked, the insurance company shall not be relieved from liability because
of nonpayment of the premium, failure to renew the license at the end of the
year or any other act or omission of the insured. Such policy of insurance
shall be further conditioned upon the payment of any judgments up to the limits
of the policy recovered against any person other than the owner, the owner's
agent or employee who may operate the ambulance with the consent or
acquiescence of the owner.
   (G)   Each insurance policy required herein shall extend for the period to
be covered by the license applied for, and the insurer shall be obliged to give
not less than fifteen days written notice to the License Officer and to the
insured before any cancellation or termination thereof before the expiration
date. The cancellation or other termination of any insurance policy shall
automatically revoke and terminate the licenses issued for the ambulances
covered by such policy, unless another insurance policy complying with the
provisions of this section is provided and in effect at the time of such
cancellation or termination.
(Ord. 064-00. Passed 3-27-00.)
840.09   DUTIES OF INSPECTION OFFICER.
   (A)   Prior to the issuance of any license, the Inspection Officer shall
inspect each vehicle, its equipment, and the EMSO premises designated in each
application and shall certify  approval in a written report to the License
Officer when the officer finds compliance with the standards prescribed in this
Chapter and with any regulations promulgated thereunder. However, under the
terms of this chapter, the Inspection Officer shall have no responsibility and
shall exercise no authority in connection with laws and ordinances of general
applicability which deal with motor vehicle inspection.
   (B)   Subsequent to issuance of any license, the Inspection Officer shall
cause to be inspected each licensed vehicle, its equipment,  and EMSO premises
whenever the officer deems such inspection to be necessary and shall promptly
report the findings in a written report to the License Officer. These
inspections shall be in addition to any other safety or motor vehicle
inspections required to be made for ambulances or other motor vehicles and any
other inspections required to be made under general laws or ordinances; shall
not excuse compliance with any requirement of law or ordinance to display any
official certificate of motor vehicle inspection and approval, and shall not
excuse compliance with the requirements of any other applicable general law or
ordinance.
   (C)   A copy of each quarterly or other ambulance, equipment, and EMSO
premises inspection report submitted by the Inspection Officer to the License
Officer under the provisions of this section shall be promptly transmitted to
the applicant or licensee to whom it refers.
(Ord. 064-00. Passed 3-27-00; Ord. 025-13. Passed 1-28-13.)
840.10   DUTIES OF LICENSE OFFICER; MAYOR.
   (a)   The License Officer shall, within a reasonable time after receipt of
an application for any license under this chapter, cause such investigation as
the officer deems necessary to be made of the applicant or application for the
purpose of processing the license application.
   (b)   The License Officer may issue a license for a specified emergency
medical service organization, which shall have no expiration date, unless
earlier suspended, revoked or terminated, when the officer finds that the
emergency medical service organization has met all the requirements of this
chapter and all other applicable laws, ordinances and rules.
   (c)   The License Officer may issue a license for a specified ambulance,
which license shall expire on December 31 of each year, unless earlier
suspended, revoked or terminated, when the officer finds:
      (1)   That each ambulance, its required equipment and the premises
designated in the application have been certified by the appropriate official
as provided for herein;
      (2)   That the applicant is a responsible and proper person to conduct or
work in the proposed business;
      (3)   That only duly licensed drivers, attendants and attendant-drivers
are employed in such capacities; and
      (4)   That all the requirements of this chapter and all other applicable
laws and ordinances have been met.
   (d)   The License Officer may issue a license to a driver, attendant or
attendant-driver, valid for a period of one year, unless earlier suspended,
revoked or terminated, when the officer finds that the applicant has a valid
State driver's license and has completed emergency vehicle training, and when
the officer finds, further, that the applicant:
      (1)   Is not addicted to the use of intoxicating liquors or narcotics and
is morally fit for the position;
      (2)   Is able to speak, read and write the English language;
      (3)   Has been found by a duly licensed physician, upon examination
attested to on a form provided by the License Officer, to be of sound physique,
to possess eyesight corrected to at least 20/40 in at least one eye, and to be
free of physical defects or diseases which might impair the applicant's ability
to drive or attend an ambulance with reasonable accommodations; and
      (4)   Has a currently valid certificate evidencing successful completion
of the State of Ohio certified EMT, EMT-B, EMT-I or EMT-P courses.
   (e)   All licenses issued, suspended, or revoked under this chapter shall be
done only with the approval of the Mayor.  For good cause shown, after
consultation with the Fire Chief, and with Council approval, the Mayor may
waive any requirement of this chapter if he determines that such a waiver is in
the best interests of the residents of the City and does not adversely affect
the public health, safety, and welfare.
   (f)   The Mayor is authorized to develop a 911 and emergency call
dispatching policy that shall be submitted to City Council for approval.
(Ord. 064-00. Passed 3-27-00; Ord. 59-14. Passed 3-10-14; Ord. 220-18. Passed
9-24-18.)
840.11   LICENSE RENEWAL.
   (A)   A license required by this chapter that has not been revoked,
terminated and is otherwise valid, may be renewed upon such forms as prepared
or prescribed by the License Officer.  The renewal application form shall
include, but not be limited to, a statement from the renewal applicant
describing what, if any, circumstances reported in the licensee's most recent
application  have changed since that application.
   (B)   A license required by this chapter, that has been revoked, terminated
or for any other reason is no longer valid, may not be renewed.  Such a license
may only be reissued upon conformance with all the requirements of this chapter
as upon original licensing.
(Ord. 064-00. Passed 3-27-00.)
840.12   LICENSE REVOCATION AND SUSPENSION.
   (A)   The Mayor may suspend or revoke a license issued under this chapter
for failure of a licensee to comply and to maintain compliance with, or for
violation of, this chapter, regulations promulgated hereunder, or of any other
applicable law or ordinance or regulations promulgated thereunder.  Except upon
a finding by the Mayor or exigent circumstances necessary to immediately
protect the health, safety, and welfare of the public, no license may be
suspended or revoked unless the licensee has been notified of the possibility
of such suspension or revocation and has been given an opportunity to be
heard.  The Mayor shall adopt administrative proceedings necessary to carry out
the provisions herein for suspension or revocation of such licenses, which
shall be submitted to Council for approval.
   (B)   The initial or other ambulance, equipment and EMSO premises inspection
report of the Inspection Officer and Fire Chief, shall be prima-facie evidence
of compliance or noncompliance with, or violation of, this chapter and the
regulations promulgated hereunder as reflected in such reports.
   (C)   Upon suspension or revocation of an EMSO license, such organization
shall cease operations as such, and no person shall permit such organization to
continue operations as such.  Upon suspension, revocation or termination of an
ambulance license, such ambulance shall cease operations as such, and no person
shall permit such ambulance to continue operations as such. Upon suspension,
revocation or termination of a driver's, attendant's or attendant-driver's
license, such driver, attendant or attendant-driver shall cease to drive or
attend an ambulance, and no person shall employ or permit such individual to
drive or attend an ambulance.
(Ord. 064-00. Passed 3-27-00; Ord. 026-13. Passed 1-28-13.)
840.13   REPORTS AND INSPECTIONS.
   (A)   Within forty-eight hours after transporting a patient within the City,
or from one place within the City to another place within or beyond its limits,
the licensee of an ambulance shall make available a written report to the
Inspection Officer upon such forms as the officer may provide or prescribe,
giving all information therein required and any other relevant information
which such Inspection Officer may require.
   (B)   Subsection (A) hereof shall apply with equal force whether such
patient dies before being transported in such ambulance, while being
transported therein or at any time prior to the acceptance of the patient into
the responsibility of the hospital or medical or other authority, if the
patient is still under the care or responsibility of the ambulance.
   (C)   Each licensed ambulance, its equipment, the EMSO premises designated
in the application and all records relating to its maintenance and operation as
such, shall be open to inspection by the Inspection Officer, the License
Officer, and the Chief of the Fire Department or their respective designees,
during usual hours of operation and at any time of day or night for unannounced
inspections if the above officials deem it necessary.
(Ord. 064-00. Passed 3-27-00.)
840.14   REGISTRATION REQUIRED.
   (a)   Any person, either as owner, agent or otherwise, who furnishes,
operates, conducts, maintains, advertises or otherwise is engaged in the
business or service of nonemergency medical transportation and provides these
services as described in section 840.01(m) of the Lima Codified Ordinances upon
the streets, alleys or other public ways or places of the City shall  register
with the Registration Officer as a “Nonemergency Medical Transport
Organization.” 
   (b)   No registration shall be required under this chapter for operation of
an ambulette or basic medical transport by a medical transportation
organization, which:
      (1)   Is operated from a location or headquarters outside the City in
order to transport patients who are picked up beyond the limits of the City and
transports to locations within the City.  However, any such Nonemergency
Medical Transportation Organization that causes an ambulette or basic medical
transport to be used to pick up patients within the City for transportation to
a location within the City shall be registered with the Registration Officer.
      (2)   Is owned by an a licensed cab operator and operated by a licensed
Taxicab Driver pursuant to Lima Codified Ordinances
Chapter 852.
      (3)   Is owned and operated by a public social service agency
transporting the  patients and clients of the agency. 
(Ord. 224-08. Passed 12-15-2008.)
840.15   REGISTRATION FORM; FEE
   (a)   Registrations for Nonemergency Medical Transport Organizations shall
be made to the Registration Officer upon forms provided by the city and shall
set forth, at a minimum, the name, address and contact information of
applicant, the trade name under which the business is conducted, a specific
description of all vehicles used (to include make, model, vin# and vehicle
registration information), the letters and marks to be used to identify the
vehicle and service provided and such other information that may be required by
the Registration Officer.
   (b)   The Nonemergency Medical Transport Organization shall pay an annual
registration fee as specified in Section
868.01 of the Lima Codified Ordinances. 
(Ord. 224-08. Passed 12-15-2008.)
840.16   EMERGENCY CALLS; 911 CALLS
   (A)   The Mayor is authorized to develop an emergency call dispatching
policy that provides for the manner and method by which EMSO’s are requested to
respond to emergency medical service calls received directly by the City or
received by the City through the local 911 emergency dispatch system.
      (1)   Such policy may provide for a system whereby emergency calls are
dispatched to EMSO’s licensed under this Chapter, and the Lima Fire Department,
on a rotating basis, as much as is practicable, so that reasonable attempt is
made for each such EMSO and the Lima Fire Department have the opportunity to
receive an approximately equivalent number of such calls in a calendar year, as
much as may be practicable. Exact equality of dispatches shall not be a goal or
specific requirement of this policy. By adoption of this policy, no EMSO is
guaranteed a certain number or percentage of dispatches from the City, and no
EMSO may rely upon this policy as any claim or entitlement to receive any such
dispatches.
      (2)   Such policy may provide for revocation or suspension of the
opportunity to receive such emergency calls, and the opportunity for the appeal
thereof.
   (B)   Only EMSO’s licensed under this Chapter, and the Lima Fire Department,
shall be eligible to receive emergency calls under this section and policy.
   (C)   To be eligible to receive emergency calls, each such EMSO and the Lima
Fire Department must maintain at least one fully equipped advanced life
support, paramedic-manned, licensed ambulance, staffed 24 hours a day, 7 days a
week, 365 days a year, which is available to respond to emergency calls
dispatched pursuant to this section and such policy. This ambulance may be one
of the ambulances required under Section
840.03(B).
(Ord. 249-10. Passed 11-22-10.)
840.99   PENALTY
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: See Section
802.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)

848.01   SOLICITATION ON STREETS; EXCEPTIONS.
   No person, association, society or other institution, except the hospitals,
veterans' organizations and other groups specified in Section
848.06, shall solicit upon the streets or other public places within the City
any gift or donation of money or other property by the sale, distribution,
giving away of or use of any tags, flowers or similar devices or by the use of
any banks, boxes or other containers or receptacles in which such money, gifts
or donations might be deposited.
(1956 Code Sec. 579.09)
848.02   LICENSE FEE FOR PEDDLERS, HAWKERS AND VENDORS; EXCEPTIONS.
   (A)   (1)   Any person engaged in the business of selling or offering for
sale from house to house on any public street within the City any fruits,
vegetables, peanuts, ice cream, candy, similar confections, and other food
products, or any goods or merchandise of any description shall pay an annual
license fee in the amount specified in Section
868.01.
      (2)   Any person using a vehicle for selling such articles of food or
merchandise on the streets of the City shall obtain and have securely fastened
to his vehicle license plates, which shall be furnished by the City License
Clerk without additional cost to the licensee.
   (B)   Any person who sells any product of his own raising or manufacture or
who is permitted by any law of the United States or of the State to pursue such
occupation or business by reason of being an honorably discharged member of the
Armed Services of the United States shall not be required to pay the license
fee required by subsection (A) hereof.
(Ord. 169-91. Passed 7-8-91; Ord. 244-17. Passed 10-9-17.)
848.03   LICENSE FEE FOR SOLICITORS; EXCEPTIONS.
   (A)   Any person engaged in the business of going about the City soliciting
orders for goods, wares, merchandise or other articles for profit shall be
deemed a solicitor and shall pay an annual license fee in the amount specified
in Section
868.01.
   (B)   The fee required by subsection (A) hereof shall not apply to an
employee of any person maintaining a regularly established bona fide place of
business within the City or to any person taking orders for products of his own
raising and manufacture.
(Ord. 169-91. Passed 7-8-91; Ord. 245-17. Passed 10-9-17.)
848.04   LICENSE FEE FOR TRANSIENT RETAIL DEALERS.
   Any person engaged in the business of selling goods, wares, or merchandise
at retail from hotel rooms or storerooms, at the entrance to hotel rooms or
storerooms, from house to house, or upon the public streets for a period of
sixty days or less and who has no regularly-established, bonafide place of
business within the City shall be deemed a transient retail dealer and shall
pay a license fee in the amount specified in Section 868.01 for each day.
(Ord. 169-91.  Passed 7-8-91; Ord. 246-17. Passed 10-9-17.)
848.05   LICENSE FEE FOR ITINERANT DEALERS; EXCEPTIONS.
   (A)   Any person who sells or offers for sale from a cart, wagon, truck,
automobile, railroad car or any other vehicle, operated or propelled over and
upon the streets of the City, any fruits, vegetables, garden produce, butter,
eggs, cheese, game, fish, meat, live or dressed poultry or any other produce,
coal, coke, Christmas trees or commodities or merchandise of any kind and
description to any person engaged in the business of the resale at retail or
wholesale of such products shall be deemed an itinerant dealer and shall pay an
annual license fee in the amount specified in Section
868.01 for each vehicle or location used.
   (B)   The license fee required by subsection (A) hereof shall not apply to
the bona fide sale of produce on the streets by hawkers and peddlers who are
otherwise regulated by Section
848.02 or to farmers and others selling any products of their own raising or
manufacture.  However, any person selling products of his own raising or
manufacture shall register his name and address with the Mayor and shall
furnish a statement noting the exact location of his farm or place of produce
and stating that he is a farmer or person selling produce of his own raising or
production.  Upon registration and the filing of such statement, the Mayor
shall furnish such person with two metal plates bearing the registration
number, the year for which issued and the term "Registered Farmer or Producer,
Lima, Ohio, No. _________," giving in the blank space the number of such
registered dealer.  The fee for a registered farmer or producer desiring an
itinerant dealer's license shall be the amount specified in Section
868.01, paid annually.
(1956 Code Sec. 579.05)  (Ord. 210-17.  Passed 9-11-17.)
848.06   CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS; REPORTS.
   (A)   The Mayor shall have the authority to issue a permit, upon proper
request and payment of the fee specified in Section
868.01, for the solicitation upon the streets and other public places within
the City of gifts, donations and contributions for the use, maintenance, and
benefit of local hospitals, of veterans' organizations composed of men or women
now or formerly identified with the Armed Services of the United States and of
other accredited patriotic, educational and philanthropic organizations,
associations, institutions and societies. Such solicitations may be in
connection with the sale, distribution or giving away of tags, flowers or
similar devices.
   (B)   The application for such permit shall be filed by a duly-authorized
representative of the hospital, veterans' organization, or other group
requesting the permit. If required to do so by the Mayor, the applicant for
such permit shall give any other pertinent information concerning the purpose
for such request.
   (C)   Within ten days from the time such solicitation is made, a written
report showing the amount of money collected shall be filed with the City
Auditor by the permittee.  Failure to file such report may be grounds for
denying permit requests by such group during the succeeding year.
(1956 Code Sec. 579.06)  (Ord. 257-17. Passed 10-23-17.)
848.07   FREQUENCY AND DURATION OF SOLICITATIONS.
   The Mayor shall have authority to make any other regulations governing the
conduct of the solicitations specified in Section
848.06. Not more than one hospital, veterans ' organization or other group
specified in Section
848.06 shall solicit such gifts, donations or contributions on the same date.
(Ord. 199-77. Passed 11-21-77.)
848.08   RECORDS; REVOCATION OF PERMITS.
   The Mayor is hereby authorized and directed to keep a record of each day set
aside for the purpose specified in Section
848.06. Every permit issued therefor by the Mayor may be revoked by him if such
revocation is found necessary in the interest of public peace, safety or
welfare. No such revocation shall be effective until the provisions of Section
802.09 are complied with.
848.99   PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
802.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)

660.01
852.01   DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (A)   "Cruising" means the driving of an unengaged taxicab for the purpose
of soliciting passengers.
`   (B)   "Driver" means the person in actual physical control of a taxicab.
   (C)   "Operator" means any person owning, in charge of or managing a taxicab
business in the City.
   (D)   "Paint" means the application of coloring matter in oil solution and
not in water solution.
   (E)   "Taxicab" means any public vehicle whose owner or driver secures or
accepts passengers for hire on the public streets or in public or quasi-public
places, except a motorbus operating under franchise of the City.
   (F)   "Unengaged taxicab" means a taxicab in the charge of a driver and
neither occupied by or standing at the direction of a passenger nor responding
to the call of a prospective passenger. A taxicab standing at a taxi stand
shall be presumed to be unengaged.
   (G)   "Taximeter" means a mechanical or electronic instrument or device by
which the charge for hire of a public cab is calculated, either for distance
traveled, or for waiting time, or for both, and upon which such charges shall
be indicated by means of figures.
(Ord. 218-83. Passed 12-19-83.)
852.02   LICENSE FEE FOR TAXICAB OPERATORS.
   Any person engaged in the business of operating taxicabs, automobiles or
other vehicles for the transportation of persons for hire shall pay an annual
license fee as specified in Section 868.01.  Such person shall comply with the
terms of these Codified Ordinances and all ordinances pertaining to the
regulations of taxicabs now or hereafter in effect.
(Ord. 170-91.  Passed 7-8-91; Ord. 258-17.  Passed 10-23-17.)
852.03   LICENSE FEES FOR TAXICAB AND BUS DRIVERS; REGULATIONS.
   (A)   Any person engaged in the occupation of driving taxicabs, automobiles
or other vehicles for hire for the purpose of transporting persons, except
public buses operated under franchise, shall pay an annual license fee in the
amount specified in Section 868.01.  Such fee shall include the cost of a
photograph and fingerprints to be taken by the City License Clerk. The
photograph shall have the driver's name and address attached hereto and shall
be conspicuously displayed in the vehicle. The licensee shall comply with the
provisions of these Codified Ordinances and all ordinances or laws governing
the operation of taxicabs and motor vehicles now or hereafter in effect.
   (B)   The Chief of Police or his designee shall approve or disapprove all
applications for licensing required under subsection (A) hereof. Grounds for
refusal of a license are as follows:
      (1)   The applicant has been convicted of a theft offense within one
year.
      (2)   The applicant has been convicted of a felony theft offense within
three years.
      (3)   The applicant has been convicted of a drug sale offense; no time
limit.
      (4)   The applicant has been convicted of a drug abuse offense within one
year.
      (5)   The applicant has been convicted of operating a motor vehicle while
under the influence of drugs or alcohol or being in physical control of a motor
vehicle while under the influence of drugs or alcohol within the past two
years.
      (6)   The applicant has been convicted of a sexual assault offense; no
time limit.
      (7)   Any person who has a lengthy or diverse criminal record who, in the
opinion of the Chief or his designee, should not be issued a taxicab driver's
license.
      (8)   For any person whose convictions fall within the above guidelines,
the date of conviction shall be deemed to be the later of the actual date of
conviction or his release from incarceration resulting from the conviction.
      (9)   The Chief of Police or his designee is hereby authorized and
empowered to establish such additional rules and regulations covering the
issuance of taxicab driver's licenses, not inconsistent herewith, as may be
necessary and reasonable.
(Ord. 170-91. Passed 7-8-91; Ord. 259-17. Passed 10-23-17.)
852.04   UNLICENSED DRIVERS.
   No licensee shall permit any licensed taxicab to be driven for hire by any
person who is not a licensed driver under the provisions of Section
852.03.
(1956 Code Sec. 583.04)
852.05   LICENSING PROVISIONS.
   Any person engaged in the business of operating one or more taxicabs, as
defined in Section
852.01, shall pay the annual license fees required by Sections
852.02 and
852.03 of the Codified Ordinances of Lima, Ohio and shall comply with all of
the provisions of this chapter and all other ordinances pertaining to the
regulation of taxicabs.
   When licenses are issued for taxicab operation after August 1 of any year,
the fee shall be one-half the annual fee. All licenses shall expire on the next
January 31st, after issuance.
(Ord. 41-11. Passed 2-28-11.)
852.06   INSURANCE.
   No person shall operate taxicabs or engage in the business of operating
taxicabs for the transportation of persons for hire within the City unless the
applicant for a license under the provisions of Section
852.05 deposits with the Mayor a policy or certificate of liability insurance
for each taxicab for which a license is applied. Insurance coverage shall be in
the minimum amounts of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000) per person and
three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000) per accident. The policy shall
contain a clause obligating the surety company or insurance company writing
such policy to give ten days' written notice to the Mayor before cancellation
of such policy. Upon the lapse, expiration or termination of such policy and
insurance, the license issued under the provisions of Section
852.05 shall expire.
(Ord. 211-83. Passed 12-5-83.)
852.07   LICENSE APPLICATION.
   Applications for taxicab licenses shall be made to the Mayor upon blanks
provided by the City and shall set forth the name and address of the applicant,
the trade name under which he does business, the seating capacity, design,
color scheme, lettering and marks to be used on the vehicles to be used, the
motor number of each vehicle to be used, the location of the taxicab stand and
such other information as may be required by the Mayor.
(1956 Code Sec. 583.07)
852.08   LICENSE ISSUANCE.
   (A)   Before a taxicab license is issued upon an original application or
renewed, the vehicle shall display a current Ohio State Patrol safety
inspection sticker.  All taxicabs at all times shall display a current, valid
Ohio State Patrol safety inspection sticker.
   (B)   In addition to all other applicable provisions of this chapter, no
license shall be issued to, or renewed for, any driver or operator unless such
driver or operator has first timely filed all appropriate City Income Tax
Returns and paid all tax due thereunder. 
(Ord. 139-95.  Passed 11-20-95.)
852.09   LICENSE TRANSFER TO OTHER OWNER; SUBSTITUTING EQUIPMENT.
   Licenses may not be transferred from owner to owner, but, upon application
therefor duly filed, may be transferred to other equipment upon payment of a
fee of one dollar ($1.00). Applications for such transfer shall be referred to
the Police Department for investigation in the same manner as in the case of an
original application for a license, as set forth in Section
852.08, and such license may thereafter be transferred to cover the substituted
equipment, upon a finding that the proposed substituted equipment is safe and
that it complies with all requirements of these Codified Ordinances and other
ordinances of the City.
(1956 Code Sec. 583.09)
852.10   LICENSE REVOCATION AND SUSPENSION.
   (A)   Taxicab Driver's License. A taxicab driver's license may be suspended
or revoked at any time by the Chief of Police or his designee upon his own
initiative. Before suspending or revoking such taxicab driver's license, the
Chief of Police or his designee shall afford the licensee an opportunity of a
hearing upon the charges. The licensee may appeal from such order to the Mayor,
who may schedule a hearing within fifteen days. A second suspension for the
same reason, or, in any case a third suspension of a driver's license, shall
operate as a revocation of such taxicab driver's license. No driver whose
license has been revoked shall again be licensed as a public cab driver in the
City unless upon presentation of reasons satisfactory to the Chief of Police or
his designee.
   (B)   Cab Operator's Licenses. Licenses granted under this chapter may be
revoked or suspended at any time by the Chief of Police or his designee if the
vehicle shall be used for immoral or illegal business purposes, and licenses so
revoked shall not be reissued again. Licenses granted under this chapter may
also be suspended or revoked at anytime by the Chief of Police or his designee
if the vehicle is not in good condition and appearance, clean and safe.
Licenses when so suspended or revoked shall not be reissued until the vehicle
and all its appurtenances shall be put into fit condition for use by the
public.
(Ord. 218-83. Passed 12-19-83.)
852.11   RESTORATION OF SUSPENDED LICENSE.
   Upon showing by a licensee whose license has been suspended that he has in
good faith complied with all conditions at any time prior to the time specified
in the notice of suspension, his license may be restored at any time.
(1956 Code Sec. 583.11)
852.12   SURRENDER OF LICENSE CERTIFICATE; DESTRUCTION OF LICENSE.
   No person whose license has been suspended or revoked shall fail, refuse or
neglect to surrender the license certificate to any police officer demanding
the same nor shall any person conceal or destroy any license certificate during
the year for which such license was issued.
(1956 Code Sec. 583.12)
852.13   CONDUCTING BUSINESS DURING SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION PERIOD.
   No person shall conduct any taxicab business during any period during which
the license therefor is suspended or after such license is revoked, until, in
either case, such license is restored.
(1956 Code Sec. 583.13)
852.14   DISPLAY OF LICENSE CERTIFICATE.
   It shall be the duty of every person to whom a taxicab license is issued to
post such license certificate in a prominent place upon the premises of the
headquarters from which the business is conducted and to keep such license
certificate so posted as long as such business is conducted thereunder. The
licensee shall not permit such license to be obscured or concealed in any way,
so that such license will not be readily visible at all times to persons
lawfully present on such premises.
(1956 Code Sec. 583.14)
852.15   TAG OR DECAL.
   The Mayor shall furnish to each licensee an appropriate license tag or
decal, in addition to the license certificate, which tag or decal shall be
displayed on the taxicab in such place as may be prescribed by the Police
Department. In case of the loss of a license tag or decal, the owner may file
with the Mayor a sworn statement of the facts concerning such loss and if the
Mayor is satisfied that the facts justify the issuance of a replacement tag or
decal, he shall issue such. The charge for such replacement tag or decal shall
be one dollar ($1.00).
(1956 Code Sec. 583.15)
852.16   IDENTIFICATION.
   (A)   Every person owning and operating taxicabs who obtains a license from
the City may adopt any trade name, design, color scheme or method of painting
or lettering such taxicabs that is approved by the Mayor. Such trade name,
design, color scheme or method of painting or lettering shall include the
following:
      (1)   A serial body number, assigned by the Mayor to each taxicab,
painted on each side and on the rear of the taxicab; and
      (2)   The name of the owner or the trade name under which he does
business, painted on each side of the taxicab.
   (B)   If the name of the owner or the trade name under which he does
business does not include any one of the words "taxicab," "taxi" or "cab," the
word "taxicab" shall be painted on each side of the taxicab immediately beneath
his name or the trade name.
   (C)   Whenever any person owning or operating taxicabs does not adopt and
use an approved trade name, design, color scheme or method of painting and
lettering, it shall be mandatory for such person to paint the following matter
on his taxicabs:
      (1)   A framed panel enclosing on separate lines the name of the owner,
the word "taxicab" and the serial body number assigned to the taxicab by the
Mayor. Such panel shall be painted on each side of the taxicab and shall cover
an area no less than fifteen inches by twenty inches. The form of such panel
shall be substantially as follows:
         JOHN T. SMITH
         TAXICAB
         32
      (2)   The serial body number assigned the taxicab by the Mayor painted on
the rear exterior of the taxicab.
   (D)   All mandatory lettering and wording, whether in a particular trade
name, design, color scheme, method of painting or lettering or otherwise, shall
be at least three inches in height and shall be of such color as, in the
opinion of the Mayor, will contrast distinctly with the color of the body of
the taxicab. The serial body numbers on sides and rear shall be no less than
four inches in height.
   No person shall cause or permit any taxicab to appear with a trade name,
design, color scheme or method of painting and lettering that is not approved
by the Mayor for the taxicab concerned or that is not in accordance with the
terms of this section.
(1956 Code Sec. 583.16)
852.17   CONDITION AND EQUIPMENT. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section 852.17 was repealed by Ordinance 107-77, passed June
6, 1977.)
852.18   PERIODIC INSPECTION. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section 852.18 was repealed by Ordinance 107-77, passed June
6, 1977.)
852.19   TRANSPORTING PASSENGERS WITH COMMUNICABLE DISEASE. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section 852.19 was repealed by Ordinance 107-77, passed June
6, 1977.)
852.20   RATES PRESCRIBED; POSTING. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section 852.20 was repealed by Ordinance 31-79, passed
February 12, 1979.)
852.21   LIMITATIONS ON USE.
   No operator or driver of a taxicab shall:
   (A)   Drive over any fixed or regular route;
   (B)   Pass any specified point on a fixed or regular time schedule for the
purpose of picking up passengers;
   (C)   When hired, accept any other passengers without the consent of the
person who has hired the cab;
   (D)   Permit a taxicab to practice cruising on the streets or in quasi-
public places; or
   (E)   Permit the carrying of nonpaying passengers at any time.
(1956 Code Sec. 583.21)
852.22   HOURS OF SERVICE.
   Any operator granted a license to operate a taxicab or taxicabs must provide
service, which is available by phone contact, to the public twenty-four hours
per day, seven days a week, including holidays. Failure to provide this service
shall be reason for the Mayor or his designee to revoke the operator's license.
Every operator granted a license after passage of this section, or those with
existing licenses, must file a schedule of his regular hours with the Mayor.
Service shall not be changed thereafter without the consent of the Mayor.
(Ord. 218-83. Passed 12-19-83.)
852.99   PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
802.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 854
Antenna Installation
854.01   Permit Required.
854.02   Permit Application.
854.03   Certificate of Approval.
854.04   Permit and Inspection Fees; Reinspection.
854.05   Transferability and Duration of Permit.
854.06   Board of Appeals.
854.07   Right of Appeal.
854.08   Bond.
854.09   Technical Requirements.
854.10   Authority to Reinspect and Require Alterations to Be Made.
854.11   Demonstration Antenna Systems.
854.12   Minor Repairs.
854.13   Nuisance.
854.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Radio signals - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
656
   Radio and television transmitting stations in Class I Residential Districts
- see P. & Z.
1248.01(a)(5)
   Installation standards and approved materials for electrical devices or
equipment - see B. & H. Ch.
1472
854.01   PERMIT REQUIRED.
   Except as otherwise herein contained, no person shall install, either as an
owner or as an agent, servant or employee of an owner, tenant  or lessee, or as
an independent contractor for an owner, or otherwise, any outside antenna
system for any type of radio antenna, television antenna or television
receiving apparatus or equipment, or any additions to or substitutions for such
a system, or a satellite antenna, unless and until a permit for such additions
or substitutions has been first obtained from the City Engineer. For the
purpose of this chapter, "antenna system" shall mean the structural apparatus
used to support any type of antenna attached thereon. 
(Ord. 10-92.  Passed 2-24-92.)
854.02   PERMIT APPLICATION.
   Any person desiring to erect, install or maintain any outside antenna system
for any type of radio antenna, television antenna, satellite antenna, or any
additions to or substitutions for any such system, shall make a written
application for the same to the City Engineer upon such forms as may be
prescribed, and accompany such application with a fee for the same as provided
in Section
854.04. Upon finding that the proposed installation or work complies in every
respect with the requirements of this chapter, the City Engineer shall issue a
permit to the applicant.
   Whenever property upon which such a satellite antenna, radio antenna,
television antenna or any other antenna is to be erected, or upon which
additions to or substitutions for existing antenna systems are to be made, is
not occupied by the owner thereof, any tenant must furnish a proper written
approval given by the owner thereof prior to the issuance of a permit.
(Ord. 10-92.  Passed 2-24-92.)
854.03   CERTIFICATE OF APPROVAL.
   When any installation covered by a permit provided for in this chapter has
been completed, the person in whose name the permit therefor has been granted
shall immediately notify the City Engineer that the work is ready for final
inspection and shall pay the inspection fee required. Thereupon the same shall
be promptly inspected by representatives of the Division of Engineering and, if
the work complies in all respects with the provisions of this chapter and with
the permit, a certificate of approval shall be given by the City Engineer to
the permittee. In the event that such work does not comply in all respects with
the provisions of this chapter and with the permit, a certificate of approval
shall be withheld until and unless a subsequent inspection discloses
compliance. A request for reinspection shall be accompanied by the payment of a
reinspection fee as set forth in Section
854.04. Except for test purposes, no antenna system shall be placed in use
until such certificate of approval is obtained.
(Ord. 10-92.  Passed 2-24-92.)
854.04   PERMIT AND INSPECTION FEES; REINSPECTION.
   At the time of issuing a permit for any antenna system, the applicant
therefor shall pay to the City Engineer the applicable fee provided in Section
868.01 for each installation and inspection of such antenna before a
certificate of approval is given. If a reinspection is required, an additional
one-time fee in the amount provided in Section
868.01 shall be submitted to the City Engineer.  A permit is not necessary for
changing the type of antenna unless the design of the antenna will cause
additional stress on the antenna system.  Re-inspections may be required by the
City Engineer whenever it is found that the application contains an incorrect
address, when work is found to be faulty upon first examination, or when
repairs or corrections are not made when reinspection is requested.
(Ord. 10-92.  Passed 2-24-92; Ord. 247-17.  Passed 10-9-17.)
854.05   TRANSFERABILITY AND DURATION OF PERMIT.
   Any permit issued under this chapter shall be personal to the applicant and,
if not exercised within thirty days after the date of issuance thereof, shall
become null and void. 
(Ord. 10-92.  Passed 2-24-92.)
854.06   BOARD OF APPEALS.
   A Board of Appeals, consisting of three members appointed by the Mayor who
are electors of the City and who, by experience and training, are persons
qualified to pass upon the safety of installations and apparatus regulated by
this chapter, is hereby created. Such members shall not be employees of the
City, shall serve without compensation and shall hold office for three years,
unless removed by the Mayor. No member of the Board shall sit on a case in
which he is directly or indirectly interested, and in case of disqualification
for such cause or in case of the necessary absence of a member, the Mayor shall
make a temporary appointment of a substitute. All vacancies occurring on the
Board shall be filled by the Mayor. Upon consideration of a case upon appeal,
the Board may reverse, modify or affirm the decision or order appealed from. 
(Ord. 10-92.  Passed 2-24-92.)
854.07   RIGHT OF APPEAL.
   Any person who is dissatisfied by any decision of the City Engineer under
this chapter may appeal to the Board of Appeals provided for in Section
854.06 by serving written notice within ten days thereafter upon the City
Engineer. Such matter shall, within ten days thereof, be transmitted to the
Board, and a meeting to consider such matter shall be held within twenty days,
unless continued for good cause.
(Ord. 10-92.  Passed 2-24-92.)
854.08   BOND.
   Every person engaged in the business of erecting antenna systems for
television antennae, satellite antennae and radio antennae shall annually file
with the City Auditor a good and sufficient bond approved by such official,
payable to the City, in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000). Such bond
shall indemnify, save and keep harmless the City from any and all costs,
damages and expenses of any kind which may be suffered by the City or which may
occur against the same by reason of the granting of permission to erect any
television antenna or to perform any work thereon or by reason of any acts or
things done under or by authority granted by the City Engineer. Such bond shall
also inure to the use and benefit of any person or property by reason of the
construction, care and management of such antenna and may be drawn upon, in the
name of the City, for the use and benefit of any such person but without cost
or expense to the City.
   The maintenance of such bond in full force and effect as herein provided
shall be a prerequisite to the issuance of any permit and certificate of
approval required under this chapter, except that such bond shall not be
required by a property owner desiring to perform such work upon his own
property.
(Ord. 10-92.  Passed 2-24-92.)
854.09   TECHNICAL REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Radio and Television Antennae.  All radio antenna and television
antenna installations, except citizen band and amateur radio antennas, from and
after the effective date of this chapter, shall be made in accordance with the
following regulations:
      (1)   Antennae must be securely fastened as approved by the enforcing
authority, to a dwelling or garage by not less than three guy wires, as equally
separated as is practically possible, or if fastened to any other point, shall
not be less than seven feet from a well-anchored stub if in earth.
      (2)   Antenna systems shall be installed according to the manufacturing
specification except if the same are in conflict with this chapter.
      (3)   Guy wires must be rust-resistant, standard wire, not smaller than
No. 10B and S gauge, or any other material approved by the enforcing authority.
      (4)   The antenna system and the antenna shall not exceed fifty feet in
height without written approval from the City Engineer. Upon denial, the person
will have the right to appeal as set forth in this chapter.
      (5)   Each guy wire shall have at least one approved insulator between
the antenna system and the point of fastening to the building structure.
      (6)   A guy wire must not be fastened to any utility pole or any tree.
      (7)   Grounding requirements shall be in accordance to the National
Electrical Code and manufacturing specifications.
      (8)   Antennae and antenna systems must be grounded to a driven ground
not less than eight feet long on the outside of the building.
      (9)   Grounding conductors must not be more than No. 6 stranded copper
wire.
      (10)   Antenna fastened to suitable chimneys by means of approved straps
are permitted for ten-foot installations only and shall be installed to
manufacturing specifications.
      (11)   Antennae may be not fastened to soil pipes, vent pipes or other
objects.
      (12)   Any type of radio or television antennae must comply with all
applicable sections of the Ohio Basic Building Code (OBBC) and the National
Electrical Code (NEC).
   (B)   Satellite Antennae.  All satellite antennae placements shall be made
in accordance with all zoning restrictions and the following regulations:
      (1)   A permit is required prior to installation for all satellite
antenna systems.
      (2)   They shall be installed and maintained in compliance with all the
applicable Ohio Basic Building Code (OBBC), the National Electrical Code (NEC)
and manufacturing specifications and be properly grounded.
      (3)   Satellite antennae and associated guy wires shall meet all zoning
district setbacks. Rotatable satellite antennae must meet all required setback
requirements on the lot and/or parcel regardless of antenna directions.
      (4)   Any part of the satellite antenna shall have vertical and
horizontal clearance from any electrical line as required by applicable
provisions of the National Electrical Code.
      (5)   Pole-mounted and roof-mounted satellite antennae shall be in
compliance with the following:
         (a)   A pole-mounted satellite antenna may only be mounted on a single
pole and affixed to a dwelling or garage on the parcel or lot.
         (b)   Pole and roof-mounted satellite antennae require the submission
of plans to the City Engineer that meet or exceed all applicable requirements
of the Ohio Basic Building Code and the National Electrical Code.
      (6)   Maximum height requirements for all Residential District satellite
antennae shall be as follows:
         (a)   Ground-mounted antennae shall not exceed fifteen feet, including
the base, pedestal or other mounting device.
         (b)   Roof-mounted antennae shall not exceed twelve feet in height, 
including the base, pedestal or other mounting device as long as they do not
exceed the building height of the zoning district in which they are located.
         (c)   Pole-mounted antennae shall not exceed the maximum building
height of the zoning district in which they are located.  However, no
supporting pole shall exceed twelve feet in height above the main ridge of the
roof of an attached garage or dwelling.
      (7)   No signage of any type is permitted on a satellite antenna.
      (8)   All satellite antennae shall be supported from a fixed location.
      (9)   Satellite antennae are permitted anywhere on a lot notwithstanding
zoning setbacks, except in a front yard.
      (10)   There shall be no more than one satellite antenna per lot or
parcel.
      (11)   Any properly existing satellite antennae which are not in
conformity with this chapter on the date of its passage shall have a reasonable
time from the date of passage to come into conformity with this chapter.
   (C)   Citizen Band and Amateur Radio Antennae.  All poles, master towers and
antenna systems used in the operation of citizen band and amateur radios
regulated by the Federal Communication Commission (FCC) shall meet the
following requirements.
      (1)   They shall not exceed fifty feet in height unless such person
wishing to install the same presents to the City Engineer specifications or
plans indicating that the support structure meets or exceeds all accepted
engineering practices.  Upon denial, the person will have the right to appeal
as set forth in this chapter.
      (2)   Antenna systems shall meet all manufacturers specifications and
shall be of non-combustible and non-corrosive hardware.
      (3)   Every antenna must be adequately grounded.
      (4)   Guy wires, if necessary, support anchor structures, free-standing
towers and wire antennae are not permitted within a front yard.
      (5)   The person operating or owning a citizen band and/or amateur radio
must comply with all rules and regulations of the FCC and be licensed, if
required, by the FCC.
(Ord. 10-92.  Passed 2-24-92.)
854.10   AUTHORITY TO REINSPECT AND REQUIRE ALTERATIONS TO BE MADE.
   Nothing herein contained, nor the fact that any person has obtained a
certificate of approval, shall be construed to prevent the City, through its
duly authorized inspectors under the direction of the City Engineer, from
inspecting any antenna system in use in the City in order to ascertain whether
or not the same continues to remain in a safe condition and in compliance with
the terms of this chapter. In case any condition is found which might result in
danger to life or property, the City Engineer is authorized to give written
notice to the owner or operator of such antenna, at his last known address,
pointing out such condition and requiring the condition of the same to be
corrected within twenty-five days after such notice. If such conditions are not
corrected within such time, no owner or user of any such defective installation
shall maintain the same.
(Ord. 10-92.  Passed 2-24-92.)
854.11   DEMONSTRATION ANTENNA SYSTEMS.
   The provisions of this chapter requiring a permit and certificate of
approval shall not be applicable to antenna systems installed for demonstration
purposes where the duration of their existence does not exceed three days.
However, before any such demonstration antenna systems are installed, oral
approval therefor must be obtained from the office of the City Engineer. No fee
shall be charged for such oral approval.
(Ord. 10-92.  Passed 2-24-92.)
854.12   MINOR REPAIRS.
   Notwithstanding anything in this chapter to the contrary, minor repairs to
antenna elements may be made without the necessity of a permit or certificate
of approval, provided that a prompt report thereof is made to the City
Engineer. Should a check thereof by such official disclose defects, however,
the same must be pointed out and corrected in the manner set forth in this
chapter.
(Ord. 10-92.  Passed 2-24-92.)
854.13   NUISANCE.
   The City may declare a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter by
a licensee to be a nuisance, subject to abatement under Ohio R.C. 715.44.
(Ord. 10-92.  Passed 2-24-92.)
854.99   PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
802.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 856
Trailer and Tourist Camps

   Residential districts - see P. & Z. Ch.
