1404.01   INTERPRETATION; CONFLICTS.
   (A)   The provisions of this Building Code shall be construed to secure
their expressed intent and to insure the public safety, health and welfare
insofar as they are dependent upon building construction.
(Ord. 125-50. Passed 9-11-50.)
   (B)   The provisions of this Building Code shall be held to be the minimum
requirements to protect the health, safety, morals and welfare of the residents
of the City. When this Building Code imposes greater requirements than those
imposed by other provisions of law, the provisions of this Building Code shall
control.
(Ord. 36-61. Passed 4-17-61.)
1404.02   PLANS AND CONSTRUCTION; PROCEDURE. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE:  Section 1404.02 was repealed by Ordinance 087-07, passed
April 23, 2007, which adopted the Residential Code of Ohio.)
1404.03   SPECIAL TECHNICAL SERVICES.
   When applications for unusual technical design or magnitude of construction
are filed, the Building Commissioner may refer such plans and specifications to
whoever he feels is qualified for analysis and recommendation as to safety of
design and compliance with this Building Code or may retain a properly
qualified licensed engineer or registered architect to examine the application
for a specific building operation with respect to structural safety and
compliance with this Building Code and with all other statutory requirements.
1404.04   COORDINATED INSPECTIONS.
   The provisions of City laws, of State regulations and of the legally adopted
rules of local fire, health and labor officials with respect to the operation,
equipment, housekeeping, fire protection, handling and storage of flammable
materials, liquids and gases and maintenance of safe and sanitary conditions of
use and occupancy in all buildings shall be strictly enforced by the
administrative officials to whom such authority is delegated. Whenever
inspection by any authorized enforcement officer discloses any violation of the
provisions of this Building Code or of any other rule, regulation or law, he
shall immediately notify the administrative officer having jurisdiction of such
violation.
   (Ord. 125-50. Passed 9-11-50.)
1404.05   STOP WORK ORDERS.
   Unless otherwise provided herein, whenever any provision of this Building
Code, of a building permit, or of any ordinance or statute pertaining to this
Code or such a permit, are not complied with a written stop work order shall be
served by the Building Commissioner on the owner, his agent or the person
having charge of the work. A copy thereof shall be posted at the site of the
construction. Such stop work order shall not be removed or withdrawn except by
written permission of the Commissioner, after satisfactory evidence has been
supplied that the violation has been corrected. From and after the service and
posting of such stop work order, all labor shall be discontinued on any and all
portions of the building or structure for which such permit was granted and
shall not be resumed until the Commissioner has given written permission to do
so.
(Ord. 087-07.  Passed 4-23-07; Ord. 244-18.  Passed 10-8-18.)
1404.06   PROHIBITION AGAINST TRANSFER OF OWNERSHIP.
   No owner of any property, dwelling unit, or structure who has been served
with an Order or Notice from the Building Commissioner shall sell, transfer,
mortgage, lease or otherwise dispose of the property, dwelling unit, or
structure to another until the provisions of the Order or Notice have been
complied with, or until such owner shall first furnish the grantee, transferee,
mortgagee or lessee a copy of any Order or Notice issued by the Building
Commissioner, and furnish to the Building Commissioner a signed and notarized
statement from the grantee, transferee, mortgagee or lessee, acknowledging the
receipt of such Order or Notice and fully accepting the responsibility, without
condition, for making the corrections, repairs, or actions required by such
Order or Notice.
(Ord. 082-20.  Passed 4-20-20.)
1404.99   PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
Building Code, for which no penalty is otherwise provided, or erects, uses,
occupies, or maintains any building or structure in violation of any of the
provisions of this Building Code, or causes or permits such violation, or
fails, neglects or refuses to obey any lawful order made by the Building
Commissioner, for which no penalty is otherwise provided, is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the third degree and shall be fined not more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned not more than sixty days, or both. A separate
offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation or
noncompliance occurs or continues.
CHAPTER 1406
Building Appeals Board
1406.01   Composition, Term and Meetings.
1406.02   Appeals.
1406.03   Modifications and Variances.
1406.04   Decisions.
1406.05   Appeals from Decisions of the Board.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Authority of Council to establish boards - see CHTR. Sec.
83
   Ohio State building standards - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 3781; B & H.
1402.01(b)
   Variances - see P. & Z.
1244.05
   Dangerous buildings defined - see B. & H.
1420.05
1406.01   COMPOSITION, TERM AND MEETINGS.
   (a)   Appointment. There is hereby established in the City a Building
Appeals Board consisting of five members who are qualified by experience and
training to pass judgment upon matters pertaining to building construction and
who shall be appointed by the Mayor. The Mayor shall designate one of the
members to serve as Chairman. All members of the Board shall be residents of
the City.
   (b)   Term of Office. The Mayor shall appoint one member of the Building
Appeals Board for a term of one year, one for a term of two years, one for a
term of three years, one for a term of four years and one for a term of five
years. Thereafter, each member shall be appointed for a term of five years.
Vacancies shall be filled for an unexpired term in the manner in which original
appointments are made. Continued absence of any member from regular meetings of
the Board shall, at the discretion of the Mayor, render such member liable to
immediate removal from office by the Mayor.
   (c)   Quorum. Three members of the Board shall constitute a quorum. In
varying the application of any of the provisions of this Building Code or in
modifying an order of the Building Commissioner, the affirmative votes of three
members shall be required. No member of the Board shall vote upon any question
in which he, or any corporation in which he is a shareholder, is interested.
   (d)   Meetings and Records. Meetings of the Board shall be held at the call
of the Chairman and at such other times as the Board may determine. All
hearings before the Board shall be open to the public. The Board shall keep
minutes of its proceedings, showing the vote, or the absence or failure to vote
of each member upon every question, and shall also keep records of its
examinations and other official actions. The minutes  and records shall be
public records.
   (e)   Procedure. The Board shall establish rules and regulations for its own
procedure which are consistent with the provisions of this Building Code.
(Ord. 36-61. Passed 4-17-61.; Ord. 106-98. Passed 6-22-98.)
1406.02   APPEALS.
   (A)   Any aggrieved person or the principal officer of any agency of the
City may appeal to the Building Appeals Board from any decision of the Building
Commissioner. 
   (B)   An appeal shall be made within ten days from the date of the decision
appealed by filing with the Building Commissioner a notice of appeal,
specifying the grounds therefor. However, in the case of a building or
structure which, in the opinion of the Commissioner, is unsafe or dangerous,
the Commissioner may, in his order, limit the time for such appeal to a shorter
period. The Commissioner shall forthwith transmit to the Board all the papers
pertaining to the decision from which the appeal was made.
(Ord. 36-61. Passed 4-17-61.)
1406.03   MODIFICATIONS AND VARIANCES.
   (A)   Any appellant, the Building Commissioner and any other person whose
interests may be affected by the appeal shall be given a fair opportunity to be
heard, in person or by counsel, and to present written argument. 
   (B)   The Building Appeals Board, after a hearing in the presence of the
appellant and the Commissioner or their representatives, who have been given at
least seven days notice in advance of such hearing, shall have the power to
reverse or modify the order of the Commissioner, if it finds:
      (1)   That the order is contrary to this Building Code and any rule or
regulation made thereunder or contrary to a fair interpretation or application
thereof; or
      (2)   That a variance from the provisions of this Building Code or any
rule or regulation made thereunder, in the specific case, will not be contrary
to the public interest where a literal enforcement of such provisions will
result in unnecessary hardship. 
   (C)   A decision of the Board to vary the application of any of the
provisions of this Building Code or to modify an order of the Commissioner
shall specify the manner in which such variance or modification shall be made,
the conditions upon which it is made and the reasons therefor. 
   (D)   The Board shall, upon application from either the appellant or the
Commissioner, grant a rehearing before the Board in any case where new evidence
is presented which, in the opinion of the Chairman, justifies such rehearing.
The rehearing shall not serve to stop execution of the previous decision of the
Board pending the rehearing, unless the Board, by special action, so directs.
(Ord. 36-61. Passed 4-17-61.)
1406.04   DECISIONS.
   (A)   The Building Appeals Board shall in every case reach a decision
without unreasonable or unnecessary delay. Every decision shall be in writing,
shall indicate the vote upon the decision, shall be promptly filed in the
office of the Building Commissioner and shall be open to public inspection. A
certified copy of the decision shall be sent by mail or otherwise to the
appellant and a copy shall be kept publicly posted in the office of the
Commissioner for two weeks after filing. 
   (B)   If a decision of the Board reverses or modifies a refusal, order or
disallowance of the Building Commissioner or varies the application of any
provision of this Building Code, the Commissioner shall take action immediately
in accordance with such decision.
(Ord. 36-61. Passed 4-17-61.)
1406.05   APPEALS FROM DECISIONS OF THE BOARD.
   Any person aggrieved by a decision of the Building Appeals Board, whether
previously a party to the proceeding or not, or any officer or any board may,
after the filing of such decision in the office of the Building Commissioner,
appeal to the appropriate court in accordance with law.
(Ord. 36-61. Passed 4-17-61.)

1408.01   BUILDING PERMITS.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE:  Section 1408.01 was repealed by Ordinance 087-07, passed
April 23, 2007, which adopted the Residential Code of Ohio.)
1408.02   DEMOLITION PERMIT.
   (A)   (1)   Notwithstanding the provisions of Section
1408.01(c), a permit authorizing the demolition of any structure may be revoked
or suspended unless all demolition work covered by such permit is completed
within the following time limits:
   Type of Structure         Number of Days
   One-story dwelling         30
   Two-story dwelling         45
   Three-story dwelling         60
   One-story commercial building   45
   Two-story commercial building   60
   Three-story commercial building   75
   Four-story commercial building   90
      (2)   The period of time set forth above shall be deemed to commence from
the date of issuance of the permit.
      (3)   For any building more than four stories in height, an additional 15
days for each story in excess of four shall be allowed for completion.
      (4)   Apartment structures containing more than three family units shall
be considered commercial buildings for the purposes of this section.
      (5)   Upon receipt by the Building Commissioner of a written request from
the applicant, received at least ten days prior to the end of the original time
limit for such demolition, an extension of time not exceeding 30 days may be
granted by the Commissioner for the completion of the demolition work covered
by the permit, if the Commissioner determines that exceptional circumstances
exist.
   (B)   A permit authorizing demolition of any structure shall be void unless
such demolition is commenced within twenty days of the date of issuance of the
permit.
   (C)   (1)   All demolition work shall be completed to the specifications
required by the Building Commissioner within the time limits set forth above.
If the Commissioner determines the demolition is not completed according to
specifications or within the time limit set forth above, the Commissioner shall
order the person or other entity to whom the permit was issued to properly
complete the demolition.
      (2)   The order issued by the Commissioner shall be in writing, sent by
regular U.S. mail to the person or other entity at the address listed on the
permit or application therefor, shall describe the nature and manner of the
work to be completed, and shall order said work to be completed within fourteen
days of the date of the order.
   (D)   (1)   If the person or entity to whom an order is directed fails to
comply with the requirements of the order, the Building Commissioner shall
cause the demolition to be properly completed and may employ or contract for
the necessary labor to perform such work, including equipment, materials, and
supplies related thereto. All expenses for such demolition work shall be paid
out of funds appropriated by Council upon vouchers approved by the Mayor. The
expenses shall consist of the following:
            (a)   All direct costs for the completion of the demolition; plus
            (b)   An administrative fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
      (2)   In the event the person or other entity to whom an order is
directed fails to pay such expenses within 30 days after being notified of the
amount thereof by the Commissioner, in writing, by regular U.S. mail, the
expenses set forth above may be collected using one or more of the following
methods, provided, however, that the expenses may only be collected once:
            (a)   Such expenses may be certified by Council to the County
Auditor and placed upon the tax duplicate for collection as a special
assessment and thereupon shall be collected as other taxes and assessments; or
            (b)   The Director of Law is authorized to bring suit and take
other necessary legal action to collect all such expenses.
   (E)   The remedies provided in this section shall be in addition to any
other penalty provided in these Codified Ordinances and any other remedy
allowed by law.
(Ord. 89-97.  Passed 6-2-97.)
1408.03   PERMIT REVOCATION.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE:  Section 1408.03 was repealed by Ordinance 087-07, passed
April 23, 2007, which adopted the Residential Code of Ohio.)
1408.04   FEES.
   (A)   Before receiving a building permit, an owner or his or her agent shall
pay the fees provided in division (F) of this section. Such fees shall include
the costs of the prescribed inspections to determine whether or not the actual
construction or alteration permitted is in conformity with this Building Code.
   (B)   When work for which a permit is required by this Building Code is
begun prior to obtaining a permit, the fees shall be doubled.  However, the
payment of the doubled fees shall not relieve any person from full compliance
with the requirements of this Building Code, in the execution of the work, or
from any penalty provided.  In no event shall the penalty portion of the
doubled fees exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00).
   (C)   If there are any changes in the plans and specifications at any time
before the completion of the work for which a permit has been granted, if such
changes are in compliance with this Building Code and if such changes or
additions increase the cost of the work to be done, then an additional permit
shall be obtained for each such change.  The fee for each such additional
permit shall result in a total permit fee the same as the fee charged for one
permit. However, no refund of the fee will be made in the event that such
changes involve a decrease in the cost of the work to be performed.
   (D)   "Estimated cost", as used in division (F) of this section and as
applicable to residential, commercial or industrial structures, means the
current cost, as of the date of the permit, of all materials, equipment and
labor used in any new construction, alteration or repair, including, but not
limited to, plumbing, heating, air conditioning, refrigeration, lighting and
electrical equipment and work, but not including items not normally a component
part of such construction, alteration or repair, such as furnishings or
manufacturing machinery. The cost may be determined, computed or estimated by
the Building Commissioner in accordance with generally accepted methods.
   (E)   Fees for items not specifically provided for by this Building Code
shall be assigned by the Building Commissioner in a manner that is reasonable
and appropriate, subject to appeal to the Building Appeals Board.
   (F)   For construction within the City on buildings and structures subject
to the Ohio Basic Building Code, the permit fee shall be eighteen dollars
($18.00) for the first one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) of the estimated cost,
plus one dollar and twenty cents ($1.20) per one hundred dollars ($100.00) of
the estimated cost in excess of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), up to and
including fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00). The permit fee shall be
ninety-six cents ($0.96) per one hundred dollars ($100.00) of the estimated
cost between fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) and nine hundred eighty-five
thousand dollars ($985,000.00).  The permit fee shall be thirty-six cents
($0.36) per one hundred dollars ($100.00) of the estimated cost between nine
hundred eighty-five thousand dollars ($985,000.00) and two million dollars
($2,000,000.00). The permit fee shall be eighteen cents ($0.18) per one hundred
dollars ($100.00) of the estimated cost between two million dollars
($2,000,000.00) and five million dollars ($5,000,000.00). The permit fee shall
be twelve cents ($0.12) per one hundred dollars ($100.00) of the estimated cost
above five million dollars ($5,000,000.00). The minimum fee shall be eighteen
dollars ($18.00).
   (G)   For construction on buildings and structures subject to the Ohio Basic
Building Code and owned by a school, the permit fees established by this
division shall be as set forth in section 1490.01 of this Code.
   (H)   Residential building, roofing and siding construction fees within the
city shall be established as set forth in section
1490.01 of this Code.
   (I)   The fee for any inspection of an existing structure, or part thereof,
or other special service, shall be as set forth in section
1490.01 of this Code.
   (J)   The fees established herein shall not be charged for work to be
performed upon property owned by an agency of the Federal government or the
City.  The fees established herein shall not be charged for work to be
performed upon property owned by a school for construction work with total
estimated cost of less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00).
   (K)   There shall be a plan examination fee, for those structures subject to
the Ohio Basic Building Code, as set forth in section
1490.01 of this Code.  There shall be an additional fee for plans requiring
accelerated review, also set forth in section
1490.01 of this Code.  Such fees shall be paid at the time of submission of
plans to the City.
   (L)   All building permit fees and plan examination fees shall have a 5%
additional charge over the fees set forth herein, on permit fees subject to the
Ohio Basic Building Code.
   (M)   For commercial structures erected for an intended period of less than
180 days, there shall be a permit fee as set forth in section
1490.01 of this Code.
   (N)   No permit shall be issued for the construction, erection, alteration
or maintenance of any sign or outdoor display structure, any part of which
projects or hangs over a public sidewalk or street, until the applicant has
furnished the following to the Building Commissioner:
      (1)   Proof that he or she is duly licensed to engage in the business of
constructing, erecting, maintaining or altering signs or outdoor display
structures or of posting bills or painting signs, under the provisions of
Chapter 866 of these Codified Ordinances.
      (3)   Evidence that he or she has public liability insurance in effect
with an insurance company qualified to write such insurance under the laws of
the State, in an amount not in excess of the maximum specified herein, deemed
by the Commissioner adequate to cover any such lawful claims for damages.
If the applicant holds or is applying for more than one permit, he or she may
cover as many signs as he or she chooses by one insurance policy.  In the event
of such multiple coverage, the amount of insurance coverage required shall be
fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for property damage and three hundred
thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for general liability, regardless of the number
of signs such insurance covers.
(Ord. 8-97.  Passed 1-6-97; Ord. 132-01.  Passed 8-20-01.; Ord. 61-11. Passed
3- 14-11; Ord. 131-11. Passed 6-20-11.)
1408.05   CERTIFICATES OF OCCUPANCY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE:  Section 1408.05 was repealed by Ordinance 087-07, passed
April 23, 2007, which adopted the Residential Code of Ohio.)
1408.051   LAW ENFORCEMENT INSPECTION AUTHORIZED.
   (A)   Any sworn law enforcement officer having law enforcement authority
inside the City of Lima is hereby authorized to perform an inspection of any
occupied building for which a Certificate of Occupancy has been issued or is
required, and to take enforcement action to ensure compliance with the maximum
occupancy limits set forth in such Certificate of Occupancy. 
   (B)   Any building being occupied in excess of the maximum number of persons
permitted by the Certificate of Occupancy may be ordered to be vacated by all
guests or visitors if the person in charge or control of the building fails to
appropriately reduce the occupancy to within the maximum occupancy limits set
forth in such Certificate of Occupancy. 
(Ord. 247-09.  Passed 10-26-2009.)

   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
1404.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 1409
SPECIAL BUILDING CRITERIA WITHIN THE DESIGN REVIEW DISTRICT

   Required submission of plans of public buildings - see Ohio R.C. 3791.04
   Fees for plan approval - see Ohio R.C. 3791. 07
   Construction permits for sidewalks, driveways and curbs - see S.U. & P.S.

1409.01   DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this Chapter, unless otherwise expressly provided, or unless the
context clearly indicates that a different meaning is intended, the following
words shall be deemed to have the corresponding definition:
   (A)   Alter or Alteration:  Any Change in or to an external architectural
feature of any Structure within the Design Review District.
   (B)   Applicant:  Any owner, person, association, partnership, corporation,
or entity that applies for a Certificate of Appropriateness in order to
undertake any alteration to a Structure within the Design Review District.
   (C)   Application:  An application for a Certificate of Appropriateness
   (D)   Architectural Feature:  The architectural style of any building (new
or existing general design, and general arrangement of the exterior of a
structure including, but not limited to, windows, doors, porches, signage,
colors, landscaping, cornices, exterior surface materials, decorative trim, or
other fixtures of or appurtenant to the exterior of the structure).
   (E)   Certificate of Appropriateness:  A certificate issued by the Design
Review Board to authorize any Alteration to any Structure within the Design
Review District.
   (F)   New Construction or Change:  Any construction, remodeling, demolition,
removal, or other type of modification to or involving the exterior of any
Structure or piece of real property within the Design Review District,
including signage, painting and landscaping.
   (G)   Design Review District:  The downtown area of the City within the
following geographical boundaries:  from the CSX tracks on the north to the
Ottawa River on the south, and from the CSX tracks on the east to the center of
Metcalf Street on the west.
   (H)   Member:  Any member of the Design Review Board.
   (I)   Owner:  The fee simple owner of record.
   (J)   Review Board or Board:  The Design Review Board established under this
Chapter.
   (K)   Structure: Any place, building, work of art, fixture, or similar
object, not including unimproved real estate unless expressly provided. 
(Ord. 187-03. Passed 10-20-03; Ord. 218-05. Passed 11-21-05.)
1409.02   ESTABLISHMENT OF THE DESIGN REVIEW BOARD.
   (A)   There is hereby established the Design Review Board which shall have
the powers and duties as hereinafter set forth.  The Design Review Board shall
consist of seven members who shall be appointed as set forth herein. Members to
be appointed should have a demonstrated knowledge or interest in the
preservation and continued use of the City’s historic resources and a
determination to work for the overall improvement of the physical and economic
quality of the City’s architectural environment, with due regard for the need
for balance among diverse community and property owner interests.
   (B)   Members of the Board shall be appointed in the following manner:
      (1)   The Mayor shall appoint one member who shall be a representative of
the arts, cultural, or religious institutions within the Design Review
District, and two members who shall be either property owners within the Design
Review District, or individuals who own or operate a business within the Design
Review District;
      (2)   The Board of Trustees of Downtown Lima, Inc. shall appoint one
member who belongs to Downtown Lima, Inc.; one member who belongs to Downtown
Lima, Inc. and is engaged in retail trade; one member who is an architect or
design professional.
      (3)   The City Planning Commission shall appoint one member, who shall be
on the Commission.
      (4)   The appointing person or entity may remove any member at any time. 
Council may remove any member at any time during a regularly-scheduled meeting
upon motion and affirmative vote of a majority of elected Council members.
      (5)   All members must be confirmed by Council, and all members must be
either City residents or individuals who own or operate a business within the
Design Review District.
(Ord. 141-01. Passed 9-24-01; Ord. 133-17.  Passed 6-19-17.)
1409.03   POWERS AND DUTIES OF THE DESIGN REVIEW BOARD.
   (A)   The Board shall develop a “Policies and Procedures Manual” that
establishes guidelines for meetings, hearings, application contents, submittal
and review, and any other guidelines or procedures necessary for making
decisions within the District.  A majority of the membership of the Board shall
constitute a quorum, and any action or decision of the Board shall have the
support of a majority of its members. The Policies and Procedures Manual, and
any amendments thereto, must be approved by Council.
   (B)   In accordance with the terms of this Chapter and the Policies and
Procedures Manual, the Design Review Board shall evaluate any proposed
Alteration to any Structure or New Construction within the Design Review
District.  In reviewing any proposed Alteration or New Construction, the Board
shall use as evaluative criteria the Downtown Lima Design Guidelines,
incorporated herein and  appended hereto as Appendix A.  In the case of
archeological properties, the Design Review Board shall refer to the current
edition of the “Advisory Council on Historic Preservation’s Treatment of
Archeological Properties: A Handbook.”  A copy of Appendix A and such handbook
shall be kept on file for public inspection in the office of the Building
Commissioner.
(Ord. 218-05. Passed 11-21-05.)
1409.04   CERTIFICATES REQUIRED.
   (A)   No Alteration of any Structure or New Construction within the Design
Review District shall be undertaken prior to obtaining a Certificate of
Appropriateness from the Design Review Board, and a Certificate of Occupancy
from the Building Commissioner.  No Permit or Certificate of Occupancy shall be
issued by the Building Commissioner for any such Alteration or New Construction
unless the Design Review Board has first issued a Certificate of
Appropriateness.
   (B)   A Certificate of Appropriateness shall not be required by the Building
Commissioner for Alteration of any existing residential structure within the
Design Review District which is used and designed as a one or two family
dwelling unit, as defined in the Ohio Basic Building Code, and continues in
this residential use. 
(Ord. 188-03. Passed 10-20-03; Ord. 218-05. Passed 11-21-05.)
1409.05   CERTIFICATE OF APPROPRIATENESS; APPROVAL.
   (A)   When any owner intends to make an Alteration to any Structure or cause
New Construction within the Design Review District, the owner shall first apply
for and obtain a Certificate of Appropriateness from the Design Review Board. 
The application for a Certificate shall be filed with the Building Commissioner
together with such plans, specifications, photographs of the Structure subject
to the proposed Alteration or New Construction, and any other documents or
material that the Design Review Board may from time to time request.  The
Building Commissioner shall immediately transmit such application, documents
and materials to the Design Review Board.
   (B)   Within thirty (30) days of filing of the application with the Building
Commissioner, the Board shall consider the application and all supporting
material and determine 1) whether any Alteration or New Construction as defined
in this Chapter is involved, and 2) whether a Certificate of Appropriateness
should be issued or denied.  If the Board determines that no Alteration or New
Construction is involved the Certificate of Appropriateness shall be approved
and forwarded to the applicant.  A copy of the approved Certificate and all
application materials shall be returned to the Building Commissioner.  If the
Board fails to act on an application within thirty (30) days of filing, the
application shall be deemed approved, unless the owner consents, in writing, to
an extension of the 30 day period.
   (C)   In the event the Design Review Board finds that an Alteration or New
Construction is involved in the work proposed in the application, the Board
shall determine whether the proposed Alteration or New Construction is
consistent or inconsistent with the Downtown Lima Design Guidelines (Appendix
A).  In the case of archeological properties, the Design Review Board shall
refer to the current edition of the “Advisory Council on Historic
Preservation’s Treatment of Archeological Properties: A Handbook.”  If the
Board finds that the proposed Alteration or New Construction is consistent with
the Guidelines or Handbook, then the Board shall approve and issue a
Certificate of Appropriateness to the Owner.
   A copy of the approved Certificate and all application materials shall be
returned to the Building Commissioner.
   (D)   In the event the Design Review Board determines within the thirty (30)
day review period that a Certificate of Appropriateness should not be issued,
it shall issue a conditional denial of the application and state in writing the
reason for such determination, and shall include recommendations with respect
to the proposed work.  The Board shall forthwith notify the Applicant and the
Building Commissioner of such determination and transmit to the Applicant a
copy of the reasons for the conditional denial, along with any recommendations
by the Review Board.
   (E)   Upon issuing a conditional denial the Design Review Board shall impose
a waiting period of at least thirty (30) days, but not to exceed ninety (90)
days from the date of denial. During this time the Board shall negotiate with
the Applicant in order to develop a compromise proposal acceptable to both
parties.  The first meeting between the Board and the Applicant shall be held
within thirty (30) days from the date of the conditional denial of the
Certificate of Appropriateness.  If a compromise proposal is accepted by both
parties, the Board may issue a Certificate of Appropriateness for the revised
application.
   (F)   In the case of a conditional denial of a Certificate of
Appropriateness for any Alteration or New Construction not including
demolition:
      (1)   The Design Review Board and the Applicant shall undertake
meaningful and continuing discussion during the waiting period in order to find
an alternative to the proposed Alteration or New Construction.  If the Board
and the Applicant do not agree on an alternative solution at the initial
meeting, then they must continue to undertake meaningful discussions for the
purpose of seeking a compromise solution, and such good faith meetings shall be
held at least every thirty(30) days after the initial meeting, not to extend
beyond the waiting period unless agreed to in writing by the Applicant.
      (2)   If, after holding such good faith meetings during the waiting
period, the Board determines that a failure to issue a Certificate of
Appropriateness will create a substantial hardship to the Applicant, and that
such Certificate may be issued without substantial detriment to the public
welfare and without substantial derogation from the purposes of this Chapter,
then, the Board shall issue a Certificate of Appropriateness for such proposed
Alteration or New Construction to the Applicant.
      (3)   If, after holding such good faith meetings during the waiting
period, no alternative solution to the proposed Alteration or New Construction
is reached, or if the Applicant fails to meet with the Design Review Board in
good faith at the time specified, then the Board shall issue a final denial of
the Certificate of Appropriateness.
   (G)   In the case of a conditional denial of a Certificate of
Appropriateness for demolition:
      (1)   The Design Review Board and the Applicant shall undertake a
meaningful and continuing discussion during the waiting period in order to find
a means of preserving the Structure.  The Board and the Applicant shall
investigate all means of preserving the Structure.  If the Board and the
Applicant do not agree on a means of preserving the structure at the initial
meeting, then they must continue to undertake meaningful and continuing
discussions for the purpose of finding a method of saving the Structure, and
such good faith meetings shall be held at least every thirty(30) days after the
initial meeting, not to extend beyond the waiting period unless agreed to in
writing by the Applicant.
      (2)   If, after holding such good faith meetings during the waiting
period, the Design Review Board determines that a failure to issue a
Certificate of Appropriateness will create a substantial hardship to the
Applicant, and that such Certificate may be issued without substantial
detriment to the public welfare and without substantial derogation from the
purposes of this Chapter, then the Board shall issue a Certificate of
Appropriateness for such proposed demolition.
      (3)   If, after holding such good faith meetings during the waiting
period, no alternative property use is developed, or no offer to save the
structure is made by the Applicant, the Design Review Board, or a third party,
or if the Applicant fails to meet with the Board in good faith, at the time
specified, then the Board shall issue a final denial of the application.
(Ord. 218-05. Passed 11-21-05.)
1409.06   APPEALS.
   Any Applicant who receives a final denial of an Application to Alter a
Structure or New Construction may appeal the decision of the Design Review
Board to the Lima City Council by serving a notice of the appeal to the Clerk
of Council within fourteen (14) days of the date of the decision of final
denial.  Such appeal shall be heard by Council as an administrative appeal. 
Council may affirm, reverse, or modify the decision of the Review Board as it
determines to be appropriate.  Any person adversely affected by a decision of
Council under this Chapter may appeal to the Allen County Common Pleas Court,
according to law.
(Ord. 218-05. Passed 11-21-05.)
1409.07   GENERAL MAINTENANCE AND UPKEEP.
   Any Owner of any Structure within the Design Review District must provide
sufficient maintenance and upkeep for such Structure to ensure its perpetuation
and to preserve and protect the Structure from destruction by deterioration.
(Ord. 141-01. Passed 9-24-01.)
1409.08   CITY PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT.
   The City Public Works Department shall provide administrative support to and
for the Design Review Board as determined appropriate by the Mayor, but no city
employee shall be required to provide advice or recommendations to the Board
except as may be appropriate in the ordinary course of their duties.
(Ord. 141-01. Passed 9-24-01.)
1409.09   EXCLUSIONS.
   Nothing in this Chapter shall be construed to prevent the ordinary
maintenance or repair of any Structure within the Design Review District,
provided such work involves no change in material, design, texture, or outer
appearance.  Any Alteration of any Structure which in the view of the Building
Commissioner is required or desirable for the public health or safety because
of an unsafe or dangerous condition shall not be subject to the provisions of
this Chapter, as may be determined in the discretion of the Building
Commissioner.
(Ord. 141-01. Passed 9-24-01.)
1409.99   PENALTIES.
   (A)   Excluding demolition, whoever Alters any Structure or causes New
Construction in violation of this Chapter shall be guilty of a minor
misdemeanor and shall be fined $75.00 for each day the violation continues. 
Each day of violation shall be deemed a separate and distinct violation for as
long as one (1) year.  The City may also seek an injunction to stop any
unlawful work.
   (B)   Whoever demolishes any exterior feature of any Structure in violation
of this Chapter shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor and fined $100.00 for
each day the violation continues.  Each day of violation shall be deemed a
separate and distinct violation for as long as two (2) years.  The City may
seek an injunction to stop any unlawful demolition.
   (C)   Any owner who allows for the deterioration of an historic property
through neglect or negligence shall be deemed to be guilty of a minor
misdemeanor fined $50.00 a day for each day the violation continues.  Each day
of violation shall be deemed a separate and distinct violation for as long as
one (1) year. 
(Ord. 218-05. Passed 11-21-05.)

1410.01   BUILDING COMMISSIONER; APPOINTMENT.
   (a)   Until otherwise determined by Council, the City Building Administrator
shall be the Building Commissioner.  The Building Commissioner shall be in
charge of the Building Inspection Division of the Department of Public Works
and shall perform such duties as are imposed upon the Commissioner by this
Building Code and by other ordinances.
   (b)   Any Assistant Building Administrator shall act as Assistant Building
Commissioner.  The Mayor shall have the power to designate an Acting Building
Commissioner who, during the absence or disability of the Commissioner, shall
have the power to perform the duties of the Commissioner.
(Ord. 125-50. Passed 9-11-50; Ord. 148-00.  Passed 8-7-00; Ord. 245-18.  Passed
10-8-18.)
1410.02   QUALIFICATIONS.
   To be eligible to appointment, the Building Commissioner shall meet the
qualifications of the City classification specification for the position of
Building and Zoning Administrator, as approved by the Civil Service Board and
City Council. The Commissioner shall have no interest, directly or indirectly,
in the sale or manufacture of any material, process or device entering into,
used in or used in connection with building construction.
(Ord. 125-50. Passed 9-11-50; Ord. 148-00.  Passed 8-7-00.)
1410.03   RECORDS.
   The Building Commissioner shall keep records on file in the Commissioner's
office, which records shall contain the location and character of every
building, structure or other work for which a certificate or permit is issued
and a dated copy of every inspection report thereon. Such records shall be so
arranged that the full history of the various inspections of each building,
structure or other work appears in consecutive order. All original notes or
records made by the Commissioner and the Assistant Commissioners shall be
signed and properly filed for permanent record.
(Ord. 125-50. Passed 9-11-50; Ord. 148-00.  Passed 8-7-00.)
1410.04   RELIEF FROM PERSONAL LIABILITY.
   The Building Commissioner, or any official, officer or employee charged with
the enforcement of any of the provisions of this Building Code, shall not be
personally liable while acting for the City and is hereby relieved from all
personal liability for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a
result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of the Commissioner's
official duties.
(Ord. 125-50. Passed 9-11-50; Ord. 148-00.  Passed 8-7-00.)
1410.05   DUTIES.
   The Building Commissioner shall receive applications required by this
Building Code, issue permits, furnish certificates and have authority to revoke
permits as provided herein. The Commissioner shall examine premises for which
permits have been issued and make necessary inspections to see that the
provisions of law are complied with and that construction is prosecuted safely.
The Commissioner shall enforce all laws relating to the construction,
alteration, repair, removal, demolition, equipment, use and occupancy, location
and maintenance of buildings and structures, except as may be otherwise
provided.  The Commissioner shall, when requested by the Mayor or Council or
when the interests of the City so require, make investigations in connection
with matters referred to in this Building Code and render written reports
thereon. In order to enforce compliance with law, to remove illegal or unsafe
conditions, to secure the necessary safeguards during construction or to
require adequate exit facilities in existing buildings and structures, the
Commissioner shall issue such notices or orders as may be necessary.
(Ord. 125-50. Passed 9-11-50; Ord. 148-00.  Passed 8-7-00.)
1410.06   INSPECTIONS.
   (A)   Authority of Building Commissioner.  All construction or work for
which a permit is required shall be subject to inspection by the Building
Commissioner.
   (B)   Inspection Record Card.  Work requiring a building permit shall not be
begun until the permit holder or the holder's agent has posted an inspection
record card in a conspicuous place on the front of the premises and in such
position as to allow the Commissioner to conveniently make the necessary
entries thereon for inspections of the work.
   (C)   Written Approval Required.
      (1)   No work shall be done on any part of a building or structure beyond
the point indicated in each successive inspection without first obtaining the
written approval of the Commissioner.  Such approval shall be given only after
an inspection has been made of each successive step in the construction, as
required by division(d) of this section.
      (2)   There shall be a final inspection and approval of all buildings
when completed and ready for occupancy. 
   (D)   Required Inspections. 
      (1)   No reinforcing steel, structural framework or any part of a
building or structure shall be covered or concealed in any manner without first
obtaining the approval of the Commissioner.
      (2)   It shall be the responsibility of the permit holder to notify the
Commissioner when work is ready for the various inspections required by this
Building Code. Such notice shall be given a reasonable time in advance of the
time such inspection is desired, but in no event shall the notice be less than
24 hours prior to the time of inspection.
      (3)   The Commissioner, upon notification from the permit holder or the
holder's agent, shall make the following inspections of buildings and shall
either approve the portion of construction as completed or notify the permit
holder or the holder's agent wherein the completed portion fails to comply with
the law:
         (a)   A foundation and footing inspection, to be made after the
trenches are excavated and the form erected and when all materials are either
on the job site or are being delivered (such as transit-mixed concrete);
         (b)   A frame inspection, to be made after the roof, all framing,
fire- blocking and bracing is in place and all pipes, chimneys and vents are
completed; and
         (c)   A final inspection, to be made after the building is completed
and ready for occupancy.
      (4)   No person shall cover, prior to inspection, any work required to be
inspected under the provisions of this Building Code. The Commissioner shall
require the holder of the permit to uncover such work for inspection, and the
cost of uncovering such work and of replacing the cover after the work has been
found satisfactory shall be borne by the holder of the permit.  The remedy
provided herein shall be in addition to the penalty provided in Section
1404.99. 
   (E)   Additional Inspections.  The Commissioner may make such additional
inspections of any construction work as are necessary to ascertain compliance
with the provisions of this Building Code or other laws which are enforced by
the Building Inspection Division. 
   (F)   Special Inspections.  In addition to the required inspections, the
Commissioner may require the owner or the owner's agent to employ a special
inspector who shall be present at all times on special construction or on work
involving unusual hazards or requiring constant inspection.  The special
inspector shall be a qualified person approved by the Commissioner.
(Ord. 36-61. Passed 4-17-61; Ord. 148-00.  Passed 8-7-00.)
1410.07   RIGHT OF ENTRY.
   The Building Commissioner and all deputies, assistants, employees or other
persons assigned to cooperate with the Commissioner by City departments, so far
as may be necessary for the performance of their duties, shall have the right
to enter any building, any building under construction, repair, alteration or
removal, or any building which the Commissioner has reasonable cause to believe
is unsafe, a menace to life or limb or damaged or menaced by fire.
(Ord. 125-50. Passed 9-11-50; Ord. 148-00.  Passed 8-7-00.)
1410.08   HAZARDOUS CONDITIONS.
   (A)   Notice.  When any heating apparatus, chimney, flue, pipe or other
equipment or structure of a building is a danger to life or property or is
likely to cause or promote fires or explosions, it shall be the duty of the
Building Commissioner, upon finding any such defective or dangerous conditions,
or any construction in violation of this Building Code, to cause to be
delivered to the owner, lessee or occupant, written instructions to remove or
remedy the same in such manner and within such reasonable time as may be
necessary. 
   (B)   Failure to Remedy; Abatement.  If the person responsible for any
dangerous condition or violation referred to in division(a) of this section
fails to remove or remedy the same, it shall be the further duty of the
Building Commissioner to cause proceedings to be instituted to enjoin the
continuance or use thereof.
(Ord. 125-50. Passed 9-11-50; Ord. 148-00.  Passed 8-7-00.)
1410.99   PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE:  See Section
1404.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)

1412.01   PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall in any way or manner use any public street or other public
space by depositing thereon building materials or other materials or equipment,
without first obtaining a permit therefor from the Building Commissioner.
(1956 Code Sec. 15.1)
1412.02   TERM AND RENEWAL.
   Permits for the use of public streets and other public spaces shall not be
granted for more than four months. However, such permits may be renewed from
time to time for periods not exceeding four months.
(1956 Code Sec. 15.2)
1412.03   APPLICATION.
   Any application for a permit required by this chapter shall describe the
space to be used and the length of time described for such use.
(1956 Code Sec. 15.3)
1412.04   AUTHORITY OF BUILDING COMMISSIONER.
   The amount of space used shall be determined by the Building Commissioner.
(1956 Code Sec. 15.4)
1412.05   PERMIT FEE; PERFORMANCE DEPOSIT.
   The Building Commissioner shall, for each permit issued as required by
Section
1412.01, collect a fee of ten dollars ($10.00). At the time of issuing such
permit, he shall require a deposit of not less than twenty-five dollars
($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) as a guarantee of
compliance with the provisions of this chapter. The City may, from such
deposit, pay any expenses incurred by it in performing any work required by the
provisions of this chapter which the permittee refuses or neglects to do.
(Ord. 176-91.  Passed 7-8-91.)
1412.06   PERMIT REVOCATION; RESTORATION.
   The Building Commissioner shall have the authority to revoke any permit for
the occupancy of any public street or space if the public use of such street or
space necessitates such revocation. The person to whom such permit was issued
shall remove the material from such street or space and restore the same to its
former condition within ten days after having been notified to do so by the
Commissioner.
(1956 Code Sec. 15.6)
1412.07   DEPOSITS OF BUILDING MATERIALS GENERALLY.
   Building material shall not be deposited within ten feet of any fire cistern
or hydrant. The outside line of any deposited material shall not extend into
the street farther than one-third the distance from curb to curb of such street
or into the sidewalk farther than one-half its width. Gutters shall be kept
clean and free from all obstruction.
(1956 Code Sec. 16.1)
1412.08   MIXING OF CEMENT, MORTAR AND CONCRETE.
   No lime, cement, mortar or concrete shall be mixed upon any street or
sidewalk in the City except in boxes, the bottoms of which boxes shall be
tight-tongued with grooved boards. Such boxes shall be placed upon four-inch
bearers or sleepers, thereby leaving an air space, shall be protected on all
sides by a margin of two-inch boards and shall be not less than six inches
above the floor space.
   Upon completion of the work in which such mortar boxes are used, the streets
or sidewalks shall be thoroughly cleaned, and all mortar, sand, gravel, refuse
matter and building materials of any kind shall be completely removed.
(1956 Code Sec. 16.2)
1412.09   WARNING LIGHT REQUIRED.
   Whenever any public street or other space is used as provided in this
chapter, the person so using such street or other space shall place and keep
thereon, from sunset to sunrise, a warning light of red or amber glass or other
acceptable light, so placed as to be visible to street traffic. Whenever the
space occupied exceeds ten feet in length or width one such light shall be
placed at each end thereof.
(1956 Code Sec. 16.3)
1412.10   USE OF DERRICKS AND HOISTING APPARATUS.
   No person shall erect and use any derrick or hoisting apparatus exceeding
fifty feet in height on any street or sidewalk in the City, for the purpose of
erecting, changing or repairing any building or structure, without first
obtaining a special permit therefor. Such permit shall be issued under such
conditions as may be required by the Building Commissioner.
(1956 Code Sec. 16.4)
1412.11   TEMPORARY SIDEWALKS AND BRIDGES.
   Whenever any person is about to erect, change or repair any building within
five feet of the line of a traveled street, such person shall build and
maintain a temporary sidewalk or bridge, not less than four feet or more than
six feet in width, contiguous to the lot line of the premises on which the
building is to be erected. The sidewalk or bridge shall be constructed in such
manner as the Building Commissioner directs. When the building is one story
high, the sidewalk or bridge shall be roofed and provided with barricades so as
to completely protect passers-by and shall be properly lighted from sunset to
sunrise. A warning light of red or amber glass shall be hung at each end
thereof at all times between sunset and sunrise so as to be visible to
pedestrians on such sidewalks.
(1956 Code Sec. 16.5)
1412.12   DEMOLITION OF BUILDINGS.
   All the provisions, conditions, restrictions, limitations and fee and
deposit requirements provided in this chapter shall apply to and be enforced in
regard to the wrecking, tearing down, demolishing and removing of any and all
buildings, as well as to the construction and erection thereof.
(1956 Code Sec. 16.6)
1412.99   PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
1404.99 for general Code penalty if no specific  penalty is provided.)

1414.01   PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall move or cause to be moved in, on, upon or over any street or
other public place in the City any house, barn or other building without first
obtaining a permit therefor from the Building Commissioner.
(1956 Code Sec. 11.1)
1414.02   INSIDE FIRE LIMITS. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section 1414.02 was repealed by implication by Ordinance
147-85, passed July 29, 1985.)
1414.03   OUTSIDE FIRE LIMITS.
   (A)   Buildings having dimensions, including the building, the moving
vehicle and any other moving apparatus, not exceeding twelve feet six inches in
height, eight feet in width and forty-five feet in length, may be moved upon or
over any street outside the fire limits, as set forth in Section 1422.01, only
upon obtaining a permit therefor from the Building Commissioner.
   (B)   Houses and other buildings exceeding the dimensions specified in
subsection (A) hereof may he moved upon or over streets outside the fire
limits, as set forth in Section 1422.01, only upon obtaining a permit therefor
from the Building Commissioner and approval thereof by Council.
(Ord. 90-56. Passed 6-11-56.)
1414.04   BOND REQUIRED.
   (A)   Before the issuance of any permit allowing the moving of any building
specified in Section
1414.03(A) along any route, the applicant shall furnish cash, a certified check
or a surety bond in an amount, not less than one thousand dollars ($1,000), to
be approved by the Building Commissioner providing for the payment of any
damage which may he done to public or private property by such moving. Such
applicant shall hold the City harmless from any liability, judgment, damage,
cost and expense which may in any way accrue against the City in consequence of
the granting of such permit or the performance of any work thereunder.
   (B)   Before the issuance of any permit allowing the moving of any house or
other building specified in Section
1414.03(B) along any route, the applicant shall furnish cash, a certified check
or a surety bond in an amount, not less than three thousand dollars ($3,000),
to be approved by the Building Commissioner, providing for the payment of any
damage which may be done to public or private property by such moving. Such
applicant shall hold the City harmless from any liability, judgment, damage,
cost and expense which may in any way accrue against the City in consequence of
the granting of such permit or the performance of any work thereunder.
(Ord. 90-56. Passed 6-11-56.)
1414.05   PERMIT FEES.
   (A)   Any person to whom a permit is granted for the moving of a building
specified in Section
1414.03(A) shall pay, upon receiving such permit, a fee of five dollars ($5.00)
for each day, or portion of a day, that such building is on the public streets
of the City, for the privilege of moving such building over the streets.
(Ord. 90-56. Passed 6-11-56.)
   (B)   Any person to whom a permit is granted for the moving of a house or
other building specified in Section
1414.03(B) shall pay, upon receiving such permit, a fee of fifty dollars
($50.00) for each day, or portion of a day, that such building is on the public
streets of the City, for the privilege of moving such building over such
streets.
(Ord. 83-71. Passed 4-12-71.)
1414.06   CONFORMITY REQUIRED.
   No person moving a building under the provisions of this chapter shall fail
to conform to the rules prescribed therefor by the Building Commissioner.
(1956 Code Sec. 11.6)
1414.99   PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
1404.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
