1468.01   REGISTRATION AND LICENSE REQUIRED
   (A)   No person shall engage in the business of electrical contracting in
the corporate limits of the City without having first registered as an
electrical contractor with the City as provided for in Section
1468.04.
   (B)   No person shall engage in the trade of a journeyman electrician in the
corporate limits of the City, without first having obtained a license as a
journeyman electrician in accordance with the provisions of Section
1468.06.
(Ord. 157-01.  Passed 10-22-01; Ord. 140-17.  Passed 6-19-17; Ord. 120-20. 
Passed 7-6-20.)
1468.02   REGISTRATION AND LICENSE RENEWAL
   Failure of an electrical contractor or journeyman electrician to renew a
registration or license, as applicable, prior to January 15th of each year
shall be considered a violation of this Electrical Code.
(Ord. 157-01.  Passed 10-22-01; Ord. 140-17.  Passed 6-19-17.)
1468.03   LICENSE RENEWAL WITHOUT EXAMINATION.
   (A)   If any applicant for a journeyman electrician's license has been
granted an electrical journeyman's license in the City prior to the date of the
current application for license and has not, in the meantime, left his trade as
a journeyman electrician, then such license shall be considered as a renewal
and the renewal fee provided for in Section
1468.06(E) shall be collected.
   (B)   If a journeyman electrician licensed by the City enters the Armed
Forces of the United States his journeyman electrician's license will be
considered renewed for the duration of his active duty. However, he must
reapply for his license within six months from the date of separation from the
Armed Forces. Proof of his date of separation shall be presented at the time of
application.
   (C)   If a journeyman electrician licensed by the City has taken up
residence outside of the jurisdiction of the City, he shall post a letter of
absenteeism with the Electrical Inspector's office. Upon his return to the
area, he shall submit a written affidavit to the Electrical Inspector's office
as proof that he has not left his trade during his absence. Upon submission of
such written proof, his electrical journeyman's renewal license shall be issued
without examination.
(Ord. 157-01.  Passed 10-22-01; Ord. 140-17.  Passed 6-19-17.)
1468.04   ELECTRICAL CONTRACTOR'S LICENSE.
   (A)   An electrical contractor desiring a license to perform any electrical
contracting and the work involved therein shall make application in writing to
the Electrical Inspector of the City.
   (B)   Upon receipt of the application, the Electrical Inspector shall
certify the same to the City License Clerk, who shall, upon payment by the
applicant to the License Bureau of a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00), issue to
such applicant a license in accordance with such certificate. This license
shall be in effect for the balance of the current calendar year and may be
renewed annually upon payment of the fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each
renewal.
   (C)   No electrical contractor's license shall be issued to an applicant
unless:
      (1)   He holds a journeyman electrician's license with the City; or
      (2)   He has, in his permanent employ, a holder of a journeyman
electrician's license with the City.
      (3)   The electrical contractor has filed with the City a certificate of
public liability insurance in an amount not less than three hundred thousand
dollars ($300,000) combined single limit for bodily injury and property damage
liability insurance, including premises and completed operations liability,
blanket contractual and independent contractor's coverage. Such insurance shall
be with an insurance company licensed by the State and shall include a
provision that said coverage will not be cancelled by the insurance company
prior to thirty days advance notice to the City. Any such cancellation shall be
considered grounds for the revocation of the license of the contractor.
(Ord. 185-93.  Passed 9-27-93; Ord. 157-01.  Passed 10-22-01; Ord. 39-11. 
Passed 2-7-11; Ord. 140-17.  Passed 6-19-17; Ord. 121-20.  Passed 7-6-20.)
1468.05   ELECTRICAL CONTRACTOR'S BOND.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE:  Section 1468.05 was repealed by Ordinance 38-11, passed
February 7, 2011.)
1468.06   JOURNEYMAN ELECTRICIAN'S LICENSE.
   (A)   Any person desiring to perform any of the work of a journeyman
electrician shall make an application in writing to the Electrical Inspector
for a license to engage in such work.
   (B)   An applicant must have four years practical experience as an
electrical trainee or the equivalent in training or education and he may be
given credit for training in electrical engineering or an electrical trade
school. Practical electrical experience in areas where licenses are not
required will be considered, when such experience can be verified. An applicant
holding a valid journeyman electrician's license issued by another political
subdivision, when such license was issued after such journeyman electrician
successfully completed a test based on the National Electrical Code, will be
eligible for examination. The Board of Electrical Examiners shall determine
eligibility for examination based upon the requirements of this section and
shall afford each applicant an opportunity to present evidence as to his
qualification.
   (C)   An application for examination shall be accompanied by a non-
refundable fee of thirty dollars ($30.00). If the applicant passes the
examination, a license shall be issued without additional charge.
   (D)   An applicant who fails an examination shall be eligible to apply for
re-examination at the next scheduled examination date. If an applicant fails
the examination a second time, he will not be eligible for re-examination for a
period of six months from the date of the original re-examination. Further re-
examinations will be permitted on an annual basis only. All re-examination
applications shall be accompanied by a non-refundable fee of twenty dollars
($20.00). If the applicant passes the re-examination, a license shall be issued
without additional charge.
   (E)   An applicant who passes an examination will be issued a license valid
for the  balance of the calendar year to engage in journeyman electrician
work.  Such license may be renewed annually, on or before January 15th of each
successive year after its initial issuance, upon payment of a fee of twenty
dollars ($20.00) to the City.
   (F)   All applications to take an examination or re-examination for a
journeyman electrician's license shall be filed thirty days prior to any
regularly scheduled examination. Applications received after such date shall be
considered for the next regularly scheduled examination.
(Ord. 157-01.  Passed 10-22-01; Ord. 140-17.  Passed 6-19-17.)
1468.07   TEMPORARY WORKING PERMIT.
   (A)   The Building Commissioner may issue a temporary working permit to a
journeyman electrician having a valid license issued by another political
subdivision, when such license was issued after such journeyman electrician
successfully completed a test based on the National Electrical Code.  Such
temporary permit shall be valid for a period of sixty days and only one such
permit shall be issued to any one person in any calendar year.
   (B)   An application for a temporary permit shall be accompanied by a non-
refundable fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). In the event that a journeyman
electrician holding a valid permit makes an application to take the City
examination for a license, no additional fee shall be charged.
(Ord. 157-01.  Passed 10-22-01; Ord. 140-17.  Passed 6-19-17.)
1468.08   GRANTING OF JOURNEYMAN'S LICENSE TO ELECTRICAL CONTRACTORS.
   Any person registered as an electrical contractor with the City and who
desires to be licensed as a journeyman electrician with the City, shall comply
with all the requirements of Section 1468.06, provided however, that no
additional fee shall be charged to such person.
(Ord. 157-01.  Passed 10-22-01; Ord. 140-17.  Passed 6-19-17.)
1468.09   ELECTRICAL TRAINEE CERTIFICATE.
   (A)   Any person who engages in electrical work, other than a licensed
journeyman electrician, shall possess an electrical trainee certificate issued
by the Building Commissioner.  Possession of such certificate will enable such
person to learn the trade and will be credited to his experience when such
person applies for a journeyman's license.
   (B)   An electrical trainee certificate shall be issued to an applicant upon
payment of a ten dollar ($10.00) fee and shall be in effect for one calendar
year and may be renewed annually upon the payment of the same fee.
   (C)   Not more than three electrical trainees shall assist each licensed
journeyman electrician and such trainees shall be under the direct supervision
of such journeyman at all times. No restriction is placed on the number of
those helpers assisting the journeyman who are not engaged in actual electrical
work.
(Ord. 157-01.  Passed 10-22-01; Ord. 140-17.  Passed 6-19-17.)
1468.10   LICENSE SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION.
   Any license authorized by this chapter may be suspended or revoked by the
Board of Examiners should the licensee purposely violate any provision of this
Electrical Code or any law relating to electric wiring. Any licensee whose
license has been revoked shall not again be licensed within a period of one
year from the date of such action. No license shall be revoked or suspended
except by a majority vote of the Board at a regular or special meeting and no
license shall be revoked or suspended unless the licensee has been notified in
writing of the charges against him at least ten days before such meeting. A
licensee shall have the right to appear before the Board to answer the charges
and present testimony in his favor.
(Ord. 157-01.  Passed 10-22-01; Ord. 140-17.  Passed 6-19-17.)
1468.99   PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
1460.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)

   Failure of a residential electrical contractor to renew a registration prior
to January 15th of each year shall be considered a violation of this Electrical
Code.
(Ord. 122-20.  Passed 7-6-20.)
1469.03   RESIDENTIAL ELECTRICAL CONTRACTOR'S LICENSE.
   (A)   An electrical contractor desiring a license to perform residential
electrical contracting and the work involved therein shall make application in
writing to the Electrical Inspector of the City.
   (B)   Upon receipt of the application, the Electrical Inspector shall
certify the same to the City License Clerk, who shall, upon payment by the
applicant to the License Bureau of a fee of one hundred ten dollars ($110.00),
issue to such applicant a license in accordance with such certificate. This
license shall be in effect for the balance of the current calendar year and may
be renewed annually upon payment of the registration fee.
   (C)   No residential electrical contractor's license shall be issued to an
applicant unless the electrical contractor has filed with the City a
certificate of public liability insurance in an amount not less than three
hundred thousand dollars ($300,000) combined single limit for bodily injury and
property damage liability insurance, including premises and completed
operations liability, blanket contractual and independent contractor's
coverage. Such insurance shall be with an insurance company licensed by the
State and shall include a provision that said coverage will not be cancelled by
the insurance company prior to thirty days advance notice to the City. Any such
cancellation shall be considered grounds for the revocation of the license of
the contractor.
(Ord. 122-20.  Passed 7-6-20.)
1469.04   LICENSE SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION.
   Any license authorized by this chapter may be suspended or revoked by the

Electrical Code or any law relating to electric wiring. Any licensee whose
license has been revoked shall not again be licensed within a period of one
year from the date of such action. No license shall be revoked or suspended
except by a majority vote of the Board at a regular or special meeting and no
license shall be revoked or suspended unless the licensee has been notified in
writing of the charges against him at least ten days before such meeting. A
licensee shall have the right to appear before the Board to answer the charges
and present testimony in his favor.
(Ord. 122-20.  Passed 7-6-20.)

   Building inspections - see B. & H.

   Liability for defective wiring - see B. & H.

1468.10
1470.01   ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR.
   The position of Electrical Inspector is hereby established. The Electrical
Inspector shall be appointed from the classified service of the City as shall
any assistant electrical inspector. The position of clerk to the Electrical
Inspector may be created by Council. The Electrical Inspector and his
assistants and clerk shall be under the supervision of the Building
Commissioner and shall be directly responsible to such official.
(Ord. 32-65.  Passed 3-23-65; Ord. 141-17.  Passed 6-19-17.)
1470.02   VACANCY; PRIVATE CONTRACT.
   Whenever there is a vacancy in the office of Electrical Inspector and/or
assistant electrical inspector and Council deems it necessary to authorize the
Mayor to employ by private contract an individual to fulfill the duties of the
Electrical Inspector and/or assistant, that individual so employed by contract
shall have the same authority, powers and duties as the regular Electrical
Inspector and/or assistant. If such employment by private contract occurs, then
wherever the term Electrical Inspector and/or assistant appears in this
Electrical Code, such contract designee shall be substituted therefor.
(Ord. 186-73.  Passed 9-10-73; Ord. 141-17.  Passed 6-19-17.)
1470.03   QUALIFICATIONS.
   (A)   The person chosen to fill the position of Electrical Inspector shall
be a competent electrician and of good moral character. He shall have such
executive ability as is requisite for the efficient performance of his duties
and shall have a thorough knowledge of the standard materials and methods used
in the installation of electrical wiring, devices, appliances and equipment.
   (B)   He shall possess a valid certified electrical safety inspector's
license from the State Board of Building Standards, as authorized by Ohio R.C.
3783.03 as the same may be hereafter amended.
   (C)   He shall not perform any electrical work within the corporate limits
of the City, whether for hire or otherwise, except on those properties owned by
him and then only under the same conditions upon which work may be performed by
a member of the general public. He shall not be employed by, or have a
financial interest in the business of, any electrical contractor registered
with the City or electrician who has a license to perform work within the City.
He shall not be employed by any member of the Board of Examiners or the Board
of Appeals, as established in
Chapters 1462 and
1464, nor shall he have any interest in any business of any such person.
(Ord. 198-77.  Passed 12-19-77; Ord. 158-01.  Passed 10-22-01; Ord. 141-17. 
Passed 6-19-17.)
1470.04   COMPENSATION.
   The salary to be paid to the Electrical Inspector shall be as determined
from time to time by Council.
(Ord. 32-65.  Passed 3-23-65; Ord. 141-17.  Passed 6-19-17.)
1470.05   (REPEALED).
1470.06   REMOVAL.
   The Electrical Inspector shall be removed from office for cause only, after
a full hearing before the Civil Service Board.
(Ord. 32-65.  Passed 3-23-65; Ord. 141-17.  Passed 6-19-17.)
1470.07   POWERS AND DUTIES.
   It shall be the duty of the Electrical Inspector, under the direction of the
Building Commissioner, to see that the provisions of this Electrical Code are
enforced. He shall, upon application, grant permits for the installation or
alteration of electric wiring, devices, appliances and equipment and shall make
inspections of all new electrical installations and reinspection of electrical
installations, as provided in this Electrical Code. His time shall be devoted
entirely to the duties of his office. The Electrical Inspector shall notify the
Building Commissioner of any unsafe conditions and recommend actions to abate
hazard, including: to disconnect or order the discontinuance of electric
service to any electric wiring, devices, appliances or equipment found to be
dangerous to life or property because they are defective, defectively installed
or otherwise not in conformity with the provisions of this Electrical Code,
until such wiring, devices, appliances and equipment and their installation
have been made safe as directed by him. He is authorized to delegate any of his
rights or duties to any duly appointed assistant. The Electrical Inspector
shall hold membership in the International Association of Electrical
Inspectors.
(Ord. 32-65.  Passed 3-23-65; Ord. 141-17.  Passed 6-19-17.)
1470.08   REINSPECTIONS.
   The Electrical Inspector may make a thorough reinspection of all electric
wiring, devices, appliances and equipment now installed or that may hereafter
be installed within the City and within the scope of this Electrical Code. When
the installation of any such wiring, devices, appliances or equipment is found
to be dangerous or unsafe, the person owning, using or operating the same shall
be so notified in writing and shall make the necessary repairs or changes
required to place such wiring, devices, appliances and equipment in safe
condition. Such work shall be completed within fifteen days or any longer
period specified by the Building Commissioner in such notice.
(Ord. 32-65.  Passed 3-23-65; Ord. 141-17.  Passed 6-19-17.)
1470.09   RECORDS.
   The Electrical Inspector shall keep complete records of all permits issued,
inspections and reinspections made and other official work performed in
accordance with the provisions of the Ohio Building Code and the Residential
Code of Ohio.
(Ord. 32-65.  Passed 3-23-65; Ord. 141-17.  Passed 6-19-17.)
1470.10   REPORTS.
   The Electrical Inspector shall make daily written reports of all activities
and inspections to the Building Commissioner. A copy of these reports shall be
kept on file in the Electrical Inspector's office in the Building Department.
(Ord. 32-65.  Passed 3-23-65; Ord. 141-17.  Passed 6-19-17.)
1470.11   RIGHT OF ENTRY.
   The Electrical Inspector shall have the right, during reasonable hours, to
enter any building in the discharge of his official duties or for the purpose
of making any inspection, reinspection or test of the installations of electric
wiring, devices, appliances and equipment contained therein. He shall have the
authority to cut or disconnect any wire, in case of an emergency where such
action is necessary for the safety of life and property or where such wire may
interfere with the work of the Fire Department. No person shall interfere with
the Electrical Inspector in the performance of his official duties.
(Ord. 32-65.  Passed 3-23-65; Ord. 141-17.  Passed 6-19-17.)
1470.12   CONNECTIONS; APPROVAL REQUIRED.
   No electrical wiring, devices, appliances or equipment shall be connected to
a source of electrical energy until the same have been approved by the
Electrical Inspector.
(Ord. 7-79.  Passed 1-8-79; Ord. 141-17.  Passed 6-19-17.)
1470.13   ADDITIONAL CHARGES FOR NONCOMPLIANCE.
   If any person installs or orders electrical wiring or devices to be
installed, without first securing the required permit therefor, 300 percent of
the inspection charge shall be required, based on, and in addition to, the
applicable inspection fees contained in Section
1470.14. The payment of such extra charge shall not release such person from
any other penalty.
(Ord. 199-78.  Passed 12-18-78; Ord. 141-17.  Passed 6-19-17.)
1470.14   SCHEDULE OF FEES.
   For the inspection of electrical or power installations, there shall be fees
as set forth in Section
1490.01.  A rough wiring inspection shall be made upon completion of rough
wiring, including any basement wiring, and the installation of service
equipment, switches and receptacles. After the rough wiring inspection has been
made, a final inspection covering fixtures and completed installations shall be
made. All installations are subject to inspection and acceptance by the
Electrical Inspector. In addition to the base electric permit fee, there shall
be an additional fee for the following inspection services, the amount of which
shall be displayed in Section
1490.01:
   (A)   Electric panel/sub panel
   (B)   Motors one horse power and over
   (C)   Generators, rectifiers & transformers
   (D)   Temporary electric service
   (E)   Service release
   (F)   Underground conduit
   (G)   Special inspection fees. If more than two inspections are necessary
because of faulty installation, an incorrect address or locked premises, a
charge of twenty dollars ($20.00) shall be made for each additional
inspection.  When any person desires an inspection of an existing building, or
part thereof, or other special service, the fee for such inspection or service
shall be as set forth in Section
1490.01.
   (H)   Additional fees.  All electrical or power installation fees subject to
the Ohio Basic Building Code shall be increased by five percent over the fees
set forth herein.
(Ord. 073-10.  Passed 3-22-10; Ord. 135-11.  Passed 6-20-11; Ord. 141-17. 
Passed 6-19-17.)
1470.99    PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
1460.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 1472
Standards and Materials
1472.01   Installation Standards.
1472.02   Adoption of National Electrical Code.
1472.03   Approved Materials.
1472.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Adoption of technical codes - see Ohio R.C. 731.231
   Alteration and repair of damaged buildings - see B. & H.
1420.03
   Fire limits - see B. & H. Ch.
1422
   Public utilities - see B. & H.
1458.05(a)
   Inspections - see B. & H. Ch.
1470
1472.01   INSTALLATION STANDARDS.
   No installation shall be made unless it is in strict conformity with the
provisions of this Electrical Code, applicable State statutes and the rules and
regulations issued by the Industrial Commission of the State under the
authority of the State statutes and unless it is in conformity with approved
standards of construction for safety to life and property. In every case, where
no specific type or class of material or no specific method of construction is
prescribed by State statutes, by regulations issued thereunder or by this
Electrical Code, then conformity with the regulations governing installation as
specified in the National Electrical Code, as published by the National Fire
Protection Association (NFPA), and other installation and safety regulations
governing installation approved by the National Fire Protection Association
(NFPA) or the American National Standards Institute (A.N.S.I.), shall be prima-
facie evidence of conformity with approved standards of construction for safety
to life and property.
(Ord. 32-65.  Passed 3-23-65; Ord. 142-17.  Passed 6-19-17.)
1472.02   ADOPTION OF NATIONAL ELECTRICAL CODE.
   (A)   In order to establish standards for the basic minimum provisions
considered necessary for safety in the use of electricity for light, heat,
power, radio signaling and other purposes, the City hereby adopts the 2014
edition of the National Electrical Code as published by the National Fire
Protection Association (NFPA), or the most recent edition referenced by the
Residential Code of Ohio for One, Two and Three Family Dwellings, and all
amendments and supplements thereto; and said Code is hereby made part of this
Electrical Code and incorporated herein by reference.
   (B)   The Building Commissioner shall keep a complete copy of such Code on
file for public inspection and make copies available at cost for the public
with brief summaries of any amendments or deletions thereto.
(Ord. 142-17.  Passed 6-19-17.)
1472.03   APPROVED MATERIALS.
   (A)   No electrical materials, devices, appliances or equipment shall be
used or installed in the City unless they are in conformity with the provisions
of this Electrical Code, applicable State statutes or rules issued thereunder
and unless they are in conformity with listed methods of construction for
safety of life and property. Except when a specific type or class of material,
device, appliance or equipment is unlisted for installation or use, conformity
of such items with the standards of Underwriters' Laboratories, Incorporated,
or other safety standards approved by the American Standards Association, the
American Society of Testing Materials, the Electrical Testing Laboratories or
the Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers shall be prima-facie
evidence that such materials, devices, appliances and equipment comply with the
requirements of this Electrical Code.  (Ord. 293-74.  Passed 12-23-74.)
   (B)   Materials or devices which have been removed from service shall not be
reinstalled until they have been repaired or renewed to meet present safety
requirements for such types of material or device.
   (C)   No building damaged by fire shall be connected to the Utility Electric
Service until all wiring of such building meets the requirements of this
Electrical Code.
(Ord. 142-17.  Passed 6-19-17.)
1472.99   PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
1460.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
TITLE SIX - Plumbing Code
         
Chap. 1474.   Health District Regulations and Ohio Plumbing Code.
CHAPTER 1474
Health District Regulations and Ohio Plumbing Code
   EDITOR'S NOTE: The Combined Allen County General Health District enforces
its own regulations, designated the Plumbing Regulations of the Combined Allen
County General Health District, as well as the Ohio Plumbing Code, being
Chapters 4101:2-56 to 69 of the Ohio Basic Building Code, 1998 edition, as
amended, in the City of Lima. All plumbing inspections in the City are made by
the District Board of Health.
1474.01   Violations; Notice to Discontinue Work.
1474.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Adoption of technical codes - see Ohio R.C. 731.231
   Power to enforce State Building Code relating to plumbing - see Ohio R.C.
3781.03
   Stop work orders; suspension of work - see B. & H.
1404.05,
1460.04
1474.01   VIOLATIONS; NOTICE TO DISCONTINUE WORK.
   In case of any violation of or noncompliance with any rule or regulation of
the Combined Allen County General Health District relative to plumbing or any
provision of the Ohio Plumbing Code, the approval of the plans and
specifications thereof shall be nullified by the District Inspector and notice
thereof shall at once be given to the plumbers having charge of the work and
doing the same, and to the owner of the building or his agent. Thereupon all
work under such plans and specifications shall immediately cease and work shall
not recommence until such plans and specifications shall have been reapproved
by the Inspector. The equitable remedy provided for herein shall be in addition
to the penalty provided in Section
1474.99.
(1956 Code Sec. 1909.01) 
1474.99   PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any rule or regulation of the
Combined Allen County General Health District relative to plumbing or any
provision of the Ohio Plumbing Code, or fails to obey a valid order of the
Building Commissioner or the Combined Allen County General Health District, is
guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree and shall be fined not more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned not more than sixty days, or both.
A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a
violation or noncompliance occurs or continues.

1602.01   OHIO FIRE CODE, ADOPTED; FILE AND DISTRIBUTION COPIES.
   (A)   There is hereby adopted, for the purpose of prescribing regulations
and standards governing conditions hazardous to life and property from fire or
explosion, the 2017 Ohio Fire Code (also referred to as the Fire Prevention
Code), and any and all supplements, modifications, amendments, and subsequent
Ohio Fire Codes as may be enacted.
   (B)   The Fire Chief shall file with the Clerk of Council a copy of the Ohio
Fire Code, supplements, amendments, and which is hereby incorporated as a part
of these Codified Ordinances as fully as if rewritten herein.
   (C)   The Clerk of Council shall keep complete copies of such Code on file
for inspection by the public and shall make copies available for distribution
to the public, at cost, with brief summaries of any amendments thereto or
deletions therefrom.  A copy shall be filed with the County Law Library by the
Clerk.  A copy shall also be filed with the County Public Library by the Clerk.
(Ord. 066-18.  Passed 3-12-18.)
1602.02   ESTABLISHMENT AND DUTIES OF BUREAU OF FIRE PREVENTION.
   (A)   The Fire Prevention Code shall be enforced by the Bureau of Fire
Prevention, which is hereby established in the Fire Department of the City and
which shall be operated under the supervision of the Chief of the Fire
Department.
   (B)   The Chief may designate such members of the Fire Department as
inspectors, otherwise known as Code Officials, as are from time to time
necessary.
   (C)   A report of the Bureau of Fire Prevention shall be made annually and
transmitted to the Mayor.  It shall contain all proceedings under this Fire
Prevention Code, with such statistics as the Fire Chief may wish to include
therein.  The Chief shall also recommend any amendments to this Fire Prevention
Code which, in his judgment, are desirable. 
(Ord. 147-93.  Passed 9-13-93.)
1602.03   BONFIRES.
   (a)   For purposes of this section a “bonfire”  is an open burning fire that
is used for cooking food for human consumption, pleasure, religious,
ceremonial, warmth, recreational or similar purposes that is fueled by clean
seasoned firewood or its equivalent, is not used for waste disposal, and has a
total fuel area greater than three feet in diameter or two feet in height and
no more than five feet in height and five feet in width; and,
   (b)   No person shall cause a bonfire and/or ceremonial fire to be conducted
in a manner prohibited by the Ohio Fire Code, as adopted in this chapter, the
Ohio Administrative Code and any rules and regulations of the EPA or Ohio EPA;
and,
   (c)   Any person who causes a bonfire to be conducted shall, ten days prior
thereto, notify the Ohio EPA, as required by Rule 1301:7-7-01 of the
Administrative Code, and apply for a permit through the Lima Fire Department
Fire Prevention Bureau; and,
   (d)   Whoever violates division (c) of this section by failing to obtain a
permit from the Fire Prevention Bureau is guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
(Ord. 192-12. Passed 9-24-12.)
1602.04   LIMITS OF DISTRICTS IN WHICH STORAGE OF FLAMMABLE LIQUIDS IN OUTSIDE
ABOVE GROUND TANKS IS PROHIBITED.  (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE:  Section 1602.04 was repealed by Ordinance 46-92, passed
March 23, 1992.)
1602.05   LIMITS ON BULK STORAGE OF LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GASES IS RESTRICTED. 
(REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE:  Section 1602.05 was repealed by Ordinance 159-94, passed
December 5, 1994.)
1602.06   LIMITS OF DISTRICTS IN WHICH STORAGE OF EXPLOSIVES AND BLASTING
AGENTS IS PROHIBITED.  (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE:  Section 1602.06 was repealed by Ordinance 46-92, passed
March 23, 1992.)
1602.07   MOTOR VEHICLE ROUTES FOR VEHICLES TRANSPORTING EXPLOSIVES AND
DANGEROUS ARTICLES.  (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE:  Section 1602.07 was repealed by Ordinance 46-92, passed
March 23, 1992.)
1602.08   PERMITS; FIRE SUPPRESSION, HOOD SUPPRESSION AND FIRE ALARM SYSTEMS.
   (A)   Unless otherwise specifically provided in these Codified Ordinances,
all permits approved by the Fire Prevention Bureau, shall be issued under the
authority of the Ohio Fire Code and regulated consistent with the procedures
and conditions required thereunder.
   (B)   Annual permits shall be obtained for all required fire suppression,
hood suppression (commercial cooking), and fire alarm systems. Applications
shall be submitted to the Licensing and Permit Clerks by June 1st of each
calendar year and shall contain information consistent with that which is
required for the Annual Inspection Tag or as otherwise required by the Fire
Prevention Bureau.
(Ord. 82-14. Passed 3-24-14.)
1602.09   MODIFICATIONS.
   The Chief of the Fire Department, as head of the Bureau of Fire Prevention,
shall have the power to modify any of the provisions of the Fire Prevention
Code upon application in writing by the owner or lessee or his duly authorized
agent, when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the
strict letter of the Fire Prevention Code, provided that the spirit of the Fire
Prevention Code shall be observed, public safety secured and substantial
justice done.  The particulars of such modification, when granted or allowed,
and the decision of the Chief thereon, shall be entered upon the records of the
Department and a signed copy shall be furnished the applicant. 
(Ord. 101-85.  Passed 6-17-85.)
1602.10   APPEALS.
   Whenever the Chief of the Fire Department disapproves an application or
refuses to grant a permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the
provisions of this chapter do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of
the Ohio Fire Code have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant
may appeal from the decision of the Chief as set forth in the Ohio Fire Code.
(Ord. 101-85.  Passed 6-17-85.)
1602.11   NEW MATERIALS, PROCESSES OR OCCUPANCIES WHICH MAY REQUIRE PERMITS.
   The Mayor, the City Engineer and the Chief of the Fire Department shall act
as a committee to determine and specify, after giving affected persons an
opportunity to be heard, any new materials, processes or occupancies which
shall require permits, in addition to those now enumerated in the Ohio Fire
Code.  The Fire Chief shall post such list in a conspicuous place in his office
and distribute copies thereof to interested persons.
(Ord. 101-85.  Passed 6-17-85.)
1602.12   CONFLICT OF LAWS.  (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE:  Section 1602.12 was repealed by Ordinance 46-92, passed
March 23, 1992.)
1602.13   AMENDMENTS. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE:  Section 1602.13 was in conflict with, and therefore
repealed by Ordinance 057-06,  Passed 2-27-06.)
1602.14   JURISDICTIONAL LIABILITY.
   The City shall not be liable under this code for any damage to persons or
property, by reason of the inspection or reinspection of buildings, structures
or equipment authorized herein, or by reason of failure to inspect or reinspect
such buildings, structures or equipment, or by reason of the approval or
disapproval of any building, structure or equipment authorized herein.
(Ord. 149-93.  Passed 9-13-93.)
1602.15   ADMINISTRATIVE LIABILITY.
   The code official, officer or employee charged with the enforcement of this
code, while acting for the jurisdiction, shall not thereby be rendered
personally liable, and is hereby relieved from all personal liability for any
damage to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in
the discharge of official duties.  Any suit instituted against any officer or
employee because of an act performed in the lawful discharge of duties and
under the provisions of this code shall be defended by the legal representative
of the jurisdiction until the final termination of the proceedings.  The code
official or any subordinates of the code official shall not be liable for costs
in any action, suit or proceeding that is instituted pursuant to the provisions
of this code, and any official, officer or employee, acting in good faith and
without malice, shall be free from liability for acts performed under any of
its provisions or by reason of any act or omission in the performance of
official duties in connection therewith.
(Ord. 148-93.  Passed 9-13-93.)
1602.16   "SHALL" DEFINED.
   Whenever any provision of the Ohio Fire Code, as adopted in Section
1602.01, uses the term "shall" to describe an act or action to be taken by the
code official or other official or employee or agent of the City, the term
"shall" shall be interpreted to mean that such official, employee or agent may
act or take such action at his or her discretion.
(Ord. 159-94.  Passed 12-5-94.)
1602.99    GENERAL CODE PENALTY.
   (A)   Criminal Penalties. Unless otherwise specifically provided, whoever 
violates any of the provisions of this Part Sixteen - Fire Prevention Code,
including the provisions of the Fire Prevention Code herein adopted, or fails
to comply therewith, or violates or fails to comply with any order made
thereunder, or builds in violation of any detailed statement of specifications
or plans submitted and approved thereunder, or any  certificate or permit
issued thereunder, and from which no appeal has been taken, or fails to comply
with such an order as affirmed or modified by the Building Appeals Board or by
a court of competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed herein, shall
severally for each and every such violation and noncompliance respectively be
guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one hundred
dollars ($100.00). Whoever is guilty of a second or subsequent offense within
one year of a prior conviction is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree.
The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation
or permit it to continue and all such persons shall be required to correct or
remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable time. When not otherwise
specified, a separate offense shall be deemed committed each ten days that
prohibited conditions are maintained.
   (B)   Fire Code Violations; Civil Penalties.
      (1)   No person shall knowingly violate any provision of the State Fire
Code or any order made pursuant to it.
      (2)   Any person who has received a citation for a serious violation of
this Fire Prevention Code or any order issued pursuant to it shall be assessed
a civil penalty of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000) for each such
violation.
      (3)   Any person who has received a citation for a violation of this Fire
Prevention Code or any order issued pursuant to it, and such violation is
specifically determined not to be of a serious nature, may be assessed a civil
penalty of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000) for each such violation.
      (4)   Any person who fails to correct a violation for which a citation
has been issued within the period permitted for its correction may be assessed
a civil penalty of not more than one thousand dollars for each day during which
such failure or violation continues.
      (5)   Any person who violates any of the posting requirements, as
prescribed by Ohio R.C. 3737.42(C), shall be assessed a civil penalty of not
more than one thousand dollars ($1,000) for each violation.
      (6)   Due consideration to the appropriateness of the penalty with
respect to the gravity of the violation, the good faith of the person being
charged and the history of previous violations shall be given whenever a
penalty is assessed under this section.
      (7)   For purposes of this section, a serious violation shall be
considered to exist if there is a substantial probability that an occurrence
causing death or serious physical harm to persons could result from a condition
which exists, or from one or more practices, means, methods, operations or
processes which have been adopted or are in use, unless the person did not and
could not with the exercise of reasonable diligence, know of the presence of
the violation.
   (C)   The application of the above penalty shall not be held to prevent the
enforced removal of prohibited conditions.
(Ord. 203-89.  Passed 12-4-89.)

1604.03   HINDERING OFFICERS; COMPLIANCE WITH ORDERS.
   No person shall hinder or prevent any officer of the Bureau of Fire
Prevention from enforcing the provisions of this chapter or the Fire Prevention
Code nor fail, neglect or refuse to obey any lawful order made by such
official.
   In addition, in case of fire resulting directly or indirectly from any
omission or neglect to properly comply with a lawful written order of the Chief
of the Fire Department as head of the Bureau of Fire Prevention, as provided in
Section
1602.02, or the Fire Prevention Code, unless such order has been appealed from
and until such appeal has been disposed of or modified as provided in Section
1604.01, the person culpable or negligent in respect thereto shall be liable in
a civil action for the payment of all costs and expenses of the Fire Department
incurred in and about the use of employees, apparatus and materials in the
extinguishing; of any fire resulting from such cause. The amount of such cost
and expenses shall be fixed by the Mayor and, when collected, shall be paid
into the General Fund of the City.
(Ord. 6-61.  Passed 1-16-61.)
1604.04   AUTHORITY TO INSPECT.
   None of the provisions of this chapter or the Fire Prevention Code shall
interfere with the authority of the Chief of the Fire Department, the members
of the Department or any State official to inspect any buildings or premises
within the City under such authority as may be granted by law.
(Ord. 6-61. Passed 1-16-61.)
1604.05   INSPECTORS TO REPORT HAZARDS AND VIOLATIONS.
   It shall be the duty of the inspectors of the Bureau of Fire Prevention to
report to the Chief of the Fire Department any fire hazards and any violations
of this chapter or the Fire Prevention Code which may come to their attention.
(Ord. 6-61. Passed 6-16-61.)

   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
1602.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)

1606.02   DUTY TO REPORT FIRES.
   It shall be the duty of the owner, manager or person in charge of every
hotel, restaurant, hospital, church, school, theater, public building, store or
any mercantile establishment of any kind in the City to notify the Fire
Department as to the existence and location of any fire upon such premises
immediately upon discovering the existence of such fire. However, this section
shall not be construed to prohibit the owner, manager or person in control of
such establishment from using all diligence necessary to extinguish the fire on
such premises prior to the arrival of the Fire Department.
(1956 Code Sec. 941.02)

1606.06   SMOKING IN SPECIFIED PUBLIC PLACES.
   (A)   No person shall smoke or carry a lighted cigar, cigarette or pipe, or
use any  spark, match or flame-producing device, on any passenger elevator or
in any retail store, theater, church, school auditorium or school gymnasium.
However, the provisions of this section shall not apply to designated smoking
and rest rooms in any retail store, theater or church when such rooms have been
approved for such purpose by the Chief of the Bureau of Fire Prevention, nor
shall the provisions of this section apply so as to interfere with religious
services conducted by any church organization.
   (B)   The manager of any place where smoking is prohibited by the provisions
of subsection (A) hereof or the person having the control of such premises,
shall cause to be conspicuously displayed durable signs containing a notice
reading as follows:
      NO SMOKING
      by City Ordinance
   The words "no smoking" contained in the above-mentioned sign shall be in
letters not less than three inches in height.
(Ord. 162-50. Passed 11-27-50.)
1606.07   SMOKING IN BED IN HOTELS, ETC.
   (A)   No person shall smoke or hold a lighted cigar, cigarette or pipe, or
use any spark, match or flame-producing device, in or on a bed in any hotel,
dormitory or rooming or lodging house.
   (B)   The manager or person in control of every hotel, dormitory and rooming
or lodging house shall cause to be conspicuously displayed durable signs
containing a copy of the provisions of subsection (a) hereof in each sleeping
room thereof.
(Ord. 162-50. Passed 11-27-50.)
1606.08   SMOKING ON CITY BUSES.
   (A)   No person shall smoke or carry a lighted cigar, cigarette or pipe, or
use any spark, match or flame-producing device, on any bus operated under
franchise with the City. It is hereby made the duty of the operator of each bus
to cause this requirement to be observed.
   (B)   Any person having a franchise with the City to operate buses within
the limits thereof shall cause to be conspicuously displayed durable signs on
each bus bearing the sign prescribed by subsection (B) hereof, such signs to
conform to the specifications contained in such subsection.
(Ord. 162-50. Passed 11-27-50.)

CHAPTER 1802
Rules of Construction and Definitions
1802.01   Rules of construction.
1802.02   Definitions.
1802.01   RULES OF CONSTRUCTION.
   (A)   Scope. Unless otherwise expressly stated, the following terms shall,
for the purposes of this Property Maintenance Code (PMC), have the meanings
shown in this chapter.
   (B)   Interchangeability. Words stated in the present tense include the
future; words stated in the masculine gender include the feminine and neuter;
the singular number includes the plural and the plural the singular. 
   (C)   Terms Defined in Other Parts. Where terms are not defined in this
chapter and are defined in other chapters of this PMC, or are defined in any of
the building, plumbing and mechanical codes listed in
Chapter 1826, such terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in those
chapters or codes. In the event there is a conflict between the definition of a
term in any code listed in
Chapter 1826 and the definition listed in any section or chapter of this PMC,
then the definition in this PMC shall prevail. 
   (D)   Terms Not Defined. Where terms are not defined in this PMC, or in any
of the building, plumbing and mechanical codes listed in
Chapter 1826, such terms shall have ordinarily accepted meanings such as the
context implies. 
   (E)   Terms to Include "Or Any Part Thereof."  Whenever the words "dwelling
unit," "dwelling," "premises," "building," "rooming house," "rooming unit,"
"story" and "structure" are used in this PMC, they shall be construed as though
they were followed by the words "or any part thereof."
(Ord. 37-94.  Passed 4-11-94.)
1802.02   DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this PMC, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
respectively ascribed to them herein:
   (A)   Approved: Approved by the Code Official.
   (B)   Basement: That portion of a structure which is partly or completely
below grade.
   (C)   Bathroom: A room containing plumbing fixtures, including but not
limited to a bathtub, shower, sink, or toilet.
   (D)   Building: Any structure occupied or intended for supporting or
sheltering any occupancy, or any vacant structure.
   (E)   Building Code: The Building Code officially adopted by the legislative
body of this jurisdiction, or other such codes officially designated by the
legislative body of this jurisdiction for the regulation of construction,
alteration, addition, repair, removal, demolition or location of buildings and
structures.
   (F)   Code Official: The Code Official is the Director of the Department of
Community Development or any person duly authorized by him to administer or
enforce the provisions of this PMC.
   (G)   Condemn: To determine as unfit for occupancy.
   (H)   Construction documents: All the written, graphic, or pictorial
documents prepared or assembled for describing the design, location and
physical characteristics of the elements of a project necessary for obtaining a
building permit. The construction drawings shall be drawn to an appropriate
scale.
   (I)   Dormitory: A space in a building where group sleeping accommodations
are provided in one room, or in a series of closely associated rooms, for
persons not members of the same family group.
   (J)   Dwelling: Any type of structure occupied or intended for occupancy by
any person for purposes of living or sleeping therein, such as a dormitory,
dwelling unit, hotel, one-family dwelling, rooming house, rooming unit,
apartment house or complex, condominium, duplex or two-family dwelling.
   (K)   Dwelling unit: A single unit providing complete, independent living
facilities for one or more persons, including provisions for living, sleeping,
eating, cooking and sanitation.
   (L)   Exterior property area: The open or unoccupied land of a premises, and
any adjoining property under the control of owners or operators of such
premises.
   (M)   Extermination: The control and elimination of insects, rats or other
pests by eliminating their harborage places; by removing or making inaccessible
materials that serve as their food; by poison spraying, fumigating or trapping;
or by any other approved pest elimination methods.
   (N)   Family: An individual or married couple and the children thereof with
not more than two other persons related directly to the individual or married
couple by blood or marriage; or a group of not more than five unrelated
persons, living together as a single housekeeping unit in a dwelling unit.
   (O)   Garbage: The animal or vegetable waste resulting from the handling,
preparation, cooking and consumption of food or food products.
   (P)   Habitable space: Space in a structure for living, sleeping, eating or
cooking. Bathrooms, toilet compartments, closets, halls, storage or utility
spaces, and similar areas, are not considered habitable spaces.
   (Q)   Hotel: Any building containing six or more guest rooms, intended or
designed to be occupied, or which are rented or hired out to be occupied, for
sleeping purposes by guests.
   (R)   Infestation: The presence, within or contiguous to a structure or
premises, of insects, rats, vermin or other pests.
   (S)   Junk: "Junk" means any worn out, cast-off or discarded article, or
material which is ready for disposal or destruction, or which has been
collected or stored for salvage or conversion to some other use. Any article or
material which, unaltered or unchanged and without further reconditioning, can
be used for its original purpose as readily as when new, shall not be
considered junk. Portions of junk motor vehicles, such as hoods, fenders,
radiators, rims, motors, etc., not being utilized for the repair of a motor
vehicle, shall be considered junk.
   (T)   Let for occupancy or let: To permit possession or occupancy of a
dwelling, building or structure by a person who is not the legal owner of
record thereof, pursuant to a written or unwritten lease, agreement or license,
or pursuant to a recorded or unrecorded agreement or contract for the sale of
land.
   (U)   Occupancy: The purpose for which a structure or portion thereof is
utilized or occupied.
   (V)   Occupant: Any person living or sleeping in a dwelling, building or
structure, or having possession of a space therein.
   (W   One-family dwelling: A building containing one dwelling unit.
   (X)   Openable area: That part of a window or door which is available for
unobstructed ventilation and which opens directly to the outdoors.
   (Y)   Operator: Any person who has charge, care or control of a structure or
premises which is let or offered for occupancy.
   (Z)   Owner: Any person, agent, operator, firm, corporation or other legal
entity having a legal or equitable interest in property, or recorded in the
official records of the state, county or municipality as holding legal title to
the property, or otherwise having control of the property, including the
guardian of the estate of any such person, the executor or administrator of the
estate of any such person, a trustee, or a receiver if ordered to take
possession or control of real property by a court.
   (AA)   Person: An individual, corporation, firm, partnership, trustee,
receiver, joint venture or any other group or legal entity.
   (BB)   Plumbing: The practice, materials and fixtures utilized in the
installation, maintenance, extension and alteration of all piping, fixtures,
appliances and appurtenances within the scope of the plumbing code listed in
Chapter 1826.
   (CC)   Plumbing fixture: A receptacle or device which is either permanently
or temporarily connected to the water distribution system of a premises and
which demands a supply of water therefrom, or which discharges wastewater,
liquid-borne waste materials or sewage either directly or indirectly to the
drainage system of the premises, or which requires both a water supply
connection and a discharge to the drainage system of the premises.
   (DD)   Premises: A lot, plot, parcel or area of land, including the interior
and exterior of any structures thereon. 
(Ord. 25-96.  Passed 2-26-96.)
   (EE)   Public nuisance: Includes any of the following, as may be determined
by the Code Official:
      (1)   The physical condition or occupancy of any premises regarded as a
public nuisance at common law, or as determined by statute.
      (2)   Any physical condition or occupancy of any premises or its
appurtenances considered to be an attractive nuisance to children, including,
but not limited to, abandoned wells, shafts, basements, excavations and unsafe
fences or structures.
      (3)   Any premises that has unsanitary sewerage or plumbing facilities.
      (4)   Any premises determined to be unfit for human habitation.
      (5)   Any premises that is manifestly capable of being a fire hazard, or
is manifestly unsafe or unsecured so as to endanger life, limb or property.
      (6)   Any premises from which the plumbing, heating or facilities
required by this PMC have been removed, or from which utilities have been
disconnected, destroyed, removed or rendered ineffective, or for which the
required precautions against trespassers have not been provided.
      (7)   Any premises that is unsanitary, or that is littered with rubbish
or garbage, or that has an uncontrolled growth of weeds.
      (8)   Any structure that is in a state of dilapidation, deterioration or
decay; that has faulty construction; that is overcrowded; that is open, vacant
or abandoned; that is damaged by fire to such an extent that it does not
provide shelter; that is in danger of collapse or failure; or that is dangerous
to anyone on or near the premises.
   (FF)   Registered design professional: An architect or engineer, registered
or licensed to practice professional architecture or engineering, as defined by
the statutory requirements of the professional registration laws of the state
in which the project is to be constructed.
   (GG)   Rooming house: A building arranged or occupied for lodging for
compensation, and not occupied as a one-family dwelling or a two-family
dwelling.
   (HH)   Rooming unit: Any room or group of rooms forming a single habitable
unit occupied or intended to be occupied for sleeping or living.
   (II)   Rubbish: Combustible or noncombustible waste materials, except
garbage.  The term shall include the residue from the burning of wood, coal,
coke or other combustible materials and shall also include paper, rags,
cartons, boxes, wood, excelsior, rubber, leather, tree branches, yard
trimmings, tin cans, metals, mineral matter, glass, crockery, dust, domestic
animal waste, and other similar materials.
   (JJ)   Structure: That which has been, or is being, built or constructed, or
a portion thereof. 
   (KK)   Toilet room: A room containing a toilet or urinal, but not a bathtub
or shower.
   (LL)   Two-family dwelling: A building containing two dwelling units.
   (MM)   Ventilation: The natural or mechanical process of supplying
conditioned or unconditioned air to, or removing such air from, any space.
   (NN)   Weeds:
      (1)   "Weeds" are all grasses, annual plants and vegetation, other than
trees, shrubs and cultivated flowers and gardens.
      (2)   "Noxious or harmful weeds or vines" means ragweeds, daisies,
goldenrod, burdock, yellow dock, dandelions, thistles, wild carrot and any
other weed or vegetable which exhales offensive or noxious odors or from which
there is carried by the wind any injurious, offensive or annoying pollen, dust,
down, seed or particle, or which may conceal filthy deposits.
   (OO)   Workmanlike: Executed in a generally acceptable and skilled manner,
e.g. generally plumb, level, square, in line, undamaged and without marring
adjacent work.
   (PP)   Yard: An open area of land on the same premises with a structure, or
a vacant premises.
(Ord. 37-94.  Passed 4-11-94; Ord. 065-04. Eff. 05-01-04)

1804.39   Specified Parcels
1804.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Littering - see GEN. OFF.

   Noxious odors; filthy accumulations; polluting and diverting watercourses -
see GEN. OFF.
660.03
   Notice to fill lots; remove putrid substances - see GEN. OFF.
660.09

   Solid waste - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.
1052
