CHAPTER 2002
General Provisions and Definitions
2002.01   Title.
2002.02   Purpose and Intent.
2002.03   Existing Remedies.
2002.04   Workmanship/Application of Other Codes.
2002.05   Unlawful Acts.
2002.06   Prohibition Against Transfer of Ownership.
2002.07   Rules of Construction
2002.08   Public Nuisance Defined.
2002.09   Severability.
2002.10   Saving Clause.
2002.01   TITLE.
   This Part Twenty, Title Two of these Codified Ordinances shall be known as
the General Public Nuisance Code of Lima, Ohio, hereinafter referred to as
"this Code."
(Ord. 124-06.  Passed 04-24-2006.)
2002.02   PURPOSE AND INTENT.
   The purposes and intent of this Code are to enable Section 1 of the City
Charter which gives Council the authority by ordinance to define, prohibit,
abate, suppress and prevent all things detrimental to the health, morals,
comfort, safety, convenience and welfare of the inhabitants of the City, and
all nuisances and causes thereof, and to do all things necessary to promote the
health, convenience, comfort and welfare of the City’s citizens and advance the
moral, social, physical and intellectual standard of its citizenship, and
thereby to protect the public health, safety and welfare of city inhabitants by
eliminating nuisances in existing structures, residential and nonresidential,
and on all existing premises; to prevent the blighting of the City’s
neighborhoods; to promote peaceful and safe communities; and to provide for
administration, enforcement and penalties.
(Ord. 124-06.  Passed 04-24-2006.)
2002.03   EXISTING REMEDIES.
   The provisions of this Code shall not be construed to abolish or impair
existing remedies or the jurisdiction of city officers or departments relating
to the removal or demolition of any structure which is dangerous, unsafe or
unsanitary or relating to violations and orders regarding property maintenance
or building code requirements. 
(Ord. 124-06.  Passed 04-24-2006.)
2002.04   WORKMANSHIP/APPLICATION OF OTHER CODES.
   All repairs, maintenance work, alterations and installations which are
caused directly or indirectly by the enforcement of this Code shall be executed
and installed in a workmanlike manner and in accordance with applicable
property maintenance, building, plumbing and mechanical codes.
(Ord. 124-06.  Passed 04-24-2006.)
2002.05   UNLAWFUL ACTS.
   No person, firm or corporation shall erect, construct, alter, extend,
repair, remove, demolish, maintain, fail to maintain, provide, fail to provide,
occupy, let to another to occupy, or permit another person to occupy, any
structure or equipment regulated by this Code, or cause the same to be done,
contrary to, in conflict with or in violation of any of the provisions of this
Code, or fail to obey a lawful order of the Public Nuisance Administrator, or
remove or deface a placard or notice posted under the provisions of this Code. 
(Ord. 124-06.  Passed 04-24-2006.)
2002.06   PROHIBITION AGAINST TRANSFER OF OWNERSHIP.
   No owner of any property, dwelling unit or structure who has received a
public nuisance order or upon whom a public nuisance order has been served
shall sell, transfer, mortgage, lease or otherwise dispose of the unit or
structure to another until the provisions of the compliance order or notice of
violation have been complied with, or until such owner shall first furnish the
grantee, transferee, mortgagee or lessee a true copy of any compliance order or
notice of violation issued by the Public Nuisance Administrator, and furnish to
the Public Nuisance Administrator a signed and notarized statement from the
grantee, transferee, mortgagee or lessee, acknowledging the receipt of such
compliance order or notice of violation and fully accepting the responsibility,
without condition, for making the corrections or repairs required by such
public nuisance order or abatement/rehabilitation plan.
(Ord. 124-06.  Passed 04-24-2006.)
2002.07   RULES OF CONSTRUCTION.
   (A)   Terms Defined in Other Parts. Where terms are not defined in this Code
and are defined in other chapters of the Lima Codified Ordinances, such terms
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in those chapters.
   (B)   Terms Not Defined. Where terms are not defined in this Public Nuisance
Code, or in any other section of the Lima Codified Ordinances, such terms shall
have ordinarily accepted meanings such as the context implies. 
   (C)   Terms to Include "Or Any Part Thereof."  Whenever the words "dwelling
unit," "dwelling," "premises," "building," "rooming house," "rooming unit,"
"story" and "structure" are used in this Public Nuisance Code, they shall be
construed as though they were followed by the words "or any part thereof."
(Ord. 124-06.  Passed 04-24-2006.)
2002.08   PUBLIC NUISANCE DEFINED.
   For purposes of this Code a finding of at least one of the following
conditions supports the conclusion that the building, structure, parcel of real
property, premises, or portion thereof, constitutes a hazard to the public,
health, morals, safety, and welfare of the inhabitants of the City;
   (A)   Any building, structure, or portion thereof, has become so dilapidated
or deteriorated, by failure to repair and maintain or by fire or weather
damage, as to become and attractive nuisance to children, a harbor for
vagrants, criminals, or as to enable persons to resort thereto for the purpose
of committing unlawful or immoral acts; or
   (B)   Any premises that is manifestly capable of being a fire hazard or that
is in such a condition to be dangerous to anyone at or near the premises; or
   (C)   Any building or structure that is open, vacant or abandoned, that is
overcrowded, that is damaged by fire to such an extent that it does not provide
shelter or that is danger of collapse or failure, or is manifestly unsafe or
unsecured so as to endanger life, limb or property; or
   (D)   Any building or structure, used or intended to be used as for dwelling
purposes, because of inadequate maintenance, dilapidation, decay, damage,
faulty construction or arrangement, inadequate light, air or sanitation
facilities or otherwise, is determined to be unsanitary, unfit for habitation,
or in such a condition that is likely to cause sickness and disease;
   (E)   Any premises from which plumbing, heating or other facilities may be
required have been removed, or from which utilities have been disconnected,
destroyed, removed, or rendered ineffective, or from which the required
precautions against trespassers has not been provided; 
   (F)   Any premises that is subject to notice or order of property
maintenance violations, as provided in Chapter 18 of the Lima Codified
Ordinances; building code adjudication order, notice of violation, cease and
desist order, or demolition order, as provided in Chapter 14 of the Lima
Codified Ordinances; and/or adjudication order, notice of violation, or cease
and desist order as provided in Chapter 12 of the Lima Codified Ordinances; or,
   (G)   Any premises wherein there is present noxious or offensive odors or
noise, repeated breaches to the peace of the neighborhood, loitering, or
unsanitary conditions which are a menace to the health, comfort, or safety of
the community.  The source of such odors, noise, breaches of peace, or
unsanitary conditions may be derived from the conduct of persons and/or the
harboring or keeping of animals or foul;
   (H)   Any premises that is unsafe and unsanitary, or that is littered with
rubbish, offal, garbage, contains sewage, stagnant water, or that has an
uncontrolled growth of weeds, grass or other vegetation so as to interfere with
the reasonable and lawful use and enjoyment of premises within the
neighborhood; or
   (I)   Any building, structure, premises or portion thereof, is in such
condition as to constitute a public nuisance by common law or as otherwise
defined by statute, regulation, or codified ordinance as a public nuisance.
(Ord. 124-06.  Passed 04-24-2006.)
2002.09   SEVERABILITY.
   If any section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this
Code shall be declared invalid for any reason whatsoever, such decision shall
not affect the remaining portions of this Code which shall continue in full
force and effect, and to this end the provisions of this Code are hereby
declared to be severable.
(Ord. 124-06.  Passed 04-24-2006.)
2002.10   SAVING CLAUSE.
   This Code shall not affect violations of any other ordinance, code or
regulation existing prior to the effective date hereof, and any such violation
shall be removed and shall continue to be punishable to the full extent of the
law under the provisions of those ordinances, codes or regulations in effect at
the time the violation was committed.
(Ord. 124-06.  Passed 04-24-2006.)
CHAPTER 2004
Public Nuisance Administrator
2004.01   Authority of Public Nuisance Administrator Generally.
2004.02   Authority of Administrator on Notices and Orders.
2004.03   Right of Entry.
2004.04   Access By Owner or Operator.
2004.05   Rule-Making Authority.
2004.06   Relief From Personal Responsibility
2004.01   AUTHORITY OF PUBLIC NUISANCE ADMINISTRATOR GENERALLY.
   (A)   The Public Nuisance Administrator, as designated by the Mayor, shall
enforce all of the provisions of this Code.
   (B)   Whenever the Public Nuisance Administrator is notified by complaint
that a property may be a public nuisance, as defined in this Code, he/she shall
promptly cause the premises to be inspected and photographed.  If the complaint
is substantiated the Public Nuisance Administrator or his/her designee shall 
gather appropriate information from City departments and governmental agencies,
such as utility records, property maintenance complaints, building and zoning
permits, orders and adjudications, fire reports, police reports, health
department records, bankruptcy notices, and public records indicating ownership
of the property and payment of real estate taxes.
   (C)   If upon review of the information obtained the Public Nuisance
Administrator finds that a public nuisance exists, he/she shall cause
notification of the finding to be served upon the record owner and posted upon
the premises where appropriate.
(Ord. 124-06.  Passed 04-24-2006.)
2004.02   AUTHORITY OF ADMINISTRATOR ON NOTICES AND ORDERS.
   The Public Nuisance Administrator shall issue all necessary notices and
orders to ensure compliance with this Code.
(Ord. 124-06.  Passed 04-24-2006.)
2004.03   RIGHT OF ENTRY.
   The Property Nuisance Administrator is authorized to enter a structure or
premises at reasonable times to inspect the same. Prior to entering into a
space not otherwise open to the general public, the Property Nuisance
Administrator, or his or her designee, shall make a reasonable effort to locate
the owner or other person having charge or control of the structure or
premises, present proper identification and request entry. If requested entry
is refused or otherwise not obtained, the Public Nuisance Administrator shall
have recourse as provided by law.
(Ord. 124-06.  Passed 04-24-2006.)
2004.04   ACCESS BY OWNER OR OPERATOR.
   Every occupant of a structure or premises shall give the owner or operator
thereof, or his agent or employee, access to any part of such structure or its
premises at reasonable times for the purpose of making such inspections,
maintenance, repairs or alterations as are necessary to comply with the
provisions of this Code.
(Ord. 124-06.  Passed 04-24-2006.)
2004.05   RULE-MAKING AUTHORITY.
   The Public Nuisance Administrator shall have power, as necessary in the
interest of the public health, safety and general welfare, to adopt and
promulgate rules and regulations to interpret, implement and enforce the
provisions of this Code, to secure the intent thereof, and to designate
requirements applicable because of local climatic or other conditions. Such
rules shall not have the effect of waiving building, structural or fire
performance requirements specifically provided for in this Code or of violating
accepted engineering practices involving public safety.
(Ord. 124-06.  Passed 04-24-2006.)
2004.06   RELIEF FROM PERSONAL RESPONSIBILITY.
   The Public Nuisance Administrator charged with the enforcement of this Code,
while acting for the jurisdiction, shall not thereby be rendered liable
personally, and is hereby relieved from all personal liability for any damage
accruing to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in
the discharge of official duties.
(Ord. 124-06.  Passed 04-24-2006.)
CHAPTER 2006
Notices and Appeals
2006.01   Notice Requirements.
2006.02   Appeals.
2006.01   NOTICE REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Whenever the Public Nuisance Administrator determines that there has
been a violation of this Code or has grounds to believe that a violation has
occurred, notice shall be given to the owner or the person or persons
responsible therefor, as well as any known lien holders, in the manner
prescribed herein.
   (B)   The notice prescribed shall:
      (1)   Be in writing;
      (2)   Include a description of the real estate sufficient for
identification;
      (3)   Include a statement of the reason or reasons why the notice is
being issued;
      (4)   Include a correction order allowing a reasonable time to abate the
nuisance, enter into a rehabilitation plan, list the property for sale,
requiring public nuisance registration, and otherwise comply with the
provisions of this Code; and
      (5)   Include a statement notifying the person of any administrative
appeal rights and procedures. 
   (C)   Method of Service - The notice prescribed shall be served by one of
the following methods:
      (1)   Delivery by personal service upon the person to whom the notice is
directed; or
      (2)   Sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, and regular U.S.
mail, evidenced by a Certificate of Mailing addressed to such person at his or
her last known address; or
      (3)   If the certified or regular mail letter is returned showing that
the letter was not delivered because the addressee no longer lives there or is
unknown, or because a wrong address was used, and no other address is known,
then a copy of said notice shall be posted in a conspicuous place in or about
the structure affected by such notice, and the notice shall be published once
in a publication having general circulation in Allen County. When such a notice
is so published, any time periods referenced in the notice shall commence from
the date of publication. Service of such notice in the foregoing manner upon
the owner's agent or upon the person responsible for the premises shall
constitute service of notice upon the owner.
(Ord. 124-06.  Passed 04-24-2006.) 
2006.02   APPEALS.
   (A)   The owner or other responsible person named in a notice finding a
property to be a public nuisance, order to abate a public nuisance, or subject
to a denial of an abatement plan may make a demand in writing (otherwise
referred to as appeal) for a hearing on any legal or factual issue relating to
notice of public nuisance and/or orders to abate or abatement plan
determination made by the Public Nuisance Administrator pursuant to authority
of this Code. Such appeal shall be heard by the Board of Building Appeals as
set forth in
Chapter 1406 of these Codified Ordinances.
   (B)   The Public Nuisance Administrator shall take immediate action in
accordance with the decision of the Board of Building Appeals.
   (C)   Any person adversely affected by a ruling or order of the Board of
Building Appeals, including the Public Nuisance Administrator, shall have the
right to appeal to the appropriate court in the manner and time required by law
following the filing of the decision of the Board in the office of the Public
Nuisance Administrator.
(Ord. 124-06.  Passed 04-24-2006.) 
CHAPTER 2008
Requirements, Enforcement and Penalties
2008.01   Orders To Abate and Abatement Plans.
2008.02   Civil Proceedings.
2008.03   Criminal Proceedings.
2008.04   Registration.
2008.05   Civil Penalties.
2008.01   ORDERS TO ABATE AND ABATEMENT PLANS
   (A)   Order to Abate. When a property is found to be a public nuisance the
Public Nuisance Administrator may order the owner, and person(s) occupying the
premises where appropriate, to abate the public nuisance within 10 days.  Any
person in the position of owner, at the time an order pursuant to this Code is
issued and served upon him or her, shall be responsible for complying with that
order and liable for penalties and costs associated therewith. 
   (B)   Abatement Plan. Within 10 days of the issuance of the order to abate
the public nuisance, the owner may elect to file an abatement plan which must
include one of the following terms:
      (1)   Rehabilitation Plan.  A plan that sets forth a practicable
rehabilitation schedule designed to eliminate any condition constituting a
public nuisance.  The Public Nuisance Administrator will not approve plans that
do not remove all nuisances within a three (3) month period;
      (2)   Property Sales Plan.  A plan that places the property for sale with
a licensed realtor or causes weekly publication in a newspaper of general
circulation, an advertisement of sale of the property;
      (3)   Demolition Plan.  A plan indicating the intent to timely demolish
accompanied by a properly issued demolition permit. 
   (C)   Terms of Plans
      (1)   Specified Time Periods. In order to be approved each Abatement Plan
must contain a date certain for completion, to be no longer than three (3)
months following the finding of the public nuisance.  The Public Nuisance
Administrator may extend the plan for one period, not to exceed three (3)
months, for good cause, upon proper showing of substantial work completed on
the plan, or extreme hardship. 
      (2)   Financial Ability.  The owner must present information with the
Abatement or Demolition Plan regarding his/her financial ability to complete
rehabilitation or demolition within the prescribed time period.  The Public
Nuisance Administrator will provide information to the owner regarding
financial assistance that may be available through City programming.   
   (D)   Plan Approval.  The Public Nuisance Administrator shall examine the
owner’s proposal and timetable to see if it is a reasonable response which will
eliminate the nuisance condition on the premises or related to a structure.  If
the Public Nuisance Administrator determines that the proposed timetable
outlined to rehabilitate, sell, or demolish is reasonable and the proposed work
will result in bringing the structure into compliance with the law, then the
owners proposal shall be approved and become an order of the Public Nuisance
Administrator. 
   (E)   Plan Disapproval.  If the Public Nuisance Administrator determines
that the timetable is unreasonable, or that the proposed work program will not
bring the structure or premises in compliance with law or that there is no
financial ability to  complete the work program, the Public Nuisance
Administrator shall disapprove the proposal, state the reasons therefore in
writing, and the City shall continue enforcement of the abatement order to
require securing of the structure, sale of property, rehabilitation, and/or
demolition. 
   (F)   Abatement Costs.  If the owner fails to abate the nuisance within the
10 day period following the finding of the public nuisance or otherwise fails
to respond with an appropriate abatement plan, the Public Nuisance
Administrator, may issue a supplemental order requiring the owner to abate the
nuisance or pay costs to the City for such abatement.  Such costs may be
certified by Council to the County Auditor and placed upon the tax duplicate
for collection as a special assessment and thereupon shall be collected as
other taxes and assessments.
(Ord. 124-06.  Passed 04-24-2006.)
2008.02   CIVIL PROCEEDINGS.
   The Director of Law is authorized to commence a civil action in the Common
Pleas Court of Allen County requesting an order of the Court enforcing
Abatement Orders, including but not limited to, orders of sale, orders to
demolish, and orders to rehabilitate.  The Law Director is further authorized
to seek other remedies such as receivership or foreclosure actions on the
property.
(Ord. 124-06.  Passed 04-24-2006.)
2008.03   CRIMINAL PROCEEDINGS.
   A person who causes or maintains a property found to be a public nuisance,
pursuant to and in violation of this Code, or fails to comply with an order to
abate issued by the Public Nuisance Administrator, upon conviction thereof,
shall be subject to the following penalties;
   (a)   For a first conviction, a misdemeanor of the fourth degree, and shall
be fined not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not
more than thirty days, or both.
   (b)   For a second conviction, a misdemeanor of the third degree, and shall
be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned not more
than sixty days, or both.
   (c)   For a third conviction, a misdemeanor of the second degree, and shall
be fined not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) or imprisoned not
more than ninety days, or both.
   (d)   For a fourth or subsequent conviction, a misdemeanor of the first
degree, and shall be fined not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000) or
imprisoned not more than six months, or both.
(Ord. 124-06.  Passed 04-24-2006.)
2008.04   REGISTRATION.
   Any person who causes or maintains a property found to be a public nuisance,
pursuant to and in violation of this Code, shall be required to register the
property with the Public Nuisance Administrator for a registration fee of Five
Hundred Dollars ($500.00) and provide proof of insurance on the premises or
must post a bond sufficient to cover costs associated with demolition, as
determined appropriate by the Public Nuisance Administrator.  Registration
requirements shall continue until the Public Nuisance Administrator determines
that the public nuisance has been abated.  Two Hundred and Fifty Dollars
($250.00) of the registration fee may be refunded upon timely completion of and
full compliance with the initial abatement plan.
(Ord. 124-06.  Passed 04-24-2006.)
2008.05   CIVIL PENALTIES.
   Any person who fails to register the property, post bond or provide proof of
insurance shall be assessed a civil penalty of Three Hundred and Fifty Dollars
($350.00) which will then be levied against the owner.  In the event that the
person fails to pay the Civil Penalty, or portion thereof, within thirty (30)
days after being notified in writing, by regular U.S. Mail, or posting on the
premises, of the amount thereof by the Public Nuisance Administrator, such
amount may be collected by using one or more of the following methods, provided
however that the civil penalty is collected once:
   (A)   Such penalties may be certified by Council to the County Auditor and
placed upon the tax duplicate for collection as a special assessment and
thereupon shall be collected as other taxes and assessments; or
   (B)   The Director of Law is authorized to bring suit for judgment and take
other necessary legal action to collect such penalties.
(Ord. 124-06.  Passed 04-24- 2006.)
CHAPTER 2010
Board of Public Nuisance Appeals
2010.01   Creation; Membership.
2010.02   Powers and Duties.
2010.03   Vote.
2010.04   Appeals.
2010.05   Variances.
2010.06   Fees For Appeals.
2010.01   CREATION; MEMBERSHIP.
   (A)   There is hereby created a Board of Public Nuisance Appeals in and for
the City. Such Board shall consist of five residents of the City, each to be
appointed by the Mayor and confirmed by Council, for terms of three years.
(Ord. 259-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
   (B)   There is hereby created the position of Clerk to the Board of Public
Nuisance Appeals, which shall be filled as determined by the Chief of Police.
(Ord. 259-06.  Passed 11- 06-2006.)
2010.02   POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Board of Public Nuisance Appeals shall adopt, from time to time, such
rules and regulations as it may deem necessary to carry into effect the
provisions of the Drug House Nuisance Abatement Code.  A quorum shall consist
of three members.  Upon request from any affected person, the Board shall hear
and decide appeals from and shall review any order, requirement, decision or
determination made by the Drug House Nuisance Administrator in the
administration of the Drug House Nuisance Abatement Code.
(Ord. 259-06.  Passed 11- 06-2006.)
2010.03   VOTE.
   The concurring vote of three members of the Board shall be necessary to
reverse or modify any order, requirement, decision or determination from which
there has been an appeal.
(Ord. 259-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
2010.04   DECISIONS.
   The Board may reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or may modify the order,
requirements, decision or determination appealed from. The Board shall make
such order, requirement, decision or determination as, in its opinion, ought to
be made in the premises, and to that end shall have the powers of the office
from which the appeal is taken.
(Ord. 259-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
2010.05   VARIANCES.
   The Board shall have the power, in specific cases where, owing to special
conditions a literal enforcement of the provisions of the Drug House Nuisance
Abatement Code will result in unnecessary hardship, to so vary the application
of such provisions in harmony with the public interest, health, safety, and
welfare, and with the spirit of said Code, SO that substantial justice shall be
done.
(Ord. 259-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
2010.06   FEES FOR APPEALS.
   Any person desiring to file an appeal before the Board shall pay a fee of
seventy-five dollars ($75.00) to cover the costs of necessary investigation,
legal notices and other expense incidental to the determination of such matter.
The payment of such fee shall be a prerequisite to the consideration of any
such matter by the Board, unless so waived by the Board upon a showing of good
cause. Such fees shall be deposited with the Clerk of the Board, who shall
thereupon deliver the money to the City Treasurer to be credited to the General
Fund of the City.
(Ord. 259-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
TITLE FOUR - DRUG HOUSE NUISANCE ABATEMENT CODE
         
Chap. 2020   General Provisions and Definitions
         
Chap. 2022   Drug House Nuisance Administrator
         
Chap. 2024   Notices and Appeals
         
Chap. 2026   Requirements, Enforcement and Penalties
CHAPTER 2020
General Provisions and Definitions
2020.01   Title.
2020.02   Purpose and Intent.
2020.03   Existing Remedies.
2020.04   Workmanship/Application of other Codes
2020.05   Unlawful Acts.
2020.06   Prohibition against transfer of Ownership.
2020.07   Rules of Construction.
2020.08   Drug House; Public Nuisance Defined.
2020.09   Severability.
2020.10   Saving Clause.
2020.01   TITLE.
   This Part Twenty, Title Four of these Codified Ordinances shall be known as
the Drug House Nuisance Abatement Code of Lima, Ohio, hereinafter referred to
as "this Code."
(Ord. 258-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
2020.02   PURPOSE AND INTENT.
   The purposes and intent of this Code are to enforce part of  Section 1 of
the City Charter which gives Council the authority by ordinance to define,
prohibit, abate, suppress and prevent all things detrimental to the health,
morals, comfort, safety, convenience and welfare of the inhabitants of the
City, and all nuisances and causes thereof; authorizes Council by ordinance to
do all things necessary to promote the health, convenience, comfort and welfare
of the City’s citizens and advance the moral, social, physical and intellectual
standard of its citizenship; and thereby to protect the public health, safety
and welfare of city inhabitants by eliminating nuisances in structures and on
premises which are used for illegal drug activity; to prevent the blighting of
the City’s neighborhoods; to promote peaceful and safe communities; and to
provide for administration, enforcement and penalties of this Code.
(Ord. 258-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
2020.03   EXISTING REMEDIES.
   The provisions of this Code shall not be construed to abolish or impair
existing remedies or the jurisdiction of city officials or departments relating
to the enforcement of any federal, state, or municipal criminal law, or the
enforcement of any other law, ordinance, rule or regulation affecting a subject
premises or the occupants thereof.
(Ord. 258-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
2020.04   WORKMANSHIP/APPLICATION OF OTHER CODES.
   All repairs, maintenance work, alterations and installations which are
caused directly or indirectly by the enforcement of this Code shall be executed
and installed in a workmanlike manner and in accordance with property
maintenance,  building, plumbing, mechanical and other applicable codes or
laws.
(Ord. 258-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
2020.05   UNLAWFUL ACTS.
   No person or entity shall erect, construct, alter, extend, repair, remove,
demolish, maintain, fail to maintain, provide, fail to provide, occupy, let to
another to occupy, or permit another person to occupy, any structure or
premises regulated by this Code, or cause the same to be done, contrary to, in
conflict with or in violation of any of the provisions of this Code, or fail to
obey a lawful order of the Drug House Nuisance Administrator, or remove or
deface a placard or notice posted under the provisions of this Code. 
(Ord. 258-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
2020.06   PROHIBITION AGAINST TRANSFER OF OWNERSHIP.
   No owner of any structure or premise who is the subject of a nuisance order
under this Code shall sell, transfer, mortgage, lease or otherwise dispose of
the property to another until the provisions of the nuisance order have been
complied with, or until such owner shall first furnish the grantee, transferee,
mortgagee or lessee a true copy of any nuisance order issued under this Code,
and furnishes to the Administrator a signed and notarized statement from the
grantee, transferee, mortgagee or lessee, acknowledging the receipt of such
nuisance order and fully accepting the responsibility, without condition, for
taking the actions necessary to comply with the nuisance order, abatement plan
thereunder, and any other provisions of this Code.
(Ord. 258-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
2020.07   RULES OF CONSTRUCTION.
   (A)   Terms Defined in Other Parts. Where terms are not defined in this Code
and are defined in other chapters of the Lima Codified Ordinances, such terms
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in those chapters.
   (B)   Terms Not Defined. Where terms are not defined in this Code, or in any
other section of the Lima Codified Ordinances, such terms shall have ordinarily
accepted meanings such as the context implies. 
   (C)   Terms to Include "Or Any Part Thereof."  Whenever the words "dwelling
unit," "dwelling," "premises," "building," "rooming house," "rooming unit,"
"story" and "structure" are used in this Code, they shall be construed as
though they were followed by the words "or any part thereof," and shall include
the exterior lands surrounding the premises.
(Ord. 258-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
2020.08   DRUG HOUSE;  PUBLIC NUISANCE DEFINED.
   (A)   Drug House.  A “Drug House” is any premises or structure within which,
or upon the grounds of, illegal drug activity has taken place, as shown by a
preponderance of the evidence, regardless of whether there has been any
criminal conviction in a court of law for such activity.
   (B)   Illegal Drug Activity.  Illegal Drug Activity means any conduct which
would constitute a violation of any provision of Ohio Revised Code Chapter 2925
or any similar provision of any federal or local law, regardless of whether
there has been a criminal conviction for the same activity.
   (C)   Public Nuisance.  Any structure or premise which is determined to be a
Drug House under this Code is hereby determined to be a public nuisance,
subject to the abatement procedures set forth in this Code.
(Ord. 258-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
2020.09   SEVERABILITY.
   If any section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this
Code shall be declared invalid for any reason whatsoever, such decision shall
not affect the remaining portions of this Code which shall continue in full
force and effect, and to this end the provisions of this Code are hereby
declared to be severable.
(Ord. 258-06.  Passed 11-06- 2006.)
2020.10   SAVING CLAUSE.
   This Code shall not affect violations of any other ordinance, code or
regulation existing prior to the effective date hereof, and any such violation
shall continue to be punishable to the full extent of the law under the
provisions of those ordinances, codes or regulations in effect at the time the
violation was committed.
(Ord. 258-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
CHAPTER 2022
Drug House Nuisance Administrator
2022.01   Authority - Generally.
2022.02   Authority on Notices and Orders.
2022.03   Right of Entry.
2022.04   Access by Owner or Operator.
2022.05   Rule- Making Authority
2022.06   Relief from Personal Responsibility.
2022.01   AUTHORITY OF DRUG HOUSE NUISANCE ADMINISTRATOR GENERALLY.
   (A)   The Drug House Nuisance Administrator (hereafter referred to as the
Administrator), shall be designated by the Mayor, and shall enforce, or
coordinate the enforcement of, all of the provisions of this Code.
   (B)   Whenever the Administrator is notified that a structure or premises
may be a public nuisance as a Drug House, as defined in this Code, the
Administrator shall conduct an investigation into the matter to determine
whether there exists a Drug House.
   (C)   If the Administrator  determines there is insufficient evidence to
determine the existence of a Drug House, he shall close his investigation and
keep a file of the record of his investigation in accordance with the City’s
record retention schedule.
   (D)   If the Administrator  determines there is sufficient evidence to
determine the existence of a Drug House he shall determine if the owner of the
premises knew or reasonably should have known of the existence or likelihood of
the drug activity.
      (1)   In determining if an owner “reasonably should have known of the
existence or likelihood of the drug activity” an objective standard of a
reasonable person shall be used, not the subjective knowledge of the actual
owner.
   (E)   If the Administrator  determines there is sufficient evidence to
determine the existence of a Drug House and that the owner of the premises knew
or reasonably should have known of the existence or likelihood of the drug
activity, he shall so notify the Law Director who shall determine the
appropriateness of legal proceedings to be instituted in accordance with any
applicable provision of this Code.
   (F)   If the Administrator  determines there is sufficient evidence to
determine the existence of a Drug House and that the owner of the premises did
not know or reasonably would not have known of the existence or likelihood of
the drug activity, the Administrator shall issue a Determination of Public
Nuisance and Order of Abatement to the owner of the premises.
      (1)   The owner shall have the right to appeal the Determination and
Order to the  Public Nuisance Appeals Board.
(Ord. 258-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
2022.02   AUTHORITY OF ADMINISTRATOR ON NOTICES AND ORDERS.
   The Drug House  Nuisance Administrator or his designee shall issue all
necessary notices and orders to ensure compliance with this Code.
(Ord. 258-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
2022.03   RIGHT OF ENTRY.
   The Administrator is authorized to enter a structure or premises only upon
obtaining the consent of a person who reasonably appears authorized to give
such consent, or under authority of a search warrant approved by an appropriate
judicial officer.
(Ord. 258-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
2022.04   ACCESS BY OWNER OR OPERATOR.
   Every occupant of a structure or premises shall give the owner or the
owner’s agent, employee, or designee access to any part of such structure or
its premises at reasonable times for the purpose of making such inspections,
maintenance, repairs or alterations as are necessary to comply with the
provisions of this Code.
(Ord. 258-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
2022.05   RULE-MAKING AUTHORITY.
   The Drug House  Nuisance Administrator shall have the power, as necessary in
the interest of the public health, safety and general welfare, to adopt and
promulgate rules and regulations to interpret, implement and enforce the
provisions of this Code, to secure the intent thereof, and to designate
requirements applicable because of local or other conditions. Such rules shall
not have the effect of waiving property maintenance, building, structural or
fire performance requirements specifically provided for by City Ordinance or of
violating accepted engineering practice involving public safety.
(Ord. 258-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
2022.06   RELIEF FROM PERSONAL RESPONSIBILITY.
   The Administrator charged with the enforcement of this Code, while acting
for the City, shall not thereby be rendered liable personally, and is hereby
relieved from all personal liability for any damage accruing to persons or
property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of
official duties.
(Ord. 258-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
CHAPTER 2024
Notices and Appeals
2024.01   Notice Requirements
2024.02   Nuisance Abatement Order.
2024.03   Future Drug Activity; Compliance - Non Compliance.
2024.04   Failure to comply with Nuisance Abatement Order.
2024.05   Appeals.
2024.01   NOTICE REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Whenever the Administrator determines that there has been a violation
of this Code, notice shall be given to the owner of the property or the person
or persons responsible therefor, as well as any known lien holders of record,
in the manner prescribed herein.
   (B)   The notice prescribed shall:
      (1)   Be in writing;
      (2)   Include a description of the real estate sufficient for
identification;
      (3)   Include a statement of the reason or reasons why the notice is
being issued;
      (4)   Include an abatement order allowing a reasonable time to abate the
nuisance, enter into a rehabilitation plan, list the property for sale,
requiring Drug House nuisance registration, and otherwise comply with the
provisions of this Code; and
      (5)   Include a statement notifying the person of any administrative
appeal rights and procedures. 
   (C)   Method of Service - The notice prescribed shall be served by one of
the following methods:
      (1)   Delivery by personal service upon the person to whom the notice is
directed; or
      (2)   Sent by regular U.S. mail, evidenced by a Certificate of Mailing
addressed to such person at his or her last known address as reflected in the
records of the Allen County Auditor.
      (3)   If no address is available, then a copy of said notice shall be
posted in a conspicuous place in or about the structure or premises affected by
such notice, and the notice shall be published once in a publication having
general circulation in Allen County. When such a notice is so published, any
time periods referenced in the notice shall commence from the date of
publication.
      (4)   Service of such notice in the foregoing manner upon the owner's
agent or upon the person otherwise responsible for the premises shall
constitute service of notice upon the owner. 
      (5)   Lienholders shall be served in the same manner as set forth herein.
(Ord. 258-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
2024.02   NUISANCE ABATEMENT ORDER
   (A)   The Nuisance Abatement Order issued pursuant to this Code shall
include the following provisions:
   (1)   The owner must register the Drug House with Lima Police Department and
pay a $500 annual fee, until such time as the Drug House is removed from the
registration list by the Administrator  or the Public Nuisance Appeals Board.
   (2)   The owner must begin proceedings to evict the existing tenants or
occupants involved in the illegal drug activity.
   (3)   New tenants must have a Lima Police Department (LPD) background check.
      (4)   New tenants must be given a written lease prohibiting illegal drug
activity.
   (5)   The owner or his agent must physically inspect the house once every
three months for potential drug activity, Property Maintenance Code violations,
and unauthorized tenants.  The owner must file the inspection reports with LPD
within 10 days of the inspection.
   (6)   Any other factors the Administrator  determines are reasonably related
to the abatement of the nuisance under the particular circumstances.
(Ord. 258-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
2024.03   FUTURE DRUG ACTIVITY; COMPLIANCE AND NONCOMPLIANCE
   (A)   If the owner complies with the Nuisance Abatement Order, and there is
future drug activity with a new tenant, the Administrator  shall conduct a new
investigation pursuant to this Code. 
   (1)   If there are no circumstances to indicate the owner knew or should
have known of possible drug activity, a new Nuisance Abatement Order shall be
issued.
      (2)   If there are circumstances to indicate owner knew or should have
known of possible drug activity, he shall so notify the Law Director who shall
determine the appropriateness of legal proceedings to be instituted in
accordance with this Code, and take all necessary action thereunder.
   (B)   If the owner fails to comply with the Nuisance Abatement Order, and
there is future drug activity with the same or a new tenant, the Administrator 
shall conduct a new investigation pursuant to this Code.  If there are
circumstances to indicate the owner knew or should have known of possible drug
activity, he shall so notify the Law Director who shall determine the
appropriateness of legal proceedings to be instituted in accordance with this
Code, and take all necessary action thereunder.
(Ord. 258-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
2024.04   FAILURE TO COMPLY WITH NUISANCE ABATEMENT ORDER
   (A)   If the owner fails to comply with the Nuisance Abatement Order, the
Administrator shall issue such a finding and Order the owner to post a $2,500
bond with the City Auditor to cover cost of future illegal drug monitoring by
LPD.
   (B)   LPD may draw against the bond for reimbursement as needed, as reviewed
and approved by City Auditor.  The owner must then replenish the bond.
   (C)   If the owner then sells the property or complies with abatement order,
any unused portion of the bond shall be returned to the person posting the
bond.
   (D)   The requirement for the bond shall remain in place until it is
dispensed with by the Administrator or the Public Nuisance Appeals Board.
   (E)   If the owner fails to post or renew the bond, the Administrator  shall
so notify the Law Director who shall determine the appropriateness of legal
proceedings to be instituted in accordance with this Code, and take all
necessary action thereunder.
(Ord. 258-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
2024.05   APPEALS.
   (A)   Any person or entity named in a notice or order issued by the Drug
House  Nuisance Administrator pursuant to authority of this Code may appeal  to
the Public Nuisance Appeals Board.
   (B)   The Drug House  Nuisance Administrator shall take immediate action in
accordance with the decision of the Public Nuisance Appeals Board.
   (C)   Any person or entity (including the Drug House  Nuisance
Administrator) adversely affected by a ruling or order of the Public Nuisance
Appeals Board, shall have the right to appeal to the appropriate court in the
manner and time required by law, following the filing of the decision of the
Board in the office of the Drug House  Nuisance Administrator and appropriate
service thereof to the affected parties.   
(Ord. 258-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
CHAPTER 2026
Requirements, Enforcement and Penalties
2026.01   Orders to Abate and Abatement Plans.
2026.02   Civil Proceedings.
2026.03   Criminal Proceedings.
2026.04   Registration.
2026.05   Civil Penalties.
2026.01   ORDERS TO ABATE AND ABATEMENT PLANS
   (A)   Order to Abate. When a property is found to be a public nuisance, the
Drug House  Nuisance Administrator may order the owner, and person(s) occupying
the premises where appropriate, to submit a plan within 10 days to abate the
public nuisance. Any person in the position of owner or otherwise responsible
for the premises, at the time an order pursuant to this chapter is issued and
served upon him or her, shall be responsible for complying with that order and
liable for penalties and costs associated therewith. 
   (B)   Abatement Plan. Within 10 days of the issuance of the order to abate
the public nuisance, the owner shall file an abatement plan which must include
one of the following terms
      (1)   Rehabilitation Plan.  A plan that sets forth a practicable
rehabilitation schedule designed to eliminate any condition constituting a
public nuisance.  The Drug House  Nuisance Administrator will not approve plans
that do not remove all nuisances within a three (3) month period;
      (2)   Property Sales Plan.  A plan that places the property for sale with
a licensed realtor or causes an advertisement of sale of the property to be
published weekly in a newspaper of general circulation in Allen County, Ohio;
      (3)   Demolition Plan.  A plan indicating the intent to timely demolish
accompanied by a properly issued demolition permit. 
   (C)   Terms of Plans
      (1)   Specified Time Periods. In order to be approved each Abatement Plan
must contain a date certain for completion, to be no longer than three (3)
months following the finding of the public nuisance.  The Drug House  Nuisance
Administrator may extend the plan or appropriate portion thereof for one
period, not to exceed three (3) months, for good cause, and upon proper showing
of substantial work completed on the plan, or extreme hardship. 
      (2)   Financial Ability.  Additionally the owner must present information
with the Abatement or Demolition Plan regarding the owner’s financial ability
to complete rehabilitation or demolition within the prescribed time period. 
The Drug House  Nuisance Administrator will provide information to the owner
regarding financial assistance that may be available through City programming.
   (D)   Plan Approval.  The Drug House  Nuisance Administrator shall examine
the owner’s proposal and timetable to see if it is a reasonable response which
will eliminate the nuisance condition on the premises or related to a
structure.  If the Drug House  Nuisance Administrator determines that the
proposed timetable outlined to rehabilitate, sell, or demolish is reasonable
and the proposed work will result in bringing the structure into compliance
with the law, then the owner’s proposal shall be approved and become an order
of the Drug House Nuisance Administrator. 
   (E)   Plan Disapproval.  If the Drug House  Nuisance Administrator
determines that the timetable is unreasonable, or that the proposed work
program will not bring the structure or premises in compliance with law or that
there is no financial ability to  complete the work program, the Drug House 
Nuisance Administrator shall disapprove the proposal, state the reasons
therefore in writing, and the City shall continue enforcement of the abatement
order to require securing of the structure, sale of property, rehabilitation,
demolition, or other applicable terms. 
   (F)   Abatement Costs.  If the owner fails to abate the nuisance within the
10-day period following the finding of the public nuisance or otherwise fails
to respond with an appropriate abatement plan, the Drug House  Nuisance
Administrator, may issue a supplemental order requiring the owner to abate the
nuisance or pay costs to the City for such abatement.  Such costs may be
certified by Council to the County Auditor and placed upon the tax duplicate
for collection as a special assessment and thereupon shall be collected as
other taxes and assessments.
(Ord. 258-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
2026.02   CIVIL PROCEEDINGS.
   The Director of Law is authorized to commence a civil action in the Common
Pleas Court of Allen County requesting an order of the Court enforcing
Abatement Orders, including but not limited to, orders of sale, orders to
demolish, and orders to rehabilitate.  The Law Director is further authorized
to seek other remedies such as receivership or foreclosure actions on the
property.  In any civil proceeding involving real estate, due notice shall be
given to all lienholders of record against the subject property.
(Ord. 258-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
2026.03   CRIMINAL PROCEEDINGS.
   A person who causes or maintains a property found to be a public nuisance in
violation of this Code, or fails to comply with an order to abate issued by the
Drug House Nuisance Administrator, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to
the following penalties;
   (A)   For a first conviction, a misdemeanor of the fourth degree.
   (B)   For a second conviction, a misdemeanor of the third degree.
   (C)   For a third conviction, a misdemeanor of the second degree.
   (D)   For a fourth or subsequent conviction, a misdemeanor of the first
degree.
(Ord. 258-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
2026.04   REGISTRATION.
   Any person who causes or maintains a property found to be a public nuisance
in violation of this Code shall be required to register the property with the
Drug House Nuisance Administrator for a registration fee of Five Hundred
Dollars ($500.00) and provide proof of insurance on the premises or must post a
bond sufficient to cover administrative costs associated with the abatement of
the nuisance, as determined appropriate by the Drug House Nuisance
Administrator.  Registration requirements shall continue until the Drug House
Nuisance Administrator determines that the public nuisance has been abated. 
Two Hundred and Fifty Dollars ($250.00) of the registration fee may be refunded
upon timely completion of and full compliance with the initial abatement plan.
(Ord. 258-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
2026.05   CIVIL PENALTIES.
   Any person who fails to register the property, post bond, or provide proof
of insurance shall be assessed a civil penalty of Three Hundred and Fifty
Dollars ($350.00).  In the event that the person fails to pay the Civil
Penalty, or portion thereof, within thirty (30) days after being notified in
writing, by regular U.S. Mail, or posting on the premises, of the amount
thereof by the Drug House  Nuisance Administrator, such amount may be collected
by using one or more of the following methods, provided however that the civil
penalty is collected once:
   (A)   Such penalties may be certified by Council to the County Auditor and
placed upon the tax duplicate for collection as a special assessment and
thereupon shall be collected as other taxes and assessments; or
   (B)   The Director of Law is authorized to bring suit for judgment and take
other necessary legal action to collect such penalties.
(Ord. 258-06.  Passed 11-06-2006.)
